<div class="right bookMeta darkGreyText">    <span class="smallText">(showing 31-60)</span></div><div id="bookReviewControls" data-book-reviews-page="2">  <a class="uitext" id="span_class_actionlink_filter_span_tip_959" style="cursor: pointer; " href="#" onclick="return false"><span class="actionLink">filter</span></a><script>//<![CDATA[      var newTip = new $copy.find('script').remove();          $j('#rating_details_tip').prepend($copy);      }  //]]>  </script></div><div id="bookReviews">    <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section firstReview">      <div id="review_1543853246" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543853246" />    <a title="Chelsea" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/33481873-chelsea"><img alt="Chelsea" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1469800455p2/33481873.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543853246?book_show_action=false">Aug 03, 2016</a>      <a title="Chelsea" class="user" name="Chelsea" href="/user/show/33481873-chelsea">Chelsea</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33481873-chelsea?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543853246" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4349923002236460607">• <a href="https://romweasley.wordpress.com/2016/08/03/harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-this-is-riddikulus-warning-spoilers/" rel="nofollow">review also posted on Wordpress!</a> • <br /><br />Warning: This review contains major spoilers! Don’t read this if you haven’t read the Harry Potter series and Harry Potter and the Cursed Child yet!<br />-------------------------------------<br />If you loved Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, I wouldn’t recommend reading my review. This is going to be a rant! You’ve been warned!<br />-------------------------------------<br />This is the very first time I have rated a book one stars! Believe me, I don’t want to do this, but I real</span>  <span id="freeText4349923002236460607" style="display:none">• <a href="https://romweasley.wordpress.com/2016/08/03/harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-this-is-riddikulus-warning-spoilers/" rel="nofollow">review also posted on Wordpress!</a> • <br /><br />Warning: This review contains major spoilers! Don’t read this if you haven’t read the Harry Potter series and Harry Potter and the Cursed Child yet!<br />-------------------------------------<br />If you loved Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, I wouldn’t recommend reading my review. This is going to be a rant! You’ve been warned!<br />-------------------------------------<br />This is the very first time I have rated a book one stars! Believe me, I don’t want to do this, but I really didn’t enjoy reading Cursed Child. Before I get started, I want you to know the following:<br /><br /> 1. A couple of weeks ago, I read some spoilers from people who had watched the play. Those immediately lowered my expectations. I knew going into this I wasn’t going to like it.<br /> 2. I knew this was not written by J.K. Rowling.<br /> 3. I knew this wasn’t the eight book, but the script for the play.<br /><br />I love the Harry Potter series so much. And I always will. It means a lot to me and when I heard about this, I immediately pre-ordered it. I’ve seen some people say ‘it’s Harry Potter so obviously I love this’, but I can’t say the same. Call me critical but I spent money on this. People spend money on tickets to go see the play. I expect something decent in return then.<br /><br />To call this fanfiction is an insult to all the people who try to bring more joy to a fandom. The Cursed Child was just plain bad writing. I will get into detail later, but I refuse to accept what happened as canon. I don’t care what J.K. Rowling says. This is a disgrace to the characters and the people who loved the original book series. You might think that I’m taking this too seriously, but they shouldn’t ask money for this if it were ‘just for fun’. This is literally being promoted as ‘the eight story’ in the Harry Potter series. I knew before I started it that it wasn’t, but the marketing team pretends it is.<br /><br />So no, I won’t apologise for being critical. Just because this isn’t a book, but a play, doesn’t mean that the story shouldn’t be as good. In fact, that is such an insult to plays! It’s just another form of media. I’ve seen some people say: “You can’t judge this if you haven’t seen the play”. Well, if that’s the case, they shouldn’t have published it as a book. I can’t afford going to London and paying a lot of money in order for some people to validate my opinion.<br /><br />Let’s start of with the things I did like:<br /><br />This felt as if I was reading a book. It didn’t take time to adjust to the format. I’m also curious to see what everything is going to look like in the actual play. But, since I really don’t like the actual story and what they did to the characters, I’m not sure yet whether I’d be willing to pay money for that.<br /><br />Out of all the characters, Hermione was the only one who still resembled who she used to be. I’m proud that she has become Minister for Magic! I also really liked Minerva! And Draco proved he was a good parent (much better than Harry…).<br /><br />I enjoyed the interactions between Albus and Scorpius! They’re such good ‘friends’ (A.K.A. boyfriends).<br /><br />That was it. Those were the only thing I like. My list of dislikes is much longer! I had six full pages of notes. When I read a book that’s over a thousand pages long, I don’t even have that many notes! Let’s get started:<br /><br />The plot is basically 90% about trying to bring back Cedric Diggory. I don’t understand why Albus is so obsessed with Cedric. So many people died for Harry, why does it have to be Cedric? Obviously because Amos asked, but to have almost the entire plot of this play resolve around that…<br /><br />I’d rather read every single second of a class taught at Hogwarts! Because this wasn’t magical enough. Sure, it features the characters we know and love and Hogwarts, but we rarely get to see actual magic. When Albus, Delphi and Scorpius are searching for the Time Turner in Hermione’s office, they don’t even try ‘accio’! Instead, they search the entire bookcase! Whenever we do get some magic, it isn’t explained enough. Why couldn’t Delphi use ‘imperio’ on Albus? She said: “to fulfil the prophecy […] Imperio just won’t do”. Why not? Or when Harry transfigured into Voldemort… Is that even possible? Why would wizards go through the trouble of brewing polyjuice potion then? All of this is just very convenient, but didn’t make enough sense.<br /><br />One of the things that bothered me most, was Ron Weasley’s characterisation. He has become a caricature of the person he used to be. The only reason he’s there, is for comic relief. All he does is eat and make stupid jokes. They act as if he’s so dumb and doesn’t take anything serious. Did Thorne actually read the original series before he wrote this? Because this is not the Ron I know! I refuse to believe that he was so drunk at his own wedding he doesn’t remember anything. And why would Ron give someone love potion? He had a terrible experience with it when he was a teenager, why in the world would he do that? It doesn’t make any sense!<br /><br />Another character who was completely butchered was Cedric Diggory. In the alternate universe where he lost the Triwizard Tournament, he becomes a death-eater and kills Neville. Cedric was one of the kindest characters. It’s absurd to assume that he would become a racist murderer just because he got humiliated!<br /><br />Scorpius said: “Cedric was a different person entirely – dark, dangerous”. We only found out that he killed Neville, but Scorpius didn’t interact with him. I don’t understand where this observation comes from. And I had that feeling quite a few times while reading this; as if I had skipped a couple of pages without realising it.<br /><br />Harry Potter is a terrible father. I didn’t like him once in this ‘book’. Granted, Albus is a whiny teenager: he has no idea how privileged he is. Don’t tell me he doesn’t get special treatment because he’s a Potter. A lot of people have it worse than him. Still, Harry had no right to say the things he did. And his excuse? He didn’t have a father figure growing up. He had plenty! What about Arthur, Sirius, Remus, Hagrid and even Dumbledore, Harry?! Harry had no right to attack Minerva either. Just because a woman doesn’t have children, doesn’t mean she isn’t able to take care of them. She’d be a much better parent than he ever was.<br /><br />And when did he become a psychic? His scar hurts, he actually hears Voldemort’s voice and can speak Parseltongue again, but Delphi hadn’t even saved Voldemort yet (actually, she never does). How is he able to do that if nothing has changed? Voldemort wasn’t back, yet he acted as if he was? Once again, I just don’t understand…<br /><br />Also, what is up with Lily’s blanket? I don’t remember him ever talking about it in the books, yet now Harry pretends as if it’s his most precious possession in the entire world. I know he didn’t possess it in the other books, but it’s still strange that he’s so obsessed with it now.<br /><br />Oh, and the special privileges? Harry is at Hogwarts all the damn time! I don’t remember parents being allowed there. I guess being a Potter does mean you’re allowed to do more than others.<br /><br />A lot of people hate Severus Snape and don’t see him as a brave person. While I don’t feel as strongly about that as them, I completely understand why they feel that was. He was horrible to his pupils, particularly Hermione, Harry and Neville. But, in the alternative universe, Hermione and Ron secretly work together with him. He used to be so mean to them, it seems highly unlikely to me they would forgive him! Just because he didn’t turn out to be a death-eater, doesn’t mean it justifies his behaviour. Snape’s interactions with Scorpius were so cringe-worthy. He isn’t a nice guy who makes one or two jokes and he’d never talk that openly about Lily.<br /><br />Because so many characters felt differently, I didn’t care about them anymore. When Hermione and Ron sacrificed themselves and received the dementor’s kiss, I felt nothing. On the one hand, I’m sad we didn’t get to see Sirius, Remus, Tonks an Teddy. But on the other hand, I’m very glad, since their characters would have been butchered as well!<br /><br />This book almost pretends as if the other Potter and Granger-Weasley kids don’t exist. Ever heard of Hugo???<br /><br />The timeline is so strange. Page 22 and a year has past. Page 27 and they’re already starting their third year at Hogwarts. Seven pages later, another year has past! Surely, they could have given us a glimpse at their lives at Hogwarts without having to do it like this. Later on, Scorpius and Albus are in Scotland, without any brooms or wands. Yet the very next page, they’re already in Godric’s Hollow! How is that even possible? Again, this is not explained.<br /><br />And how did Albus and Scorpius know every single detail from what went down over twenty years ago at the Triwizard Tournament and Battle of Hogwarts? Did their parents tell them literally everything? Were very detailed books written? I need to know this!<br /><br />In the alternate universe, they kept mentioning an ‘Augurey’ and I had no idea what it meant. It’s only explained many scenes later. I cannot stress enough how underdeveloped some plots were. Sometimes, I had no idea what was going on because things weren’t explained well enough. And that causes plot holes.<br /><br />I’m so thankful they didn’t use the Time Turner often in the Harry Potter series. I can already imagine how how things would have ended otherwise: Harry would have gone back in time and kill Voldemort and save James and Lily. Whenever a universe has the ability to time travel, that’s the kind of things that happen. It’s predictable. Yet that’s exactly what Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is about. They go back in time over FOUR TIMES just to go back to how things were at the beginning of the play. It’s such a waste of time. I can think of so many plots that would have been more interesting. Imagine there’s ever going to be a F.R.I.E.N.D.S movie and it turns out Monica has left Chandler and never wants to see her children again. That wouldn’t make any sense at all. But that is how Cursed Child feels like to me.<br /><br />Prisoner of Azkaban is one of my favourite books an films, so I obviously have no problems with time travelling. But this was just too much.<br /><br />As I’ve mentioned before, I really missed the magic. And of course the characters, because Cursed Child completely butchered them. Think of how much better this would be if it was about one school year at Hogwarts, without Voldemort trying to kill everyone. Just one year of the adventures Scorpius and Albus encounter. There didn’t need to be this much family drama. Honestly, I’m pretty sure this was the script of a Days of Our Lives or The Bold and the Beautiful episode instead! Just think how they could have explored the other houses, besides Gryffindor! But no, in Cursed Child, everyone is still prejudiced towards Slytherins and they pretend Ravenclaw and Hufflepuff don’t even exist!<br /><br />This is only about three hundred pages long, yet it was so repetitive. Scorpius and Albus do something stupid; Draco, Harry and Ginny run after them and need Hermione because “their children are missing!” AGAIN!<br /><br />I also had some problems with the writing itself:<br /><br /> Voldemort Day? ‘Oh Potter’ instead of ‘Oh Shit’? Mudbloods in the dungeons? The Blood Ball? WE GET IT, VOLDEMORT IS BACK!<br /><br /> “A Malfoy who may be a Voldemort” Euhm, that’s just awful writing. ‘Voldemort’ isn’t a last name; it’s not as if ‘Lord’ was his first name. It should have been ‘Riddle’ instead.<br /><br /> ‘Thank Dumbledore’ instead of ‘Thank God’ is not only cheesy, it is also incredibly arrogant. I’m not the most religious person but to say that Dumbledore is a God…<br /><br /> It’s so sexist that at the Triwizard Tournament, every school got a lot of cheers besides Beauxbatons! I know boys also attend it, but it’s still more ‘feminine’ than Durmstrang or Hogwarts.<br /><br />Almost everyone who has read this, can’t deny there is something going on between Albus and Scorpius. They are so gay! But of course, this book is heteronormative to the max! I can already hear J.K. Rowling in a couple of years: “Actually, they were dating, but it wasn’t important to the story”. Please don’t give this woman any praise when it comes to diversity, she doesn’t deserve it. The Cursed Child could have meant a great deal more if they weren’t so afraid to include characters who aren’t straight for a change. And don’t even get me started on Albus’ crush on Delphi. He’s like fourteen and she was twenty? That’s disgusting.<br /><br />Which brings me to Delphi, the daughter of Voldemort and Bellatrix. Do you really expect me to believe that Voldemort was capable of love and lust? Why do they feel the need to establish that every character is ‘oh so straight’?! Supposedly, Bellatrix gave birth to Delphi before the Battle of Hogwarts in Malfoy Manor. WHAT?! In Harry Potter and the Deadly Hallows, we actually see her there! Don’t you think anyone would have noticed? DRACO ACTUALLY LIVED THERE! How oblivious is he supposed to be then? This doesn’t make any sense!<br /><br /><b>I could go on, but I think I’ve made my point. There were so many things that bothered me and I don’t ever want to read this again. I regret paying this much money for it. I refuse to accept this as canon. I will pretend this doesn’t exist. <b></b></b></span>  <a data-text-id="4349923002236460607" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1543853246">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1543853246" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1543853246u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1543853246'><a id="like_count_review_1543853246" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1543853246?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">194 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1543853246" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1543853246" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=194u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1543853246u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1543853246" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1543853246, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); I cant believe JK did this to us... because she did! she allowed this script to happen insulting us... harry potter fans and expectations should mean something (im sorry for my grammar, english isnt my first language)</span>  <a data-text-id="1093428116609675099" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Sep 08, 2016 04:15PM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_158420243" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Justyna" href="/user/show/60516535-justyna"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477650464p1/60516535.jpg" alt="60516535" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/60516535-justyna">Justyna</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer12467014656030799685">I couldn't agree more with you, especially with your comments on J. K. Rowling. She's such a disappointment for me (There's nothing wrong in admitting</span>  <span id="freeText12467014656030799685" style="display:none">I couldn't agree more with you, especially with your comments on J. K. Rowling. She's such a disappointment for me (There's nothing wrong in admitting that she wrote Hermione as a black girl and now she's changed her mind. That would be a stronger message that even she is not free from such issues as lack of diversity in literature). I can only add to this that she made a clear division between good and bad characters in her books emphasizing that those evil ones are not pretty or worse they are ugly, fat and dull. It's quite normal for fairy tales that bad characters are revolting but we are speaking about the author who pretends to be a spokesperson for diversity and tolerance. Not everyone has to be slim, bright and pretty. The fact the someone isnt't, doesn't make him/her evil. But it's a clear connection in Rowling's books.<br /><br />I was do excited about Cursed Child that I couldn't wait and I read the story on Wikipedia. Then I tried to read the synopsis but after Rose's comments in Hogwart's Express about how privileged kids they are, I gave up. The whole story is build on many nonsensical ideas.</span>  <a data-text-id="12467014656030799685" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Oct 26, 2016 11:08AM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1543853246' style='display: class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1543958291" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543958291" />    <a title="P " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25327841-p"><img alt="P " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1469415764p2/25327841.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543958291?book_show_action=false">Aug 18, 2016</a>      <a title="P " class="user" name="P " href="/user/show/25327841-p">P </a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543958291" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer151158270286471157"><blockquote> <b>"Harry, there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic. In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again. Be honest to those you love, show your pain. To suffer is as human as to breathe."</b> </blockquote><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1469956335i/19874247._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="250" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b> <u>There are two rules to enjoy this book as much as possible :</u> </b><br>1) You have to overcome the thought you have had in your head that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is the</span>  <span id="freeText151158270286471157" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <b>"Harry, there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic. In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again. Be honest to those you love, show your pain. To suffer is as human as to breathe."</b></blockquote><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1469956335i/19874247._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="250" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>  <u>There are two rules to enjoy this book as much as possible :</u></b><br>1) You have to overcome the thought you have had in your head that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is the sequel to the Harry Potter series.<br>2) Seeing this book as if it's just fanfiction or a script will prevent your disappointment.<br><br>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a script. In my opinion, I look at this as fanfiction of the series I hold close for many years. I protected myself from the feelings that would destroy my time reading this book by repeating that, and it turned out I thoght this book was helplessly fun even if it was not my fondness. However, I had a hunch that Rowling didn't take a big part in this book, it just — weird and wrong; I couldn't smell her signature in there.<br><br>Albus Severus Potter takes a big role in this book. He has problems with his Dad, Harry, so he goes back into the time when Cedric was killed. And the consequence is really bad. REALLY REALLY BAD !<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1469955586ra/19874193.gif" width="400" height="180" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I felt like this was another version of the Harry Potter franchise being thrown into the mix with <i>The Butterfly Effect</i> movie. Whoever wrote this— I can't remember their names— tried to insert and present the old characters to the play and the only way to do this was turning back time. It's so messy and does nothing good. There are many ways to present this without using this <i>Into the Future</i> plot.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1469956335ra/19874248.gif" width="400" height="200" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1469957293i/19874434._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="230" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Instead of turning the prequel to the play, they showed us what happens after the epilogue of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. Act one and two were interesting with a new character I liked. Scorpius, he's Draco's son and has very much chemistry whenever he's with Albus. Just one moment, I thought they're lovers, the dialogue : 'You two — you belong together' made me think that way and I couldn't help myself to ship them so hard till the end.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1469957232i/19874432._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="250" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1469957293i/19874435._SX540_.jpg" width="400" height="250" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><blockquote>  <b>"That’s the thing, isn’t it? About friendships. You don’t know what he needs. You only know he needs it. Find him, Scorpius. You two — you belong together."</b></blockquote><br><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[I wanted to puke when I knew Delphi is the heir of Voldemort and Bellatrix. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> Ummmmmm I don't even know when they had an affair or anything, it seemed unbelievable to me.<br><br>Act four was hard to enjoy, though. I was afraid they might ruin everything in the previous books with a time-travel plot. Alas it ruined some parts of my feeling, but not much. It was just okay because I kept telling myself all the time but this is fanfiction and don't take it serious.<br><br>All in all, I quite enjoyed this but I also hope wholeheartedly that this book is a full-length novel, not a script, or Rowling just let the story end that way with those seven books I want to cherish forever.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1467924179ra/19646955.gif" width="400" height="180" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I have a question. Will this book be turned into a full novel in the near future ? If it's a big YES, I'll read it undoutedly ! Because it might be better if the book is more descriptive than this.<br><br>HP is my life, and this book is a drop of honey to quench my craving this year.<br><br>More at <a target="_blank" href="https://goo.gl/I48iFE" rel="nofollow">https://goo.gl/I48iFE</a> | <a target="_blank" href="http://goo.gl/m88lvl" rel="nofollow">http://goo.gl/m88lvl</a></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="151158270286471157" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544008223" />    <a title="Alejandro" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/665584-alejandro"><img alt="Alejandro" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1328672389p2/665584.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544008223?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Alejandro" class="user" name="Alejandro" href="/user/show/665584-alejandro">Alejandro</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781338099133" href="/book/show/29069989-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-parts-1-2">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=horror">horror</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=paranormal">paranormal</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=military">military</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=espionage">espionage</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=politics">politics</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/665584-alejandro?shelf=novel">novel</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544008223" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7040762897240194827"><b> <u>Wickedly Wonderful!!!</u> </b><br /><br /><br /><i>This is the Eighth book in the “Harry Potter” series. This is not a novel per se, but a special edition featuring the rehearsal script for the theatrical play staged in London.</i><br /><br /><br /><b> <u>THE WAITING TIME</u> </b><br /><br /><b> <i>Love blinds.</i> </b><br /><br />When I knew about the staging of a theatrical play about <i>Harry Potter</i>, it was a bittersweet feeling, since I was happy to know that there will be a new chapter in the wizarding world of <i>Harry Potter</i> but sad since I couldn’t apparate in London to attend to that theatric</span>  <span id="freeText7040762897240194827" style="display:none"><b>  <u>Wickedly Wonderful!!!</u></b><br /><br /><br /><i>This is the Eighth book in the “Harry Potter” series. This is not a novel per se, but a special edition featuring the rehearsal script for the theatrical play staged in London.</i><br /><br /><br /><b>  <u>THE WAITING TIME</u></b><br /><br /><b>  <i>Love blinds.</i></b><br /><br />When I knew about the staging of a theatrical play about <i>Harry Potter</i>, it was a bittersweet feeling, since I was happy to know that there will be a new chapter in the wizarding world of <i>Harry Potter</i> but sad since I couldn’t apparate in London to attend to that theatrical play and it was very unlikely to be ever set here, in Costa Rica. <br /><br />However, I was quite happily shocked when I read that there will be a publication of the theater script, and even better, published just a day later of the premiere of the theatrical play. I guessed that maybe after a couple of years, when the play would be presented in major cities, then, it would be a publication of the story, but happily, I have no doubt that the publishing houses (UK u0026amp; USA) wanted a piece of the magical new cake.<br /><br /><b>  <i>The world changes and we change with it.</i></b><br /><br />So, I counted the days, I enlisted myself in a waiting list in the main local bookstore here. I even checked out twice to verify that I was still in the list! I didn’t want that any Death Eater mischief would deprive me of having the new book of <i>Harry Potter</i>, in the very day of its publication.<br />Since the last book (the seventh) of <i>Harry Potter</i>, I’d read the novels of <i>Cormoran Strike</i> series, written also by J.K. Rowling (under the pseudonym of “Robert Galbraith”), and not matter my opinion about those books…<br /><br />…it wasn’t the same!<br /><br />They weren’t <i>Harry Potter</i> books!!!<br /><br />This incoming (and already published) book was something else, it was a <b>NEW</b> story about the wizarding world of <i>Harry Potter</i>.<br /><br />And I was there, in the bookstore, buying the book, and once I had it finally in my hands…<br /><br />…I had a wicked smile in my face!<br /><br /><br /><b>  <u>WHAT YOU HAVE IN YOUR HANDS</u></b><br /><br /><b>  <i>…there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic.</i></b><br /><br />I loved the book! I-LOVED-THE-BOOK-!<br /><br />It could be better? Yes, obviously anything can be better, but there isn’t such thing as perfection in this world, so why crying for the impossible and not enjoying what you really have at hand?<br /><br /><b>  <i>The truth is a beautiful and terrible thing, and should therefore be treated with great caution.</i></b><br /><br />You have a <i>Harry Potter</i> book in your hands! A new story! A canon tale! <br /><br />Don’t you get it?<br /><br /><b>You have magic in your hands!!!</b><br /><br />Enjoy it. Hug the book. Feel the dust jacket. Smell the pages. Read it without rush.<br /><br />Not every day you can read real magic translated into words.<br /><br /><br /><b>  <u>BACK TO THE MAGIC</u></b><br /><br /><b>  <i>They were great men, with huge flaws, and you know what – those flaws almost made them greater.</i></b><br /><br />The story is set nineteen years later of the end of the events in <i>Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</i>.<br /><br />Harry Potter is already an adult, married, with three children, and full of work in his position at the Ministry of Magic (No, I won’t tell which is, but it’s cool!!!).<br /><br />Hermione Granger is an adult too, married, with two kids, and with a position too in the Ministry of Magic (No, I won’t tell neither, but it’s cooooool!!!).<br /><br />And you will have the most of your favorite characters (minus Luna Lovegood, which sadly wasn’t used in the book) and it will be exciting to read about how their lives follow after the last time that you read about them, specially since the story is set so many years later.<br /><br />This isn’t only a new chapter in the wizarding world of <i>Harry Potter</i> but a closure, where we can feel the consequences of the events through the saga, how they impacted in the past, how they are driving the present, and how they can modeling the future.<br /><br />Albus Severus Snape, the youngest son of Harry Potter, isn’t having an easy childhood since there is the huge family legacy which is a too heavy burden for a young boy.<br /><br />Scorpius Malfoy, the only son of Draco Malfoy, isn’t having an easy childhood neither since his own kind of family legacy is still something that a kid shouldn’t suffer besides his own normal teenage troubles.<br /><br />An unexpected friendship will be forged.<br /><br />And as before, the power of friendship will be key to save the world.<br /><br />The Battle of Hogwarts was won by the heroes. Voldemort is dead. For nineteen years, peace has been enjoyed.<br /><br />However, there is still a powerful force of evil around, a new one but linked with the old dark magic, and with an ambitious agenda that can literally re-write everything that we already had for granted, rising a new dark age like any other before!<br /><br />You’ll have magical adventures, you’ll face exciting challenges, you’ll have priceless surprises.<br /><br />You’ll laugh. You’ll cry. You’ll live again the wizarding world of <i>Harry Potter</i>!!!<br /><br /><b>  <i>Those we love never truly leave us,… There are things that death cannot touch.</i></b><br /><br />The magical world of <i>Harry Potter</i> will never leave us, we’ll have it in our hearts forever.<br /><br />Thank you, J.K. Rowling...<br /><br />...thank you for sharing your magic with us.<br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="7040762897240194827" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1544008223">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1544008223" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1544008223u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1544008223'><a id="like_count_review_1544008223" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1544008223?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">187 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1544008223" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1544008223" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=187u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1544008223u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1544008223" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1544008223, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543978849" />    <a title="Kimi" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/17065991-kimi"><img alt="Kimi" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465941484p2/17065991.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543978849?book_show_action=false">Aug 12, 2016</a>      <a title="Kimi" class="user" name="Kimi" href="/user/show/17065991-kimi">Kimi</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/17065991-kimi?shelf=meh">meh</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/17065991-kimi?shelf=it-s-not-me-it-s-you">it-s-not-me-it-s-you</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/17065991-kimi?shelf=ya">ya</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543978849" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1071573923843737287">I don't really know how I feel about this book. I both loved it and hated it at the same time. It was absolutely amazing to be in the Harry potter world again, and I loved the story as well, but I just felt like it could have been done so much better. I wasn't a huge fan of the format at all. I would have preferred a novelized version but oh well. <br><br>I will write a more elaborate review once I get my feeling sorted. <br><br>Only one day left! <br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1469827219ra/19862739.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br></span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1543978849'><a id="like_count_review_1543978849" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1543978849?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">153 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1543978849" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1543978849" ref="like" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544202001" />    <a title="Amber Robertson" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30813900-amber-robertson"><img alt="Amber Robertson" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1479263956p2/30813900.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544202001?book_show_action=false">Sep 06, 2016</a>      <a title="Amber Robertson" class="user" name="Amber Robertson" href="/user/show/30813900-amber-robertson">Amber Robertson</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30813900-amber-robertson?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30813900-amber-robertson?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30813900-amber-robertson?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30813900-amber-robertson?shelf=urban-fantasy">urban-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30813900-amber-robertson?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30813900-amber-robertson?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544202001" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12860533044146792181"><blockquote> <i>"The truth is a beautiful and terrible thing, and should therefore be treated with great caution."</i> </blockquote><br /><br /><i>Harry Potter and The Cursed Child</i> was a book I've been looking forward to for months. My mum made jokes for the upcoming weeks of the release but I was seriously dedicated to getting my hands on this book. So much so my best friend Kyle (<i>shout out Kyle Green you're the real MVP</i>) took me to Big W at 8:30am this morning so we could wait for the doors to open. Thankfully, our town is kind of small so</span>  <span id="freeText12860533044146792181" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <i>"The truth is a beautiful and terrible thing, and should therefore be treated with great caution."</i></blockquote><br /><br /><i>Harry Potter and The Cursed Child</i> was a book I've been looking forward to for months. My mum made jokes for the upcoming weeks of the release but I was seriously dedicated to getting my hands on this book. So much so my best friend Kyle (<i>shout out Kyle Green you're the real MVP</i>) took me to Big W at 8:30am this morning so we could wait for the doors to open. Thankfully, our town is kind of small so despite there being a dozen or so people there wasn't a lot overall like there would be in a larger city. <br /><br />I saw spoilers for this book months ago and I was slightly disappointed by them. Thankfully, in the entirety of this book I <b>enjoyed</b> them. They were absolutely well done in the way that I couldn't put the book down for the three and a half hours it too me to read it. I'll do my best to mark spoilers, but it's quite difficult considering spoilers are what I love to do it seems. <br /><br />I loved reading about our next generation characters though I had some problems (hence a four star rating). I was frustrated that we didn't get to see more of Lily and James. They popped up in the beginning but basically disappeared once the storyline got intense. The same goes for Rose. I understand that Albus didn't like her but Scorpius did. Though, she didn't like Scorpius. I just wish she could have been included in their adventures a bit more, maybe making a trio among themselves. I also didn't like the fact Teddy didn't feature <b>at all</b>, and we didn't get to see Molly or Arthur or George or Charlie or Fleur or Percy or Bill or Victorie. I wish there was more to characters that I was thinking about at the end of <i>Deathly Hallows</i>.<br /><br />The script format of the book got a tad frustrating in some parts. I understand it's the special edition script and all of that, and I'm lucky to have read scripts before so I could follow it well, but at some parts I had to re-read sections in order to grasp the setting. <br /><br />In the beginning, it didn't feel much like JK Rowling to me either. To be fair though, I only read the Harry Potter books for the first time this year. <b>But</b>, I felt like the dialogue was forced in a way that made me uncomfortable to read interactions between Rose, Albus and Scorpius. <br /><br /><i>Characters</i> - <b>probably spoilers</b><br /><br />There were so many characters present in the book, so I'm going to try to focus on the primary three in order to keep this review an acceptable length. <br /><br /><b>Albus</b> was one of our three primary characters (along with Harry and Scorpius). He was frustrating. He made me want to punch him in the nose countless times. Albus just didn't feel like he belonged no matter the effort people put into trying to make him feel as if he did and as soon as he was sorted into Slytherin it was used as an excuse to basically be an asshole to his family. <br /><br />Sure, James and Lily teased him but that's what siblings do. They won't fall at your feet because Harry Potter is your father, because he's their father too. Despite the fact Albus <b>hated</b> how people only saw him for his father (it happened like twice his first year in the script and that was when he was sorted). <br /><br />I loved his character development though. Going from a sullen boy who hated everything to one who could now see the world with open eyes was great. I no longer wanted to punch him in between the eyes when the book was finished and that's some hardcore character development in my opinion. <br /><br /><b>Scorpius</b> was my favourite character by far. A character who had been plagued by rumours that he was actually Voldemort's son and not Draco's would have hurt, but this kid didn't let it get him down. He was smart, funny, and optimistic. The best friend to Albus as well. Scorpius, however, was a follower and no way a leader. I did get annoyed when he let Albus push him around or order him around. It made me want to punch him in between his eyes. <br /><br />Though, we do have Scorpius stand up for himself at the end of the book. Using his intelligence as well to save the day. He was the Hermione Granger of his duo (Albus being both Ron and Harry combined). <br /><br /><b>Harry</b> is now Minister of Law Enforcement, I can't remember the exact title don't shoot me, he is also nearing the ripe age of 40. I couldn't really connect with Harry in this book, he didn't seem to be trying a lot of the time to help Albus but decided to just blame himself and be done with it. In the book Harry compares himself to Dumbledore (in a negative way) and I couldn't have agreed more (I'm not a Dumbledore fan). <br /><br />Thankfully, character development exists and we have Harry working himself out to connect with his middle child - the one <i>"named after the two bravest men he knew"</i>. I don't really have much to say on Harry. He was more so a side character. Though, I enjoyed the fact through him we got to see Draco, Hermione, Ron, Ginny and Minerva. <br /><br /><i>World-Building</i><br /><br />The world-building wasn't exactly there. I presume the expectation to read this book is that you have read the first seven books in order to understand both jokes and the magic. Since it's a script it also lacks the detail that Rowling provided in the original series. <br /><br />However, knowing the world made this enticing. I loved how we got to see different places and travel back in time. It was still incredibly well done, but obviously not up to the standard I was expecting in a Rowling book. <br /><br /><i>Plot</i><br /><br />The plot was magnificent <i>in my opinion</i>. Sure, if you've read the spoilers, it doesn't seem that exciting. It seems a bit all over the place. It wasn't. It flowed perfectly for the most part (only confusing me a few times). I loved how the past and present intertwined and how mistakes were made that had to be rectified. <br /><br />I wasn't expecting the ending, <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[with Bellatrix and Voldemort's daughter. It definitely shocked me. I mean, I didn't trust Delphi but damn, I wasn't expecting that. I must have missed the spoiler <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> Oh, and <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Snape in the world where Voldemort was a ruler was actually a pretty good guy. I wasn't even mad and I'm definitely not a Snape fan. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> OH, OH <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[I'm also pissed we never got to see Neville. That's all I freaking wanted. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br /><i>Writing</i><br /><br />The writing was phenomenal. Despite the fact it was a script the dialogue was poetic and classic Rowling, with classic quotes from the original series and characters. There were also scenes from <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[The Goblet of Fire <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> which provided a sense of nostalgia. It was enticing in the way, as well, that it <i>was</i> a script, though it definitely made the book feel shorter than what it was. <br /><br /><i>Overall</i><br /><br />Overall, THIS BOOK IS LOVE. THIS BOOK IS LIFE. THIS BOOK IS A GIFT TO HUMAN KIND. THIS BOOK BROUGHT ME TO TEARS. THIS BOOK HAS LEFT ME ACHING FOR MORE.<br /><br />I desperately wish I could go to England to watch the play. It would be beautiful to see on stage. I also liked the fact I could imagine both the play cast <i>and</i> movie cast in this script. It did lack some of the personality of characters, like Harry, but it was still a spectacular read and dive back into the magical world. <br /><br /><b>EDIT 01/08/16</b>: I have to add in the fact that Scorpius telling Rose she smells like bread is my favourite scene in the script. Primarily becasue I love bread and those two are my new OTP.<br /><br /><b>EDIT 07/08/16</b>: I keep thinking about this book and my massive problem with it - The Trolley Lady. I felt that the random plotline of her being robot like or immortal was strange and completely unnesscary. It keeps bothering me, even days after I finished this book and I remembered I hadn't mentioned it in my review. </span>  <a data-text-id="12860533044146792181" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1715168922" />    <a title="Christy" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/11284813-christy"><img alt="Christy" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1415390359p2/11284813.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1715168922?book_show_action=false">Aug 08, 2016</a>      <a title="Christy" class="user" name="Christy" href="/user/show/11284813-christy">Christy</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11284813-christy?shelf=2016-ya-challenge">2016-ya-challenge</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1715168922" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11150419371974045440"><b>4 stars!</b> <br><br>So before I review this book, I have a confession to make. As much as I love Harry Potter (I have a dog named Dobby ffs) I’ve never read a Harry Potter book. I love the movies. I’ve seen them multiple times. Growing up, it was my sister’s favorite book series. It’s also my husband’s favorite book series. And one of these days, I’ll get to it… but I haven’t yet. Okay, so this is my first book I’ve read by JK Rowling. My husband pre-ordered and it was sitting on my kindle so I decided to</span>  <span id="freeText11150419371974045440" style="display:none"><b>4 stars!</b> <br><br>So before I review this book, I have a confession to make. As much as I love Harry Potter (I have a dog named Dobby ffs) I’ve never read a Harry Potter book. I love the movies. I’ve seen them multiple times. Growing up, it was my sister’s favorite book series. It’s also my husband’s favorite book series. And one of these days, I’ll get to it… but I haven’t yet. Okay, so this is my first book I’ve read by JK Rowling. My husband pre-ordered and it was sitting on my kindle so I decided to jump in. <br><br>I was pleasantly surprised with how much I enjoyed this book. The story is written in as a play- so the format is like a script. Which was fine by me, I was a thespian and have read many scripts, so it was easy to follow. I think it would be easy for anyone to follow, though. This book focuses on Harry Potter’s son, Albus Severus Potter. Albus is getting ready to go into his first year at Hogwarts and he is nervous. Which house will he be sorted into? Will he make friends? Being the son of Harry Potter isn't an easy thing for Albus. <br><br>There was a lot of action and twists and turns in this story, and I’ll keep that a surprise for readers, but what I really loved about this book was the friendship between Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy. Scorpius was by far my favorite character in this book. I adored him. <br><i>  <b>    <blockquote>“The world changes and we change with it. I am better off in this world. But the world is not better. And I don’t want that.”</blockquote>  </b></i>u2028I also really loved seeing our favorite characters grown up and parents. Harry, Ginny, Ron, Hermione, even Draco. I loved how much Draco loved his son. <br><br>I’ve seen a lot of fans of this book not love the script. And a lot of them are completely fan-girling over it. I liked it a lot. It wasn’t an epic 5 star read for me, but I thought it was good. Once I finally read the entire series, I’ll come back and re-read and see what I think. For now, I give it 4 stars because it was highly entertaining and I didn’t want to put it down.<br><br>(This is just a fun picture collage of my sister and me at the midnight release. That Patronus on the drink menu was delicious and there were tons of people dressed up! We had a blast :) )<br><br><a href="http://s1279.photobucket.com/user/Christyb23/media/Book%20Reviews%209/EAC0BEAE-9312-4A99-88BF-854AD3B3EE83_zpsrw7eo8ol.jpg.html" target="_blank" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470543683i/19939366._SY540_.jpg" alt=" photo EAC0BEAE-9312-4A99-88BF-854AD3B3EE83_zpsrw7eo8ol.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a></span>  <a data-text-id="11150419371974045440" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1715168922">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1715168922" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1715168922u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1715168922'><a id="like_count_review_1715168922" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1715168922?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">143 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1715168922" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1715168922" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=143u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=2u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1715168922u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1715168922" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1715168922, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">39 comments</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1715168922?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1715168922' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1715168922/comments?reverse=true">View all 39 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1715168922' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1715168922, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1706351021" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1706351021" />    <a title="Kristina Horner" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3070540-kristina-horner"><img alt="Kristina Horner" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1425746408p2/3070540.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1706351021?book_show_action=false">Jul 31, 2016</a>      <a title="Kristina Horner" class="user" name="Kristina Horner" href="/user/show/3070540-kristina-horner">Kristina Horner</a>          added it            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1706351021" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2844621945190235884">I literally don't know how to feel yet. Finished the book before noon on the 31st to avoid spoilers, and it was the weirdest, WEIRDEST reading experience of my life, for so many reasons.<br /><br />Taking time to process. More later. Can't give a star rating yet.</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1706351021">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1706351021" title="Flag this review as </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1720201588" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1720201588" />    <a title="Ryan " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/56788355-ryan"><img alt="Ryan " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1468129599p2/56788355.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1720201588?book_show_action=false">Oct 29, 2016</a>      <a title="Ryan " class="user" name="Ryan " href="/user/show/56788355-ryan">Ryan </a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56788355-ryan?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56788355-ryan?shelf=how-about-no">how-about-no</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56788355-ryan?shelf=not-my-cup-of-tea">not-my-cup-of-tea</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56788355-ryan?shelf=mixed-feelings">mixed-feelings</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56788355-ryan?shelf=2-star">2-star</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1720201588" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6159133977996543432"><b> <s>Post-review edit: I have decided to rate this three stars. I feel like it's a good middle-ground, and it matches my rating scale more or less. I still feel bad giving it less than four stars, but any rating higher than three would be dishonest on my part.</s> </b> <br><br><b>Post-post review edit: The more I think about this book, the more I want to rate it lower. So I did. (Please don't throw things at me.) And this review needed more gifs, so sorry, not sorry. <br><br>2/5 stars</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1460045606ra/18691389.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I never thought the day would come when I</span>  <span id="freeText6159133977996543432" style="display:none"><b>  <s>Post-review edit: I have decided to rate this three stars. I feel like it's a good middle-ground, and it matches my rating scale more or less. I still feel bad giving it less than four stars, but any rating higher than three would be dishonest on my part.</s></b> <br><br><b>Post-post review edit: The more I think about this book, the more I want to rate it lower. So I did. (Please don't throw things at me.) And this review needed more gifs, so sorry, not sorry. <br><br>2/5 stars</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1460045606ra/18691389.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I never thought the day would come when I would be disappointed by a Harry Potter book. <br><br>Harry Potter was the foundation of my childhood. I started reading this series when I was eight, and my obsession took off from there. I was Hermione Granger for Halloween when I was nine. I forced my mom to read the books. I regularly had Harry Potter movie marathons on the weekend. My best friend and I spent countless hours theorizing about it. I've re-read each book at least seven times. Even when I got older, and my tastes changed, I could still read Harry Potter and fall in love with the wizarding world all over again. <br><br>I don't know how I feel about Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. Did I have my issues? Hell yes. Did I feel an overwhelming sense of nostalgia despite everything? Also yes. <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1472693542ra/20227873.gif" width="400" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>One thing I could not <b>stand</b> about this book was the script format. I am not an actress. The only shows I've been in were mandatory school plays, so I am not familiar with reading scripts. Excuse me, but I wanted beautiful descriptions of Hogwarts, not choppy dialog that sounds like poorly written fanfiction.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1466045333ra/19431819.gif" width="400" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I did like things about this book - Scorpius Malfoy, seeing all of my favourite characters again, Scorpius Malfoy, being back at Hogwarts, Scorpius Malfoy - but besides that, and as much as it breaks my heart to say this, I didn't really enjoy the Cursed Child. Not like I enjoyed the other books. <br><br><s>I wanted to give this book 2 stars because of all the issues I had with it. But I also wanted to give it 4 stars because I feel terrible rating any Harry Potter book lower than that. I decided in the end that I wouldn't rate this book. I'd write my review, accept that it's a part of the Harry Potter universe, and leave it be.</s> As you can see from my two star rating, I got over that pretty quickly.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1431912714ra/14882087.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>A word of forewarning: I will be jumping into a full, spoilery, rant/discussion now.</b><br><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[This isn't so much a review as it is more of a (barely) legible list of my thoughts. <br><br><b>Things I did not like:<br><br>1) The characters did not seem like their characters.</b><br>What the hell was up with Harry during this? This was not the Harry Potter that I read about for so many years, this was someone else entirely. Though I don't exactly think he was a bad father (as he had pretty shitty role models for parenting) he still did not seem like himself. The entire time, I just wanted to scream at him. Harry, I love you, but what the fuck are you doing? Get your shit together.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1472780098ra/20272435.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>2) The plot was predictable.</b><br>I knew from the start, just from a gut feeling, that Albus would be sorted into Slytherin, and whoop dee do, look who was right? <br>I knew something was up with Delphi around the halfway mark - I trusted her for a bit, but after that, I knew she was our antagonist. I didn't think she was Voldemort's daughter, though, which leads me to my next point.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1431000854ra/14785973.gif" width="400" height="250" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>3) I do not believe for one goddamn second that Voldemort had a child.</b><br>I don't care if this is supposedly canon, I don't believe Voldemort would ever have a kid. Seriously, when they said Voldemort had a daughter, I burst out laughing, thinking, "Voldemort? A daughter? Sure. Who's the mother? Bellatrix Lestrange?" Now let me just say, I thought Bellatrix would be the mother <b>as a joke</b>. I knew she was infatuated with him, but I never thought she'd <b>actually have sex with the Dark Lord</b>. When Delphi said she was the daughter of Voldemort and Bellatrix Lestrange, I almost choked on my water. They should've written on the back of this book: <i>Warning: Do not consume food or beverages whilst reading this book. Choking on water due to the reveal that Bellatrix and Voldemort did the do may be potentially fatal.</i> <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1454283319ra/17940273.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>4) Scorpius and Albus didn't end up together.</b><br>Now, don't get me wrong, I'm normally fine with my ships not working out. In fact, I'm used to it. But when you throw around lines like "you need each other" or some shit, I'm probably going to board that ship and sail away while giving zero effs. And when you end the book without that ship reaching it's destination in the Land of Canon, I'm still going to cling on to that ship as it sinks to the bottom of the Sea of Broken Dreams. My hopes that Scorpius/Albus would work out is one of the only things that kept me going throughout this mess.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470444698ra/19929690.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>5) The use of time-turners in this book was atrocious.</b><br>Clearly, these characters do not know the <b>basic theories of time-travel.</b> I'm a huge sci-fi/science geek, and I think time-travel is one of the most interesting concepts it has to offer. Can I just start a petition to force the characters of the Cursed Child to watch Doctor Who so they'd know how unbelievably moronic they were? The mere idea that they could save Cedric was incredibly stupid! They should have at least <i>guessed</i> that going back in time and <b>changing a huge part of it</b> might permanently fuck up the future. <br><br>Come on, Albus:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1451162763ra/17512868.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Seriously though, shouldn't it just be common sense? <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470444698ra/19929691.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>6) Cedric the Death Eater</b><br>I'm sorry, but you're telling me that sweet Cedric, who was too pure and good for the wizarding world, <b>became a Death Eater?</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1448300909ra/17119875.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>7) There were some <i>serious</i> "what the actual fuck" moments in this.</b><br>The Trolley Witch. <b>The goddamn Trolley Witch</b>. What even was that scene? <br><br><b>Things I liked:<br><br>1) Scorpius Malfoy.</b><br>Scorpius Malfoy is a precious child that must be protected at all costs. That is all. (Well, seeing Snape and the rest of the cast was great, too, but <b>Scorpius Malfoy</b>.)<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1391913321ra/8474829.gif" width="400" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I am going to treat the Cursed Child like it's fanfiction, because as it turns out, <b>we didn't need an eighth Harry Potter book</b>. The way the series ended was perfect. It didn't need a spin-off. And it sure as hell didn't need this. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="6159133977996543432" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1720201588">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1720201588" likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1720201588" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1720201588" ref="like"
