</div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1578186880" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1578186880" />    <a title="Victoria Hansen" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/34354125-victoria-hansen"><img alt="Victoria Hansen" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1464332561p2/34354125.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1578186880?book_show_action=false">Aug 20, 2016</a>      <a title="Victoria Hansen" class="user" name="Victoria Hansen" href="/user/show/34354125-victoria-hansen">Victoria Hansen</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/34354125-victoria-hansen?shelf=2016">2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1578186880" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9070933087674727223"><b> <i>GINNY: “Harry, there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic. In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again. Be honest to those you love, show your pain. To suffer is as human as to breathe.”</i> </b><br /><br />On July 31, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, a new play based on a story by Rowling, Jack Thorne and John Tiffany premiered at the Palace Theatre in London’s Wes</span>  <span id="freeText9070933087674727223" style="display:none"><b>  <i>GINNY: “Harry, there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic. In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again. Be honest to those you love, show your pain. To suffer is as human as to breathe.”</i></b><br /><br />On July 31, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, a new play based on a story by Rowling, Jack Thorne and John Tiffany premiered at the Palace Theatre in London’s West End. The play, along with a book publication of its script, is the first significant addition to the Potter universe since the credits rolled on the second Deathly Hallows movie in 2011. Harry Potter stands peerless in the realm of literary hits, so Cursed Child was an assured commercial success even before it debuted. Written as a transcript, Cursed Child follows the next generation of wizards and witches.<br /><br />I found the latest installment of the Harry Potter series to be an enjoyable read in the sense that it allowed me to revisit old friends made many years ago (even if only for an afternoon). Harry Potter and the Cursed Child reignited that childlike imaginative spark in me, which is the reason I fell in love with the world of Hogwarts in the first place. Without going into too much detail, the play focuses on the difficulty Harry and Ginny's son, Albus Severus, has with being the underperforming child of the "the boy who lived". Albus struggles with living up to the reputation of the Potter name, and subsequently becomes a bit of a loner who does not hold the same esteem for Hogwarts as his parents would have hoped. The piece also speaks to the difficulty Harry has parenting a somewhat rebellious Albus, who is often viewed by others to be "different". When Albus befriends the child of a certain former Slytherin house member with whom Harry shared several altercations with during his time at Hogwarts, Harry is tasked with determining whether he should intervene to keep Albus out of trouble, or rather to put his preconceived notions of Malfoy's only son aside and allow Albus to continue to spend time with his one true friend. In addition, Harry must also make Albus understand the difference between seeking out trouble versus confronting it when it presents itself to you –a lesson Albus eventually learns throughout the course of the play.<br /><br /><b>  <i>SCORPIUS: No, it’s time that time-turning became a thing of the past.<br />ALBUS: You’re quite proud of that phrase, aren’t you?<br />SCORPIUS: Been working on it all day.</i></b><br /><br />While many readers have voiced their concerns over the writing style and how it pales in comparison to the original series, I would offer the following point. This work is written in such a style to facilitate live performances. As such, it seems unfair to compare the extent to which characters are developed and the overall plot complexity to J.K. Rowling's original series. The original seven were not bound by the added task of producing a narrative which can easily be digested in a spoken format (in addition to proving itself worthy of the original series as a standalone literary text). As I have always preferred dialogue over description, this writing form has been proven itself worthy due to its easy and fast nature to read. <br /><br />I truly don’t understand what's become of J.K. Rowling in recent years. She transformed the literary and cinematic realms with her Potter books, pioneering fantasy trends that continue to this day. I suppose she's trying to make stage plays more popular now? Not sure if that will take off, and it's kind of unfair for the many fans who can't afford to go see the play themselves. Those people are stuck with reading the script, which requires a lot more imagination to really enjoy. There's very little of Rowling's great descriptive prose on display, mostly just dialogue - and it's unclear how much of that was actually written word-for-word by her personally. It sounds like her style; I'll say that. But reading it definitely pales in comparison to reading an actual book. Frankly, I'm disappointed that Rowling hasn't taken the time to flesh this out into a novel. The same goes for the other Potter-related fiction she's written lately - the pre-Fantastic-Beasts pieces on Pottermore, to be precise. It's like reading pitches she hasn't bothered to turn into real books. Obviously, when you're as famous as Rowling, you can get away with posting your world-building notes online or having somebody else turn a story idea into a script and still have millions reading the stuff... but it smacks of laziness on her part, in my opinion.<br /><br /><b>  <i>DUMBLEDORE: Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic.</i></b><br /><br />If you came to this book hoping for a new era of Harry Potter, you're going to be disappointed. This book is an epilogue to the original series, not the start of a new one. There's nothing ground-breaking. The mythology is not expanded, and the new characters spend most of their time dealing with the legacies of the original cast. I'm gratified that the wizarding world will be built up by the Fantastic Beasts film(s), but there's a lot of untapped potential in the modern Potterverse that isn't even touched in "Cursed Child". There wasn’t enough of Hogwarts, unfortunately, and only focused on the magic outside the castle. I would have liked to see more of the home Harry Potter grew up in. <br /><br />What makes "Cursed Child" work despite all the strikes against it is what it does with the aftermath of the original stories. If "Deathly Hallows" had to have a follow-up in the first place, then this is a surprisingly good one. It's certainly an improvement on the frequently-criticized, rushed epilogue to "Hallows". This is basically an expansion of that last chapter, exploring what it's like for Albus Potter to grow up dealing with his famous dad's legacy, and it's very believable in that respect. True, Albus doesn't come across as likable until near the end of the book, and even Harry shows some striking flaws as a father, but given where both these characters are coming from, these problems make sense. It's not the forced "happily ever after" of the Hallows epilogue; it's complex and realistic. Additionally, there's a very sympathetic, funny character in play in the form of Scorpius Malfoy, Draco's son. He ends up stealing the show, and is arguably the hero of the story in his own right. His lines made me laugh out loud more than once, and convinced me that to whatever degree Rowling was involved in writing this story, she's clearly still "got it".<br /><br /><b>  <i>ALBUS: "So what would you like me to do? Magic myself popular? Conjure myself into a new house? Transfigure myself into a better student? Just cast a spell, Dad, and change me into what you want me to be, okay? It'll work better for both of us."</i></b><br /><br />Scorpius was great addition into the story. His friendship/relationship with Albus was pure, and I appreciate the attention provided towards the importance of friendship. I definitely understand why people would like to see them together as the dialogue and quick descriptions indicate a relationship, which ultimately seems to be more than friendship. Draco and Harry talking, and viewing each other as friends made me feel emotional; it took them more than twenty years, but it was worth it. I still don’t understand the story surrounding Draco and his wife, Astoria. It doesn’t make sense, and seems like bullshit the writers created to expand the plot/story. <br /><br />Parts of the story itself felt a little overdone and rushed, but you must keep in mind that this addition is originally intended to be watched, not read, with delivery fitting under a specific window of time. For this, I know I did not experience the full breath and absorption of Cursed Child during my read-through, and I am sure live-performance characteristics such as dialectic nuances and set transformations would definitely expand this work even more, but just reading the play itself took me back into this world of magic, mishap, and mischievousness that Potterheads are long-time familiar with. I am curious how the experience of watching it live differs, and cannot wait to see it when I have the chance.<br /><br /><b>  <i>DUMBLEDORE: "Harry, there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic. In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again. Be honest to those you love, show your pain. To suffer is as human as to breathe."</i></b><br /><br />The Trolley Witch part made me feel uneasy. It was irrelevant towards the plot, and made me cringe while reading it. I’ve come to a conclusion, in which I cannot consider these events cannon. As much as I enjoy certain twists and additions into the story, much of it doesn’t fit with the original Harry Potter books or does not seem to work. It felt as if the plot read like fan fiction, with its revisiting of the original novels’ plot points, its cameos of beloved characters, and its too-satisfying outcomes; Hermione, for instance, is Minister for Magic and Ginny is the sports editor for the Daily Prophet. Ron seems completely out of character, and revealed he was drunk at his wedding; there was a desperate attempt of humor with his character, which didn’t seem like the original Ron. <br /><br />Voldenmort having a child completely turned me off. He has been hinted to have a relationship with Bellatrix throughout the books, but them having an actual affair and child doesn’t seem to fit. How could Bellatrix be pregnant during the Wizarding War? There was no explanation for this, only the child was born during this time. Of course, their child would want to avenge them, and bring Voldemort back. Another villain would have improved Harry Potter and the Cursed Child as Voldemort’s daughter didn’t do the book any justice. I will not accept that Voldemort had a child with Bellatrix. I can’t, and I won’t. <br /><br /><b>  <i>HARRY: "I shouldn't have survived — it was my destiny to die — even Dumbledore thought so — and yet I lived. I beat Voldemort. All these people — all these people — my parents, Fred, the Fallen Fifty — and it's me that gets to live? How is that? All this damage — and it's my fault."</i></b><br /><br />It's a shame because there's a lot of possibility here. There are interesting storylines taking place here, they just aren't executed on the level we've come to expect from a Rowling product. I enjoy reading time travelling stories, as well as revisiting beloved characters much later in life, but this isn't how these characters act. Albus should never have been this whiny. I liked him in the seventh book. I liked Harry in the original 7. But, here, the characters have become annoying or flat. Additionally, I wasn't a fan of how entwined in the story Harry was. I've already witnessed him and everything he's capable of in the original seven books. Now, he's a blubbering fool. You can't sit there and tell me that Harry Potter, the boy who lived, is going to run to Ginny every time he has a minor problem, and he is not allowed to eat sugar.<br /><br />Having said that, as a reader, you have time to appreciate on the page how nimbly Thorne’s writing navigates the adventure’s death-defying twists and turns, and his stage directions have a poetry of their own, a style that in its lyricism and sense of the abstract is distinct from Rowling’s more direct, story-driven prose.For example, when Albus arrives at Hogwarts and is sorted into his school house, we are told: “There’s a silence. A perfect, profound silence. One that sits low, twists a bit and has damage within it.”  When the children travel in time, Thorne’s stage direction notes how: “time stops. And then it turns over, thinks a bit, and begins spooling backwards…” <br /><br /><b>  <i>DRACO: "... And being alone — that's so hard. I was alone. And it sent me to a truly dark place. For a long time. Tom Riddle was also a lonely child. You may not understand that, Harry, but I do ..."</i></b><br /><br />As a story containing many possible alternate realities, with a text created to varying degrees by three collaborators, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a complement to Rowling’s original series rather than a straightforward continuation. It won’t satisfy all fans: some have already taken issue with the story’s extensive reliance on time travel, the use of which seems to disagree with the magical precedent set in the books. Others have quibbled with the portrayal of Harry’s character: he comes across as pricklier and even more troubled than he was in Rowling’s books.  And though the release is eagerly anticipated by adult fans who grew up with the books, it remains to be seen whether children will connect with reading a complex story in a less familiar script form.<br /><br />The emotional climax is devastating even on paper. Once again, the fantasy world that Rowling created nearly 20 years ago is at its most powerful when it sets aside magic and reveals the basic, brutal and human mechanics of love and grief. The characters are, mostly, exactly as you remember them, and it’s difficult to overstate how exciting it is to read a new story set in this widely loved fantasy universe. The thrill of a new Harry Potter book, even in script form, is its own kind of magic spell.<br /><br /><b>  <i>HARRY: "You know what? I'm done being made responsible for your unhappiness. At least you've got a dad. Because I didn't, okay?"</i></b><br /><br />Nonetheless, there is still plenty in this new release to tempt fans, for familiarities abound and the magic is intact, if fleeting. Details are minimal for settings, as can be expected given the format, but it works, as there was an assumption that anyone reading the book knows the world inside and out and can paint the pictures in the mind. In fact, fans will find much that is recognizable in the new story, in spite of the altered vessel of delivery. It is worth noting that there is no effort made by either Rowling or Thorne to acquaint a Harry Potter newcomer to the world, so it is advised for those not familiar with the original series to read the books in sequence. From the opening lines — once the reader adjusts to the pace and syntax of the script format — a comforting feeling descends, for the world seems just as it was left when the last pages of Book 7 were reluctantly closed.<br /><br />Rowling never misses a chance to raise a moral conundrum, and characters are always deeper than two-dimensional, even in script from. Albus Potter, bearing the unwelcome burden of being the son of the most famous wizard to live, is faced with having to navigate Hogwarts with the same lack of anonymity as his father did. The first person young Albus encounters on the train is Scorpius Malfoy, the son of Harry’s nemesis, Draco Malfoy. Young Rose Weasley, daughter of Hermione and Ron, heads off to make other friends, but Albus stays, and in typical Rowling fashion, he befriends the last person that his father would expect him to. These sorts of moral twists are some of the reasons Rowling’s books resonate so deeply, as they appeal to our better natures.<br /><br /><b>  <i>HARRY [quoting Dumbledore]: “The truth is a beautiful and terrible thing, and should therefore be treated with great caution.”</i></b><br /><br />The twists and turns continue, and preconceptions and expectations are turned on their heads, as though Rowling is reminding the reader that change is good and an open mind should always be the goal. Not only are the characters’ prejudices challenged, but so, too, are those of the reader, and once again Rowling takes a fantasy and elevates it with characters that are distinct, flawed and endearing. There will be plenty who denounce Rowling for reopening Harry Potter’s world, but for those for whom the loves run deep, treasures await.<br /><br />If it all sounds confusing, it is, as there were several hands involved in the creation of the first of two installments that are set 19 years after Harry Potter left Hogwarts and defeated the Dark Lord Voldemort. Rowling hinted at this glimpse of Harry’s future in the epilogue of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,” and some of that much-analyzed final chapter is overlapped nearly verbatim in the play’s script; indeed, it serves as a jumping-off point for a new and wondrous adventure for Harry, his cohorts and the next generation of wizarding offspring. For true Potter fans, this might be enough to be pulled back into the story. That said, the very nature of the play format of “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” allows for very little detail, which is where Rowling’s real storytelling gifts reside. Her ability to build fully developed characters is unsurpassed and is what comprises the center of the allure of the Harry Potter series.<br /><br /><b>  <i>DRACO: Hermione Granger, I’m being bossed around by Hermione Granger. And I’m mildly enjoying it.</i></b><br /><br />Lastly, Draco and Hermione have been shipped together since the books first came out, and there is a moment dedicated to them. I've never understood the obsessiveness of their relationship, and it disgusts me; it's like shipping a white man who is a racist with black woman. It doesn't make sense. He might have changed his attitude towards muggle born people, his prejudice will never completely disappear. This line, I must admit, made me smile a bit as I realized it will make the majority of Draco and Hermione shippers happy. Yes, I felt happy for them, as pathetic as it makes me sound.<br /><br />The story, once you get past the awkward format, is gripping. I devoured it in one afternoon. There are quite a few surprises in store for hardcore fans. On the whole, the tone is very appropriate for those who have "grown up" along with Harry. Fans who are now adults can relate with the themes explored here, even when characters mess up pretty badly. Harry certainly made plenty of his own mistakes over the years, and occasionally acted like a jerk. I'd argue that it's worth giving Harry's progeny a chance, even if you don't take to him at first. At the very least, read it for Scorpius. I'm not saying you definitely won't be disappointed, but there are far worse ways for a Potter fan to bide the time until Fantastic Beasts gives us a weightier addition to the Potter universe.<br /><br /><b>  <i>DRACO: Keep up, old man.<br />HARRY: We’re the same age, Draco.<br />DRACO: I wear it better.</i></b></span>  <a data-text-id="9070933087674727223" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1578186880">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1578186880" title="Flag this review as </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1717758739" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1717758739" />    <a title="Ilenia Zodiaco" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/18922532-ilenia-zodiaco"><img alt="Ilenia Zodiaco" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1464943334p2/18922532.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1717758739?book_show_action=false">Aug 03, 2016</a>      <a title="Ilenia Zodiaco" class="user" name="Ilenia Zodiaco" href="/user/show/18922532-ilenia-zodiaco">Ilenia Zodiaco</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18922532-ilenia-zodiaco?shelf=la-vita-troppo-breve">la-vita-troppo-breve</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18922532-ilenia-zodiaco?shelf=lingua-originale">lingua-originale</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1717758739" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8655599461744479250"> No. Questa è la premessa, lo svolgimento e la conclusione. No.<br />Innanzi tutto, cerchiamo di stimare quest’iniziativa per quello che è: un modo per accaparrarsi altri quattrini. Non è un’evoluzione spontanea della storia né un omaggio finale ai fan né una folgorante ed innovativa idee che ha fulminato la Rowling sulla via di Damasco. Cosa mi spinge a dirlo? È probabile che il mio giudizio sia stato influenzato dalla totale mancanza d’ispirazione nella composizione della storia, le poche idee confu</span>  <span id="freeText8655599461744479250" style="display:none"> No. Questa è la premessa, lo svolgimento e la conclusione. No.<br />Innanzi tutto, cerchiamo di stimare quest’iniziativa per quello che è: un modo per accaparrarsi altri quattrini. Non è un’evoluzione spontanea della storia né un omaggio finale ai fan né una folgorante ed innovativa idee che ha fulminato la Rowling sulla via di Damasco. Cosa mi spinge a dirlo? È probabile che il mio giudizio sia stato influenzato dalla totale mancanza d’ispirazione nella composizione della storia, le poche idee confuse e imprecise del suo svolgimento e infine dalla scrittura banale, trita e piena di indulgenti spiegoni con cui ci è stata consegnata. All’inizio "the cursed child" si limita ad essere uno specchio della vecchia saga, un’immagine rovesciata degli stessi stratagemmi narrativi e degli stessi personaggi (hanno pure gli stessi nomi!). Il protagonista è l’anti Harry Potter, il figlio Albus. Lui verrà smistato a Serpeverde, non saprà giocare a Quidditch, si farà amico un Malfoy (che infatti, per rovesciamento, qui è identico a Ron Weasley). La sensazione è quella di assistere ad un riciclaggio di temi e motivi a noi già noti, in modo da non doverci concentrare troppo sulle cose davvero importanti come le motivazioni profonde dei personaggi, ad esempio. La velocità assurda degli eventi ce lo impedisce. Sono curiosa. Per caso c’era un elenco di elementi da dover assolutamente riproporre per ammiccare ai vecchi, mansueti fan? M’immagino già uno stralcio della lista degli sceneggiatori:<br />Pozione polisucco. Fatto.<br />Algabranchia. Fatto.<br />Tranello del diavolo (o una cosa del genere). Fatto.<br />Duello Harry/Draco like it’s 1997 all over again. Fatto.<br />Giratempo. Fatto.<br />Ah, e non fatemi iniziare con i viaggi nel tempo. Risibili. Ogni volta che questi due scimuniti si avventurano nel passato combinano un guaio più grande del precedente. Davvero, dategli una medaglia. Troppo fieno in testa ai due bovidi. Continua qui: <a target="_blank" href="http://conamoreesquallore.blogspot.it/2016/08/harry-potter-and-cursed-child-no.html" rel="nofollow">http://conamoreesquallore.blogspot.it...</a><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="8655599461744479250" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1544015835" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544015835" />    <a title="Warda" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30036082-warda"><img alt="Warda" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1466551078p2/30036082.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544015835?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Warda" class="user" name="Warda" href="/user/show/30036082-warda">Warda</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544015835" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5059579657286012615">So, I would like for Scorpius to be my child, please. Thanks. <br /><br />Honestly, I don't get the issue people have with this book. Yes, it's different. Yes, it's not a necessarily a full continuation of the story we all came to know and love, even though it's advertised as the 8th HP story (false advertisement!!). The characters don't necessarily feel the same. It couldn't, though. Even though the familiarity was there in my opinion, first off, it's not written by J.K. Rowling. She's endorsing it though,</span>  <span id="freeText5059579657286012615" style="display:none">So, I would like for Scorpius to be my child, please. Thanks. <br /><br />Honestly, I don't get the issue people have with this book. Yes, it's different. Yes, it's not a necessarily a full continuation of the story we all came to know and love, even though it's advertised as the 8th HP story (false advertisement!!). The characters don't necessarily feel the same. It couldn't, though. Even though the familiarity was there in my opinion, first off, it's not written by J.K. Rowling. She's endorsing it though, which is more than enough for me, to be honest.<br /><br />Second, there's a 19 year difference since the original story ended. It's supposed to feel different.<br /><br />Third, it's a play. It's a flippin' script. It reads like a damn script. I don't get the fan-fiction correlation. It was never advertised or was ever going to read anything remotely close to the original story or like a full-fledged novel. Which script has good writing or feels like a fulfilling story? That's what the play is there for. <br /><br />Plus I highly doubt Rowling would allow for it to be absolutely butchered. Whether that's in the sense of the plot or the characters. <br /><br />I don't know what I was expecting going into this. I was terrified though, for sure, because the reviews were quite mixed, bordering more on the negative side. Thus, I expected nothing. Which helped. Massively. It helped me separate the original story from this script and I enjoyed it immensely. I enjoyed it for what it was. It was experimental and the dialogue was a lot of fun, though some parts of the story felt slightly far-fetched. It didn't bother me though. The nostalgia was more than satisfying and more than enough. It was nice to get a brief glimpse again into the lives of those characters who meant so much to us growing up.</span>  <a data-text-id="5059579657286012615" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1544015835"> </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1543914335" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543914335" />    <a title="Dannii Elle" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/44487975-dannii-elle"><img alt="Dannii Elle" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1435955929p2/44487975.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543914335?book_show_action=false">Aug 02, 2016</a>      <a title="Dannii Elle" class="user" name="Dannii Elle" href="/user/show/44487975-dannii-elle">Dannii Elle</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44487975-dannii-elle?shelf=fantastic-fabrications">fantastic-fabrications</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44487975-dannii-elle?shelf=historical-highness">historical-highness</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44487975-dannii-elle?shelf=spelling-bee-challenge">spelling-bee-challenge</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543914335" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3080497886980718053">Disclaimer: this book could be one paragraph long and I would STILL give this five stars.<br /><br />This has given me all of the feels and I have been transported in time back to my eleven-year-old self with this new installment in the Harry Potter series!<br /><br />I was a little hesitant going in to this, due to the format of the text being set in play form. I had previously only read Shakespeare in this way and wasn't sure how my beloved fandom would translate from the expected novel format. A few pages in and I c</span>  <span id="freeText3080497886980718053" style="display:none">Disclaimer: this book could be one paragraph long and I would STILL give this five stars.<br /><br />This has given me all of the feels and I have been transported in time back to my eleven-year-old self with this new installment in the Harry Potter series!<br /><br />I was a little hesitant going in to this, due to the format of the text being set in play form. I had previously only read Shakespeare in this way and wasn't sure how my beloved fandom would translate from the expected novel format. A few pages in and I completely forgot that this was written in any alternate way! The story was, of course, dialogue heavy and yet I still managed to bring the magical world to life in my imagination, and the plot felt as fully-formed as any of the previous novels.<br /><br />I know this has received some mixed opinions due to this being partially fan-fic, but as someone who has never read or written any, this delivered the shock-factor on so many fronts! I had stayed away from any news concerning anything to do with the play or this book and so my reading journey remained spoiler-free and my experience unmarred. <br /><br />There were so many additions to this to delight the true Potter fan. Foremost, the inclusion of many characters from the initial cast was something I had not anticipated, and the fact that they played such primary roles, even less so. Many lines from the play were also seized directly from the original series and given new contexts, which had me reading open-mouthed at the brilliance and care taken in writing this.<br /><br />This was such a poignant read as my beloved childhood reads were once again brought back to life and I will never not give anything Harry Potter related five-stars!<br /><br />I feel it is only appropriate to finish this review with one line: After all this time... Always!</span>  <a data-text-id="3080497886980718053" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1543914335">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1543914335" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1543914335u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1543914335'><a id="like_count_review_1543914335" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1543914335?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">89 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1543914335" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1543914335" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=89u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1543914335u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1543914335" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1543914335, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); I'm still not sure what to rate it. A huge part of me really loved revisiting my old friends and watching their children have adventures but it wasn't the same. I'm aware that is wasn't supposed to be the same but some characters felt off and the plot moved to fast and all over the place and some characters I really wanted to see more of.<br /> I think anything that has Harry Potter in it I'll love because it is my childhood. I've happy to have read this.<br />I will be fil</span>  <span id="freeText13950017655074080501" style="display:none">I'm leaving this unrated for now. I'm still not sure what to rate it. A huge part of me really loved revisiting my old friends and watching their children have adventures but it wasn't the same. I'm aware that is wasn't supposed to be the same but some characters felt off and the plot moved to fast and all over the place and some characters I really wanted to see more of.<br /> I think anything that has Harry Potter in it I'll love because it is my childhood. elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1543947298" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543947298" />    <a title="Cameron" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/40648249-cameron"><img alt="Cameron" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1474594382p2/40648249.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543947298?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Cameron" class="user" name="Cameron" href="/user/show/40648249-cameron">Cameron</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40648249-cameron?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40648249-cameron?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40648249-cameron?shelf=middle-grade">middle-grade</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40648249-cameron?shelf=series">series</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543947298" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer290396261874074632">Okay, folks! It finally came and went. It was the moment we Potterheads were looking forward to, one and all. And now that most of us have read <i>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</i> in its entirety, I'm sad that this epic story has ended once again... at least until the <i>Fantastic Beasts</i> movie and script come out this Fall. Not to mention the eventual movie release of <i>Cursed Child</i>. We all know it's going to happen, not that I'm complaining. But still, saying goodbye to Harry, if only for a while, is</span>  <span id="freeText290396261874074632" style="display:none">Okay, folks! It finally came and went. It was the moment we Potterheads were looking forward to, one and all. And now that most of us have read <i>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</i> in its entirety, I'm sad that this epic story has ended once again... at least until the <i>Fantastic Beasts</i> movie and script come out this Fall. Not to mention the eventual movie release of <i>Cursed Child</i>. We all know it's going to happen, not that I'm complaining. But still, saying goodbye to Harry, if only for a while, is always hard. On a positive note though, I'm pleased to say <i>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</i> was not a disappointment. What a relief!<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470345672ra/19917898.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Just holding this book in my hand was like riding the Hogwarts Express back to my childhood, a time when I eagerly waited in line to buy the next book in the series. Sure, the cover for <i>Cursed Child</i> isn't quite the same as the original books, but it had the same feeling in my hands which was a nice dose of nostalgia in itself. Regardless of the fact that this is a script, it still reads very much like the series I know and love. It flows wonderfully and I was able to finish in one day without ever getting bored.<br><br>Now for all the things I loved about <i>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</i>:<br>1. First and foremost, THE FREAKING TROLLEY WITCH!!!<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470340078i/19917045.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470340078i/19917046.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470340078i/19917047.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1444831466ra/16560362.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br>2. Scorpius Malfoy... I actually liked that kid. Like, more than I liked Albus Potter. Scorpius Malfoy is a sweet character... I know, right?<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470345672ra/19917899.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>3. Minerva McGonagall. This is no different than always. But seeing her in Headmaster mode is the best, basically.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1408966391ra/10915836.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>4. Just all the returning characters altogether.<br><br>5. The budding friendship between Harry and Malfoy.<br><br>6. Harry Potter as a dad. Is he a good dad? Not usually. Is he a jerk at times? Oh, yeah. Harry has unflinchingly faced terrifying situations in the past, but when it comes to being a parent he is absolutely terrified. It's a flaw he has to learn to get past which adds a new layer onto his character that we've never seen before, for better or for worse.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470345672ra/19917900.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>7. And just countless other things!!!<br><br>I know a lot of people were let down by this script, but I'm giving it my Potterhead stamp of approval.<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1392295286ra/8533998.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="290396261874074632" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1543947298">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1543947298" class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1543947298'><a id="like_count_review_1543947298" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1543947298?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">78 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1543947298" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1543947298" ref="like" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=78u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1543947298u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1543947298' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1542395236" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1542395236" />    <a title="Liza" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/50370792-liza"><img alt="Liza" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1468187304p2/50370792.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1542395236?book_show_action=false">Aug 12, 2016</a>      <a title="Liza" class="user" name="Liza" href="/user/show/50370792-liza">Liza</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50370792-liza?shelf=own">own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1542395236" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9247466134372746983">"To suffer is as human as to breathe." <br /><br />After having a few days to gather my thoughts about this play, I lowered my initial rating from 5 stars to 4 stars. As we all should be aware, even though most don't understand, this is NOT another Harry Potter book. This is a screenplay of the play "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" that is being performed in London. Many people have had issues with being unable to connect with characters, saying that it reads like fanfiction, and that it is a disappointm</span>  <span id="freeText9247466134372746983" style="display:none">"To suffer is as human as to breathe." <br /><br />After having a few days to gather my thoughts about this play, I lowered my initial rating from 5 stars to 4 stars. As we all should be aware, even though most don't understand, this is NOT another Harry Potter book. This is a screenplay of the play "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" that is being performed in London. Many people have had issues with being unable to connect with characters, saying that it reads like fanfiction, and that it is a disappointment. This is because it is meant to be seen, not read. It is a visual experience, and this is what makes it different. It is hard to connect with characters and settings if there are no descriptions and further discussions about what is happening. I personally thought that this was an amazing addition to the already phenomenal series, as that is what it is meant to be. This brought back the excitement and joy of receiving and reading a Harry Potter book for the first time, and that in itself was irreplaceable.<br /><br />I loved seeing all of the new characters, as well as reconnecting with the old. This was not an adventure with Harry, Ron, and Hermione, this was about their children. While this book mainly focused on Albus and Scorpius, I loved the additional scenes with the original group. Since I am a diehard Draco Malfoy fan, there is no surprise that I was absolutely enthralled by his son, even though he was COMPLETELY different than his father. Scorpius was such an interesting character, and I do wish that there was another book to develop him further. He did not lack depth, nor was he boring to read about, and it made me extremely happy to see Draco's son as one of the main characters. I loved how logical and decisive he was, and how he was truly awkward and lacked the confidence of his father. He is such a raw character that I would love to learn even more about. Albus was also interesting to read about but sometimes his stupidity would frustrate me to no extent. He was cocky, manipulative, and disrespectful throughout a majority of the play, and was not really fleshed out (which is understandable as it was a PLAY). It almost seems like the writer switched the personalities of Harry and Draco and made them a bit different. Regardless, I do think that he grew as a character and understood the consequences of his actions later on. <br /><br />I loved how the topic of acceptance and the feeling of being disconnected were so deeply discussed. Everyone goes through these struggles and deals with hardships, and they made that very clear. Just because Albus was the son of Harry does not mean that life would be magical and perfect for him forever. Just because Scorpius was the son of Draco does not mean that evil will cross his path and he will be entitled and lack sensitivity. Harry and Draco explicitly discuss their mistakes and their frustrations which made them seem more real and more human than their sons thought they were. Their sons take some of their best qualities and become people of their own, which is very refreshing to read about.<br /><br />Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed my read of this play and do recommend it to Harry Potter fans. This brought back so much happiness for me, and had great connections to the previous books. I do caution readers who expect a new Harry Potter book to put aside such thoughts and read this for what it is: an amazing addition to the world, but a visual play that is meant to be seen. 4 out of 5 stars! </span>  <a data-text-id="9247466134372746983" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1542395236">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1542395236" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1542395236u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1542395236'><a id="like_count_review_1542395236" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1542395236?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">77 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1542395236" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1542395236" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=77u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1542395236u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1542395236" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1542395236, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">comment</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1542395236?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1542395236' style='display: none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1542395236' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1542395236, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1714215725" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1714215725" />    <a title="Emily" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2431873-emily"><img alt="Emily" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477433724p2/2431873.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1714215725?book_show_action=false">Jul 30, 2016</a>      <a title="Emily" class="user" name="Emily" href="/user/show/2431873-emily">Emily</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1714215725" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4507245428238299598">I saw Harry Potter and the Cursed Child in London in July. The staging, the effects, and the actors were absolutely fabulous. Seeing Jamie Parker on stage is amazing. He IS Harry in a three-piece suit, and I love him for it.<br /><br />However, this story is an absolute mess. It contradicts canon in multiple places. It feels like the clumsiest sort of fan service: let's do <i>this</i> because we know readers like this character, not because it serves the plot! <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Let's make this story a new one about H</span></span>  <span id="freeText4507245428238299598" style="display:none">I saw Harry Potter and the Cursed Child in London in July. The staging, the effects, and the actors were absolutely fabulous. Seeing Jamie Parker on stage is amazing. He IS Harry in a three-piece suit, and I love him for it. <br /><br />However, this story is an absolute mess. It contradicts canon in multiple places. It feels like the clumsiest sort of fan service: let's do <i>this</i> because we know readers like this character, not because it serves the plot! <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Let's make this story a new one about Harry as a dad - but let's spend the entire play focusing on the events of books 1-7 instead. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> It was really crazy. After the first night, my friends and I spent a couple hours talking out our feelings. "Can it bounce back? Is there a way for it to ... fix itself?" The answer is no. This is a terrible story foisted on an excellent cast. <br /><br />The line that best sums up the play for me is this: <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Harry takes Albus to Cedric's grave and mentions that he goes there every year on his death. <br /><br />HARRY: He could have been anything. He could have been an Auror. He could have played Quidditch for England. He could have been anything.<br /><br />Yes! That's true. He could have been ANY OF THE TWO WIZARDING CAREERS WE KNEW ABOUT IN 2008.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>This line made me actually laugh out loud in the theater. This play was supposed to expand the Harry Potter universe. Instead it contracted it. If they had nothing to say about Harry and real-life struggles <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[instead of blah blah Voldemort is back <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>, why even bother?<br /><br />I am 1000% disappointed and hope that JK has plausible deniability. </span>  <a data-text-id="4507245428238299598" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1714215725">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1714215725" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1714215725u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1714215725'><a id="like_count_review_1714215725" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1714215725?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">79 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1714215725" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1714215725" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=79u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1714215725u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1714215725" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1714215725, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); Sure, I want to read it but there are other books I long more to read. <br><br>Me:<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1416823267ra/12076152.gif" width="400" height="" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1544157787">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1544157787" title="Flag this review as </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1723610890" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1723610890" />    <a title="helen the bookowl" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/21992464-helen-the-bookowl"><img alt="helen the bookowl" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477245060p2/21992464.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1723610890?book_show_action=false">Aug 10, 2016</a>      <a title="helen the bookowl" class="user" name="helen the bookowl" href="/user/show/21992464-helen-the-bookowl">helen the bookowl</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1723610890" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8757748687902456490">First of all, let me just say that I'm convinced the show for this screen play is going to be absolutely magnificent! At several points, I could imagine what it would look like on stage, and I had goosebumps all over my body. <br />Let me also say that I went into reading this play knowing that it was going to be different in many ways: Different format (which, by the way, I loved - it reminded me of reading Harold Pinter), the writing, the story - so I went into it having no expectations whatsoever.</span>  <span id="freeText8757748687902456490" style="display:none">First of all, let me just say that I'm convinced the show for this screen play is going to be absolutely magnificent! At several points, I could imagine what it would look like on stage, and I had goosebumps all over my body. <br />Let me also say that I went into reading this play knowing that it was going to be different in many ways: Different format (which, by the way, I loved - it reminded me of reading Harold Pinter), the writing, the story - so I went into it having no expectations whatsoever. <br />All of that being said, I still do think that it's a shame what this story has turned into. I could sense from beginning to end that this wasn't written by J. K. Rowling, and it disappointed me a lot to find so many faults with it. <br />The biggest fault, I find, is the fact that the main decision of this play (a decision made by one of the main characters, and a decision which the rest of the play is based on), DOES NOT MAKE SENSE!!! There is no reasoning whatsoever behind this decision, and I did not believe it to be credible. It felt like the decision was made only to move the plot forward which I'm never a big fan of, and obviously that affects the rest of the play and taints the story, and I didn't like it. <br />Another thing that I wasn't absolutely crazy with were the characters who didn't seem well-developed in my eyes. These characters were obviously made for theatre, but once again they didn't seem credible to me, and therefore they were disappointing. Things were turned upside down, and the characters we know and love from the original story behave weirdly. <br />Last but not least, having now finished this play I can't help but wonder: What was the purpose? We got a story that took place nineteen years later and that we could've easily lived without. I didn't feel like anything new was added to this world and these characters, and that must be one of the biggest disappointment of all. <br />So, all in all, while I did love how this must be playing out on stage, I don't think this story is a natural and necessary continuation of the original one.</span>  <a data-text-id="8757748687902456490" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1723610890">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1723610890" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1723610890u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1723610890'><a id="like_count_review_1723610890" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1723610890?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">76 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1723610890" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1723610890" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=76u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1723610890u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1723610890" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1723610890, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">5 comments</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1723610890?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1723610890' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1723610890/comments?reverse=true">View all 5 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div><div id="comment_155420159" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="helen the bookowl" href="/user/show/21992464-helen-the-bookowl"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477245060p1/21992464.jpg" alt="21992464" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/21992464-helen-the-bookowl">helen the bookowl</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer17187268578159660987">Jeg er frisk, Rikke - over en god kop kaffe :-D</span>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Aug 11, 2016 07:59AM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_155460787" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Kim Dyer" href="/user/show/9018798-kim-dyer"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1335308938p1/9018798.jpg" alt="9018798" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/9018798-kim-dyer">Kim Dyer</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer6488502643981676371">I felt the exact same way! I agree it is undoubtedly an excellent play but I</span>  <span id="freeText6488502643981676371" style="display:none">I felt the exact same way! class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1714475654" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1714475654" />    <a title="Taylor Knight" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/12627819-taylor-knight"><img alt="Taylor Knight" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1458860014p2/12627819.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1714475654?book_show_action=false">Aug 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Taylor Knight" class="user" name="Taylor Knight" href="/user/show/12627819-taylor-knight">Taylor Knight</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1714475654" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6611056599745553006"><b>Spoiler free</b><br />Never in my life would I have thought that I would rate this book anything less than 5 stars. I never thought that I wouldn't love it and I planned on spending a month rereading it over and over. It never crossed my mind that this book would less than perfect. However, I'm torn between giving this book 2 or 3 stars. <br /><br />I'm a massive Harry Potter fan. I can't even explain how much I love the books and movies and how much they mean to me. So it physically pains me that I didn't like Harry</span>  <span id="freeText6611056599745553006" style="display:none"><b>Spoiler free</b><br />Never in my life would I have thought that I would rate this book anything less than 5 stars. I never thought that I wouldn't love it and I planned on spending a month rereading it over and over. It never crossed my mind that this book would less than perfect. However, I'm torn between giving this book 2 or 3 stars. <br /><br />I'm a massive Harry Potter fan. I can't even explain how much I love the books and movies and how much they mean to me. So it physically pains me that I didn't like Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. It started off amazing. I loved every single word and I even shed a few tears. However, as it went on and the plot started to develop, I started to dislike it. By the end of the book, I wished I hadn't even read it. I didn't mind that it was in script format. I've seen a few people saying that the format bothered them but I really didn't mind at all. The plot, however, was like reading something from a group of drunk people that decided to co-write the most insane HP fanfic the world has ever seen. None of it seemed canon at all. Everything was so crazy and bizarre and so implausible. <br />And the characters! This book took my favorite characters and turned them into people that I couldn't even recognize. The only one that stayed true was Ron (and he was the best part of this entire mess of a play/book). Yes, I know that this takes place 19 years after Deathly Hallows and it's to be expected that the characters would change in 19 years. But this was more than character development. They took away most of the best qualities from the characters and turned them into unlikable strangers. <br /><br />Overall, I'm heartbroken after reading this book. I was so excited about it and it was, to be completely honest, trash. I almost wish that I never read it. I cannot and will not accept any of this as canon. I don't know how much input J.K had in this but I pray that she didn't think up any of this insanity. </span>  <a data-text-id="6611056599745553006" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1714475654">  <td
