href="/review/show/1714257292?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1714257292' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1714257292/comments?reverse=true">View all 56 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1714257292' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1714257292, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1545046407" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1545046407" />    <a title="Vaneesha" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/23273360-vaneesha"><img alt="Vaneesha" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467667934p2/23273360.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1545046407?book_show_action=false">Aug 02, 2016</a>      <a title="Vaneesha" class="user" name="Vaneesha" href="/user/show/23273360-vaneesha">Vaneesha</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1545046407" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17953714328730538843">It breaks my heart a little to not rate a Harry Potter related book 5-stars, but I can't bring myself to give this 5-stars. In fact, if I'm being entirely honest, this is closer to a 2-star book than a 3-star, like a 2.44-star book, but we'll round up because this series means so much to me - I'd be perfectly content with reading 300-pages of Hermione's lecture notes on Professor Binns discussing self-stirring cauldrons. <br /><br />This was without a doubt my most anticipated read of 2016. There has been a</span>  <span id="freeText17953714328730538843" style="display:none">It breaks my heart a little to not rate a Harry Potter related book 5-stars, but I can't bring myself to give this 5-stars. In fact, if I'm being entirely honest, this is closer to a 2-star book than a 3-star, like a 2.44-star book, but we'll round up because this series means so much to me - I'd be perfectly content with reading 300-pages of Hermione's lecture notes on Professor Binns discussing self-stirring cauldrons. <br /><br />This was without a doubt my most anticipated read of 2016. There has been a void in my life with the absence of new Harry Potter books. So perhaps I built up my expectations of the book too much? That is very much my own fault. I did not finish reading filled with a bitter feeling of disappointment, nor did I finish reading filled with a radiant feeling of immense satisfaction. In fact, I finished reading feeling somewhat indifferent. Have I outgrown this series? HECK NO. But I was never even remotely impressed with the Nineteen Years Later chapter - I found it corny, I like to pretend it doesn't exist. I had hoped that this book would redeem that chapter, and in that aspect, The Cursed Child was most definitely successful.<br /><br />If you have not yet read the book and you intend to do so, PLEASE do not read the rest of this review! I do not want to spoil anything for you!<br /><blockquote> ************************************** </blockquote><br /><br />The Cursed Child is a screenplay, it is a script, not a novel. The stage directions, accompanied with my imagination, made reading this quite easy. I had no difficulty <i>getting into the story</i>. <br /><br />The story itself follows Albus Severus through his first few years at Hogwarts at a fast-pace. Albus does not feel he fits in with his family, his relationship with his father in particular is tumultuous. Albus’ best friend is Scorpius, the child of Draco Malfoy. At Hogwarts, the two are bullied and teased relentlessly. For Albus and Scorpius, Hogwarts is not home. When Amos Diggory shows up at the Potter house, Albus overhears a conversation between Amos and Harry, where Amos appeals to Harry to use a Time Turner salvaged from the Department of Mysteries to go back in time to save Cedric Diggory. Harry denies. Albus overhears and decides to take matters into his own hands, and is aided by Delphi Diggory, Amos’ niece. <br /><br /><b>I do not like time travel</b>. I’m not sure if I think it’s stupid, or I’m just too stupid to be able to wrap my head around the logistics. I think it has more to do with the notion of revisiting the past more than once. I find that whole concept tired and repetitive and I just <b>do not like it</b>. I was ok with the Time Turner use in Prisoner of Azkaban, and I think that was because they just went back once. It didn’t feel tedious. However, I think bringing back a storyline motivated by Time Turner use, is a regurgitation, I felt like it was a cop out. Don't get me wrong, I liked how it took us back to be able to see the Triwizard Tournament, and even Godric's Hollow, and Hagrid (OH HAGRID), and these sort of alternate-universes. But it also felt a little too much like <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/10016013.Harry_Potter_and_the_Methods_of_Rationality" title="Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality by Eliezer Yudkowsky">Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality</a>, which is fan fiction. I have nothing against fan fiction, but I was looking forward to <i>original</i> Harry Potter. I’m aware a lot changes in 19 years (it’s actually closer to 22 years because of how fast-paced the timeline is), regardless, this story did not feel <i>completely</i> like Harry Potter. To an extent, this is perfectly ok, because this is about the younger generation living in a post-Voldemort era. However, I did not particularly enjoy the focus on the younger generation. Albus is Harry and Ginny’s son so I obviously <i>care</i> about him, but the scenes with snippets of older-Harry and the palpable <i>guilt</i> that haunts him, were my favourite parts of the story.<br /><br />My problem with the Deathly Hallows’ Nineteen Years Later chapter was that everything was wrapped up so conveniently, as though everything was suddenly hunky-dory in the wizarding world now that old Voldy had been off’ed. Although The Cursed Child didn’t address the bigger world issues of classism (/blood-status-ism/house-ism ??) and speciesism, I wholeheartedly appreciate the way it approached Harry’s guilt. <br /><blockquote> HARRY: I shouldn’t have survived — it was my destiny to die — even Dumbledore thought so — and yet I lived. I beat Voldemort. All these people — all these people — my parents, Fred, the Fallen Fifty — and it’s me that gets to live? How is that? All this damage — and it’s my fault. </blockquote><br /><br />I liked that we were able to see Harry’s struggle with being a father, largely due to his limited familial relationships. We bear witness to the aftermath of his relationship with Dumbledore, and the impact that had upon him. The scene with Harry revisiting his past with Dumbledore’s portrait brought tears to my eyes. <br /><blockquote>“DUMBLEDORE: No. I was protecting you. I did not want to hurt you . . .<br /><i>DUMBLEDORE attempts to reach out of the portrait — but he can’t. He begins to cry but tries to hide it.</i><br />But I had to meet you in the end . . . eleven years old, and you were so brave. So good. You walked uncomplainingly along the path that had been laid at your feet. Of course I loved you . . . and I knew that it would happen all over again . . . that where I loved, I would cause irreparable damage. I am no fit person to love . . . I have never loved without causing harm.”</blockquote><br />Despite how immensely satisfying this was, I wanted <i>more</i>. I wanted to see:<br /><br />- If <b>Arthur</b> was any closer to understanding batteries, <br />- How <b>Molly</b> was as an overbearing, well-meaning grandmother,<br />- <b>Bill</b> and <b>Fleur</b> handling full-moons,<br />- <b>Percy</b> working under Hermione at the Ministry (??),<br />- <b>GEORGE</b>, my baby George, unable to cope with the loss of his brother; distanced from the smiling, laughing, prankster we love,<br />- <b>Hagrid</b> and <b>Grawp</b> and <b>Olympe</b> working as giant-activists, not for the purpose of trying to gain allies, but to help better their ways of life,<br />- <b>Luna</b> being Luna proving the existence of Crumple-Horned Snorkack's and starting a conservatory for them in Sweden,<br />- <b>Neville</b> with his grandmother who has grown so so so proud of her only grandson, and Neville with his parents, Neville teaching his students about <i>Mimbulus Mimbletonia</i> smiling to himself as he remembers dousing everyone in Stinksap in their Hogwarts Express compartment,<br />- <b>Parvati Patil</b> who still meets with Sybil Trelawney for tea every few months and afterwards they both cry as they remember their best friend and favourite student who they were unable to save during the Battle of Hogwarts, <br />- <b>Teddy Lupin</b> growing up without his parents, but with a loving grandmother and loving godparents and cousin, who feels like he has no right to be sad, but he thinks about the persecution his father faced for being a werewolf, and the persecution his mother faced for simply <i>falling in love</i> and he can’t help but feel sad, and all the werewolves are underground and they don’t lead normal lives, and <i>that could have been him</i> but he was lucky but he doesn’t feel lucky … <br />- <b>Kreacher</b> who still works in the Hogwarts kitchens who sometimes cleans the Slytherin dorms (even though House Elves are no longer supposed to clean up after humans, the humans are supposed to clean up after themselves) and sometimes sees Albus and Scorpius who have fallen asleep over stacks of Potions homework in the common room so he props pillows under their heads as Regulus’ locket slips out from the top of his tea cozy and lightly grazes Scorpius’ head. <br />- <b>Sirius Black</b>’s name cleared, reform in the Ministry legislature that works to prevent unjust incarceration, a bill passed in his name to appeal sentences and provides fair trials for people accused of committing crimes, the House of Black used as a group home, it's a sanctuary, it's a place of safety, for children/youth who have no families, it's more than an orphanage, it's a place of opportunity. <br /><br />I think you get the point. I wanted <i>more</i>. I do understand that since this is a play, having such a large cast to incorporate these characters and their lives post-Voldemort, would be especially challenging. I really don't care about the execution challenges, it doesn’t stop me from wishing. <br /><br />Very briefly I want to talk about Albus. I’m disappointed in his character; the pressure he feels associated with his family name is completely understandable. What I don’t understand and what I simply CANNOT believe is that his family, siblings, cousins - the Potters' entire NETWORK of people wouldn’t do everything possible to protect Albus. This is a different generation, yes, but Albus' siblings and cousins have parental figures in Ron, Hermione, Harry, and Ginny. You cannot possibly expect me to believe that Albus would not have cousins or siblings who would defend his ass from the petty likes of Polly Chapman? You can’t possibly expect me to believe that JAMES SIRIUS POTTER would stand by as his BROTHER was relentlessly bullied, and CALLED A SQUIB? I don’t buy it. You can't possibly expect me to believe that ROSE GRANGER-WEASLEY would be a bratty, narcisstic schoolgirl who wouldn't defend her cousin? Perhaps this is my fault for having such unwavering faith in the trio. I can't believe for one second that they wouldn't have raised their children to always look out for one another. This could be me holding them to too high of a standard, I understand parenting is hard work. But then again, you can’t possibly expect me to believe that PROFESSOR LONGBOTTOM would even tolerate such behaviour. NEVILLE, who was relentlessly bullied by both his peers and staff would NEVER allow his own students to torment one another. Even Headmistress McGonagall? Bullying tolerated under her authority? You can't even try convincing me that the bullying of Albus (and Scorpius) wouldn't even be on her radar, she has more important things to worry about as Headmistress? Nope. No there is NO fucking way. Not McGonagall. <br /><br />Please don’t get me started on the absurdity that is Bellatrix Lestrange hooking up with Voldemort. (<a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1528812137?comment=154950187#comment_154950187">Caidyn's Review</a> goes into fantastic detail about why this seems implausible). But I just can’t even go into detail with that nonsense, it'll get me too wound up I will probably end up stabbing myself with shards of my tangible disappointment. </span>  <a data-text-id="17953714328730538843" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1545046407">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1545046407" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1545046407u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1545046407'><a id="like_count_review_1545046407" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1545046407?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">91 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1545046407" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1545046407" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=91u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1545046407u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1545046407" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1545046407, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">35 comments</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1545046407?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1545046407' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1545046407/comments?reverse=true">View all 35 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1545046407' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1545046407, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1545288488" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1545288488" />    <a title="Sean Gibson" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/20955173-sean-gibson"><img alt="Sean Gibson" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1416866667p2/20955173.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1545288488?book_show_action=false">Sep 14, 2016</a>      <a title="Sean Gibson" class="user" name="Sean Gibson" href="/user/show/20955173-sean-gibson">Sean Gibson</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1545288488" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16750241731578322746">Reading a play is a little bit like watching someone eat ice cream. Sure, you get a feel for what it’s like, but you don’t get to savor the sweet, creamy texture on your tongue, the cold seeping through your fingers, the pleasantly sated feeling in your stomach, the…okay, maybe that’s a bad comparison, because only masochists watch someone eating ice cream without getting some themselves.<br /><br />How, then, to evaluate the script of a play as it relates to seven now-legendary, nigh-mythical novels? Is it</span>  <span id="freeText16750241731578322746" style="display:none">Reading a play is a little bit like watching someone eat ice cream. Sure, you get a feel for what it’s like, but you don’t get to savor the sweet, creamy texture on your tongue, the cold seeping through your fingers, the pleasantly sated feeling in your stomach, the…okay, maybe that’s a bad comparison, because only masochists watch someone eating ice cream without getting some themselves.<br /><br />How, then, to evaluate the script of a play as it relates to seven now-legendary, nigh-mythical novels? Is it fair to compare the feel of how a car drives to a van? Or a yak to an aardvark? I mean, apples and oranges, right? You might like both, or dislike both, but, they’re different. <br /><br />With that in mind, I’m not entirely sure how to rate The Cursed Child. Lines of dialogue that fell flat on the page might have popped on stage when delivered by a charismatic performer. Scenery and special effects might have added color and tension to a confrontation that seemed a bit tame. Two actors emoting for all their hearts are worth might imbue simple lines with the emotion that transcends what’s written on the page. <br /><br />In other words, as a performance vehicle, The Cursed Child might be stellar. As a pure reading experience, it’s…well, it’s no apple. Or novel, for that matter.<br /><br />So, I’m left to evaluate it solely for the content of its story, rather than quality of its language or descriptions, realizing that the story was very deliberately framed for staging. And, as a story in the HP canon…well, it’s no apple. <br /><br />There’s some delight to be derived from checking in with old, dear friends some years after we last saw them, especially since they’re fictional characters, which means they’re not stricken with the issues that plague, say, a reunion show for a beloved sitcom, where the ravages of time and the fickle finger of (mis)fortune is apparent on the faces (and bodies) of at least some of the stars, unless they are John Stamos, in which case they appear as they always have, with the possible exception that, if possible, their hair looks even better (if I had Stamos’s hair, I’m convinced that I could be elected Supreme Emperor of Earth; it’s that good). Ron Weasley in particular seems to be in this frame of mind, dropping in for some one-dimensional one-liner comic relief here and there, the beloved yet befuddled uncle who’s never quite sure what’s going on around him. <br /><br />The overall tenor and tone, however, is far more serious, and I’m grappling with mixed emotions on that front. <br /><br />On the one hand, one thing I (and millions of other people) loved so much about the HP books is that they made for the perfect escape from the mundane—even when they got dark, you were magically transported to another world, one where magic ruled, where Quidditch was a thing, and where butterbeer could be consumed in mass quantities. <br /><br />On the other…<br /><br />I didn’t grow up with Harry and friends—I was 22 when I discovered the series (which was right around when Goblet of Fire came out, I think), and I was well into my dotage (read: my later twenties) when subsequent volumes arrived, so I didn’t experience the trials and tribulations of adolescence alongside the characters (I did that in the sanctity of my room all by myself, albeit with the help of Tecmo Bowl, the X-Men, and pictures of Kathy Ireland). Still, I was close enough to the age group that did go through that experience to see how easy it would have been to feel like Harry, Hermione, and Ron were akin to real, live, in-the-flesh friends. And, for those people—many of whom are now, themselves, raising children, albeit perhaps slightly younger than Albus and Scorpius—I would imagine there are powerful emotions involved in seeing those friends confronting the same challenges that being a parent entails. And there’s something in seeing fictional characters to whom you’re so attached that, in an odd way, validates and informs your own life experience as much as seeing a close friend go through it might (or even, perhaps, experiencing it yourself).<br /><br />This is a phenomenon unique to addicted readers with avid imaginations, but the power of JK Rowling’s drug is such that she created a generation of junkies who will, I suspect, either fiercely embrace or strongly reject the experience of seeing Harry Potter, boy wizard, the one who defeated He Who Must Not Be Named, struggling to connect with his son in the most mundane ways.<br /><br />Parents were, as often as not, defined as much by their absence as their presence in the HP books (notwithstanding the Weasleys, who, as with Ron in The Cursed Child, resembled nothing so much as the sprawling family from an 80s sitcom family—think the Cosbys or the Seavers with wands), and to have Harry, as a parent, be so simultaneously present and absent is a conundrum. It makes sense, of course, that the boy who grew up without parents, whose father figure was simultaneously his hero and a man he could never fully trust, would struggle as a father himself; but seeing that play out on the page is heartbreaking. <br /><br />Fiction can, and often does, reflect the most real and painful parts of life back at us, and when we seek it out for that purpose, it can be a fulfilling and validating experience in a way few others can. When we seek escapism and magic and adventure, however, and are faced with the overwhelming reality of emotional turmoil…well, it’s disconcerting.<br /><br />Putting aside the staging aspects and judging this solely on the merits of the words printed on the page, as a rip-roaring HP yarn, this is somewhere in 2.5-star territory. As an exploration of how difficult it is to raise a child, no matter how good you might be at the rest of the game of life, and how emotionally eviscerating failing to connect with a tiny human that you made can be, we’ll put in 3.5-star territory.<br /><br />I will, undoubtedly, reread the 7 core HP novels many times in my life (as I already have). Will I reread The Cursed Child? Probably not.<br /><br />Unless, that is, I’m reading it with my kids, in order to stay connected with them and attuned to what they’re feeling and experiencing as they grow and change—something Harry would, by play’s end, appreciate, I think.</span>  <a data-text-id="16750241731578322746" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1545288488">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1545288488" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1545288488u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1545288488'><a id="like_count_review_1545288488" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1545288488?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">103 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1545288488" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1545288488" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1544076083" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544076083" />    <a title="Giulia " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/48295288-giulia"><img alt="Giulia " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1445896778p2/48295288.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544076083?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Giulia " class="user" name="Giulia " href="/user/show/48295288-giulia">Giulia </a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/48295288-giulia?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/48295288-giulia?shelf=english-and-american-lit-and-more">english-and-american-lit-and-more</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/48295288-giulia?shelf=plays">plays</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/48295288-giulia?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/48295288-giulia?shelf=magic-and-supernatural">magic-and-supernatural</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/48295288-giulia?shelf=disappointing">disappointing</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544076083" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3453852198920519442">Before you decide to read <i>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</i>, there are a few things you should know - the first one being, <b>J.K. Rowling did not write this play.</b> The production credits at the end of the book clearly state: <i>ORIGINAL STORY, by J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany, Jack Thorne, and PLAYWRIGHT, by Jack Thorne.</i> But, even though Jo did not actually write this, I am still baffled that she actually approved it and thought that Harry Potter fans were going to enjoy it. Because, despite some new int</span>  <span id="freeText3453852198920519442" style="display:none">Before you decide to read <i>Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</i>, there are a few things you should know - the first one being, <b>J.K. Rowling did not write this play.</b> The production credits at the end of the book clearly state: <i>ORIGINAL STORY, by J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany, Jack Thorne, and PLAYWRIGHT, by Jack Thorne.</i> But, even though Jo did not actually write this, I am still baffled that she actually approved it and thought that Harry Potter fans were going to enjoy it. Because, despite some new interesting characters, this story was <u>a mess.</u> It felt like fanfiction, and not a particularly good one at that, and - as many other people have decided to do - I think I'm just going to pretend that none of this was canon, and simply ignore what I just read. To me, Harry's story ended within the last page of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. <br /><br /><br /><u>  <b>The rest of the review contains spoilers for the original series and mild spoilers for Harry Potter and the Cursed Child</b></u><br /><br /><br />Now, let's analyse the play together, since I am still pretty confused by a lot of things.<br /><br />• Harry's children. And no, I'm not talking about Albus, who will get a paragraph of his own, but about James and Lily. Sorry, what did you say? You found two personalities lying on the floor? Well, they must be theirs then, since they had <b>none.</b> What is even the purpose of James, besides annoying Albus all the time and being a clone of young James Potter Senior? <br /><br />• Albus Severus Potter. I just, I DON'T KNOW. Did I like him? I think I mostly liked the <i>concept</i> of him, the idea that he had been <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[sorted into Slytherin <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> and that he was so much different from both his siblings and his parents. To Albus, Hogwarts wasn't the amazing place of friendship and adventure that it had been to his father. It was just school. There was homework to do, and there were bullies, and gossip, and rumors. And, constantly behind him, his father's shadow. I mean, I still think Albus seriously needs to get over himself, because he has the worst case of daddy issues I've ever witnessed, but that's somehow understandable. And he was still the only likable Potter in the whole play...<br /><br />• Harry. I mean, what? Seriously. WHAT? Disclaimer: adult Harry Potter is an asshole. I wasn't n. 1 Harry Stan in the original series either, but here he's just... oblivious, insensitive, horribly self-centered. Childish. Albus is a teenager, a <i>child</i>, but Harry seems to completely fail to understand this. He's overbearing, doesn't get his son at all, and just wants him to be a copy of himself, or - even worse - to "be more like James and Lily." He doesn't see him. And the end of the play doesn't change my opinion on this matter: Harry does not know his son. <br /><br />• Scorpius My Actual Son Malfoy. I'm sure we can all agree that he needs to be protected at all costs. All right, he's the least Malfoy person on earth, but he's still pretty adorable and dorky. I mean, who would've expected Draco's son to be a cute nerd? Well, not me, that's for sure. Still, even though I really liked Scorpius, his characterization is <i>not canon for me.</i> That's not <b>my</b> Scorpius Malfoy. I've always had a fascination with the more grey characters in the Harry Potter series, like Draco, and I like to think that Scorpius has some of that darkness in him, some of that selfishness, and ambition, but also the same fierce loyalty that Draco showed to his family during the war. To me, "Malfoy" and "cute" don't belong in the same sentence but, after all, Scorpius is still the reason why this play got an extra star. <br /><br />• Ron and Hermione. Again, what the hell? I know that, even in the original series, Ron represents the comic relief. However, that doesn't necessarily make him an <b>utter moron.</b> He was absolutely incompetent, and his complete inability to do <i>anything at all</i> besides making inappropriate jokes seemed to also have the purpose to make Hermione look more wonderful in comparison. However, this Hermione was... not Hermione at all. I only saw a glimpse of her in her interactions with Harry, but for the rest of the time, she was just a character with her name and a completely different personality. <br /><br />• Draco. MY BEAUTIFUL DRACO. Yes, I am one of those people, and I absolutely <i>adore</i> Draco Malfoy. Here we saw a softer version of him, a different version, but honestly - who cares. I just needed to see more of him. *blows kisses* *swoons*<br /><br />• I don't want to talk about the plot. It's fucking <b>embarrassing</b> how bad it is. Sometimes I even found the plot in the original series too convoluted and unrealistic, but this time it was just plainly nonsensical. Albus' reasons for doing things made no sense to me. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[And really, Voldemort has an <i>evil daughter</i>? What is even the point of that? And why does being Voldemort's child necessarily make her evil? She didn't grow up with her parents. She could've been a totally different person, <i>her own</i> person, but she was a cardboard villain instead, with ridiculous motives. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />• The thing I liked the most, besides my beloved Malfoys, was <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[the alternate universe in which Scorpius Malfoy was the Scorpion King. I know, everything was dark and bloody and twisted, but it was also a thousand times more interesting than the rest of the play. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br /><br /><br />I am done talking about this mess of a play, I really am. Can I unread it, please? Let's just pretend it never existed. I need to reread the original series and marathon all eight movies in order to recover from this.<br /><br />PS: I can't believe I've never asked, <b>but what Hogwarts House were you people sorted into?</b> I am, predictably enough, a Slytherin - and proud to be one. </span>  <a data-text-id="3453852198920519442" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> href="/user/show/46088881-reading-corner"><img alt="Reading Corner" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1440473163p2/46088881.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1545153002?book_show_action=false">Aug 31, 2016</a>      <a title="Reading Corner" class="user" p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(u0026#39;reviewTextContainer1545153002u0026#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer1545153002" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17672834678357074041"><b>3.5 stars</b> <br /><br />I'm still not really sure how to rate this one and to be honest I think it should have never been released as it slightly undermines the series.I think the play will be amazing and they should have stuck to only releasing a play.<br /><br />I did enjoy the story,mainly due to Scorpius Malfoy.I absolutely loved his character because he was just such a lil cutie and I loved the friendship between him and Albus.I also thought Draco Malfoy was written really well and loved how much he cares about his</span>  <span id="freeText17672834678357074041" style="display:none"><b>3.5 stars</b> <br /><br />I'm still not really sure how to rate this one and to be honest I think it should have never been released as it slightly undermines the series.I think the play will be amazing and they should have stuck to only releasing a play.<br /><br />I did enjoy the story,mainly due to Scorpius Malfoy.I absolutely loved his character because he was just such a lil cutie and I loved the friendship between him and Albus.I also thought Draco Malfoy was written really well and loved how much he cares about his son and appreciates his wife.I liked Ginny's character as well especially because it was obvious how much she loves her kids.<br /><br />However, everything felt a little too convenient <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[like how everything was so easily resolved and the whole mess with the time turner.Also, the whole concept of Voldemort having a daughter seemed a little silly. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>The famous trio felt so out of character especially Harry,he was just such a dick to his child,Albus and I nearly had to keep reminding myself this was the same boy from the other 7 books.Hermione was just cold and Ron's character was completely dumbed down to this silly joker who never took anything serious and was only there to laugh at.<br /><br />I did love the view into the trio's children but I would have loved if they showed some more of the other children like James or Rose.<a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[The end with Scorpius asking Rose out was adorable although I would have preferred Albus and Scorpius together, especially because it seemed like they were hinting at it. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />Overall I did enjoy the story as it's a simple plot and Scorpius is a great character but the famous trio were very out of character in my opinion.</span>  <a data-text-id="17672834678357074041" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1543928836" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543928836" />    <a title="Ashley" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3764614-ashley"><img alt="Ashley" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1445131964p2/3764614.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543928836?book_show_action=false">Aug 18, 2016</a>      <a title="Ashley" class="user" name="Ashley" href="/user/show/3764614-ashley">Ashley</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3764614-ashley?shelf=owned">owned</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543928836" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17335867863659950995">There are zero spoilers in the review below, but for the sake of nitpickers everywhere, I'll keep the review spoiler tagged for a while.<br />**Dropped this to two stars. The more I think about it the more bothered I get.**<br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Ok. Here's the deal. I liked it. My expectations for this were very, very low and because of that I ended up not being horrendously disappointed. Being a script, I anticipated the fact that there was no possible way this story could blow me away. There was definitely</span></span>  <span id="freeText17335867863659950995" style="display:none">There are zero spoilers in the review below, but for the sake of nitpickers everywhere, I'll keep the review spoiler tagged for a while.<br />**Dropped this to two stars. The more I think about it the more bothered I get.**<br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Ok. Here's the deal. I liked it. My expectations for this were very, very low and because of that I ended up not being horrendously disappointed. Being a script, I anticipated the fact that there was no possible way this story could blow me away. There was definitely a feeling of "is this cheesy fanfic" at points that perhaps would not be as obvious if you were actually seeing the play. <br /><br />The only reason this even remotely worked as a script book is because we are already familiar with the world of Harry Potter. You can get away with bare bones and dialog because the images of these places and characters are already in your mind. I'm a bit torn on how to rate this because of the nature of the format, so I'm going to go with a middle of the road 3 stars. I enjoyed it, would have rather consumed it the way it was intended (play form) but I'm glad I got to experience it at all. <br /> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span></span>  <a data-text-id="17335867863659950995" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1643203273" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1643203273" />    <a title="Aya Hamza" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/11660871-aya-hamza"><img alt="Aya Hamza" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467501189p2/11660871.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1643203273?book_show_action=false">Aug 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Aya Hamza" class="user" name="Aya Hamza" href="/user/show/11660871-aya-hamza">Aya Hamza</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11660871-aya-hamza?shelf=fiction">fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11660871-aya-hamza?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11660871-aya-hamza?shelf=middle-grade">middle-grade</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1643203273" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1632984551095287811">I can't decide if it is <b>3 or 3.5 stars</b>. I am disappointed and angry!<br>Well, I wanted to re-read the whole series then pick this up but <b>I couldn't stop thinking about it!!</b> <br>And I felt so nervous now because I have seen mixed ratings and reviews for it.<br><br>So, yeah, <b>WELCOME BACK HARRY!</b><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899608._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b> <u>What I was excited to read in the book:</u> </b><br>1) <b>Albus and Harry's relationship.</b> I wanted to read about the kind parent Harry is supposed to be.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899609.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>2) <b>Hermoine</b> and her way in thinking and making great decisions, and <b>Ron</b> the funny bu</span>  <span id="freeText1632984551095287811" style="display:none">I can't decide if it is <b>3 or 3.5 stars</b>. I am disappointed and angry!<br>Well, I wanted to re-read the whole series then pick this up but <b>I couldn't stop thinking about it!!</b> <br>And I felt so nervous now because I have seen mixed ratings and reviews for it.<br><br>So, yeah, <b>WELCOME BACK HARRY!</b><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899608._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>  <u>What I was excited to read in the book:</u></b><br>1) <b>Albus and Harry's relationship.</b> I wanted to read about the kind parent Harry is supposed to be.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899609.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>2) <b>Hermoine</b> and her way in thinking and making great decisions, and <b>Ron</b> the funny but dependable friend.<br><br>3) <b>The Malfoys</b> because Draco is one of my favorite characters in HP books after Snape and Harry -of course-.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899610.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>4) I wish the three kids were going to be <b>friends</b>! <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899611._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470237217i/19905230._SX540_.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>  <u>Writing-style:</u></b><br>I think this is the most disappointing part for me. <b>I didn't feel Rowling's touch in the book this time!</b> So, I feel she isn't the main writer for the book although her name took the biggest attention on the cover. <br><br><b>  <u>Plot:</u></b><br>I won't talk much about it because it will spoil most of the book, but here we follow the main HP characters' children, Albus Potter, Rose Weasley and scorpius Malfoy. I liked the plot twists and it brought so many memories from the older books.<br>But I expected <b>more explanations</b>. A lot of magic that happened was so unclear to me! <br>Repeating the same scenes every time they <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[traveled in time <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> was unnecessary to be written in the same way. I know this is a play but as a written book it is just so annoying.<br><br><b>  <u>Characters</u></b><br>1) <b>The Malfoys</b>, both Draco and Scorpius, were the best! Draco was an awesome father and I liked his friendship with Albus so much. The Malfoys never disappoint me! :)<br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[and I am so happy Snape is back again! ❤️ <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br> 2) I loved Scorpius so much more than Albus. I don't know how to describe Albus, but he made me feel confused!<br><br>3) <b>This can't be Harry!!! He is the worst father!</b> He just kept hurting people and that's not what I expected from Harry at all! I wanted to read about the <b>brave kind Harry</b>.<br><blockquote>  <b>    <i>“Albus: No! I just wished you weren't my dad.<br>Harry (seeing red): Well, there are times I wish you weren't my son.”</i>  </b></blockquote> <blockquote>  <b>    <i>“Harry: Albus didn't like me before. He might not like me again. But he will be safe. With the greatest respect, Minerva -you don't have children-.<br>Ginny: Harry!<br>Harry: -you don't understand.”</i>  </b></blockquote><br>This is not Harry, I swear.<br>But unlike harry, <b>Ginny</b> was amazing.<br><br>4) <b>Ron</b> here seems so silly, he just keeps telling jokes! But from other HP books he is a mix of a funny and a so dependable guy. That's how I feel about Ron from books or movies.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470237217i/19905230._SX540_.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>- <i>Now I believe it must be seen as a play!</i><br>And I really wanted to have any chance to watch this as a play, it has to be so much fun than reading a play script.<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470194563i/19899612._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I don't want to read any other new HP books! I don't want to hate all the characters I used to love for a long time. <br>I am sorry. I really tried to love this book more but I couldn't.</["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="1632984551095287811" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr name="Christina" href="/user/show/14066678-christina">Christina</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14066678-christina?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544338756" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16656584597575761916"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470530154i/19938393.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Nineteen years after the Battle of Hogwarts....</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1450380412ra/17418200.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>5 Stars, what else?<br><br>It's been a crazy 3 hours. I wish I would've re-read the other HP books before this...not to remind myself of details, because HP is the one series I could never forget. But just to fully immerse myself in that world again for a longer time. Will have to do a re-read of all 8 sometime soon with a movie marathon thrown in there.<br><br>This was amazing! I'm so happy that the script was made available as a novel. I thought I would be a bit</span>  <span id="freeText16656584597575761916" style="display:none"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470530154i/19938393.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Nineteen years after the Battle of Hogwarts....</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1450380412ra/17418200.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>5 Stars, what else?<br><br>It's been a crazy 3 hours. I wish I would've re-read the other HP books before this...not to remind myself of details, because HP is the one series I could never forget. But just to fully immerse myself in that world again for a longer time. Will have to do a re-read of all 8 sometime soon with a movie marathon thrown in there.<br><br>This was amazing! I'm so happy that the script was made available as a novel. I thought I would be a bit thrown off with it being a script rather than a proper novel. And I did miss the amazing world building and the fine details that were always a part of the HP novels. But, I had no trouble getting into the story and visualizing it (Is it weird that in my head, all the characters look the exact same...no time passage or growth?)<br><br>I wish I could have been in London to see this play, though with how much I ended up crying, it would probably have been slightly embarrassing.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1466960261ra/19535608.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I'm not going to go into details at all about this, because I don't want to spoil anyone who hasn't yet read it. Just know that this is a must read for any true Harry Potter fan.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1460325108ra/18726937.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>  <a data-text-id="16656584597575761916" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1544338756">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1544338756" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1544338756u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1544338756'><a id="like_count_review_1544338756" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1544338756?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">83 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1544338756" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1544338756" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=83u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1544338756u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1544338756" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1544338756, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1747019473" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15175945841693283065"><a href="http://leyendo-vuelo.blogspot.com/2016/09/harry-potter-and-cursed-child.html" rel="nofollow"> <b> RESEÑA COMPLETA, LLENA DE FANGIRLISMO, ACIDEZ, AMOR, ODIO, NOSTALGÍA Y CRÍTICAS AL FANDOM :P EN EL BLOG :D CLICK, CLICK </b> </a> <br /><br />La verdad, me gustó mucho.<br />¿Es necesario? Para nada.<br />¿Está a la altura de la saga original? Bitch, please, pavadas no.<br />Pero es entretenido, tiene momentos GENIALES, nostalgia a morir y, aunque muchas cosas faltaron, no se puede negar lo fantástico que es saber qué fue todos.<br /><br />Para mí el proceso de disfrute fue muy simple:<br />Lo agarré sin expectativas, recordando que es una obra de</span>  <span id="freeText15175945841693283065" style="display:none"><a href="http://leyendo-vuelo.blogspot.com/2016/09/harry-potter-and-cursed-child.html" rel="nofollow">  <b> RESEÑA COMPLETA, LLENA DE FANGIRLISMO, ACIDEZ, AMOR, ODIO, NOSTALGÍA Y CRÍTICAS AL FANDOM :P EN EL BLOG :D CLICK, CLICK </b></a> <br /><br />La verdad, me gustó mucho.<br />¿Es necesario? Para nada.<br />¿Está a la altura de la saga original? Bitch, please, pavadas no.<br />Pero es entretenido, tiene momentos GENIALES, nostalgia a morir y, aunque muchas cosas faltaron, no se puede negar lo fantástico que es saber qué fue todos.<br /><br />Para mí el proceso de disfrute fue muy simple:<br />Lo agarré sin expectativas, recordando que es una obra de teatro (con otros tiempos, otro ritmo, menor desarrollo, muchas veces exageraciones, ya que requiere una respuesta INMEDIATA del público) y tan libre de prejuicios como fui capaz, no leí reviews, ni siquiera leí la sinopsis del libro. Ignoré los rumores de la red y las opiniones ajenas. Le dije a mi fan quisquillosa interna que se callara la puta boca, y agarré el libro en blanco, dispuesta a disfrutarlo. Y eso hice.<br /><br />Creo que hay un poco de exageración en tanto descontento, a la vez me recuerda a cuando salió Las reliquias de la muerte y todos odiaron ese final, odio que borró la última década.<br /><br />En fin, ya me explayaré en mi reseña. Mi único gran consejo es: relajen, piensen menos y disfruten la sensación de volver a casa después de tanto tiempo ❤<br /><br />Pd. Les RE CABE a todos la cantidad de Romione que tiene este libro.<br />Pd2. LES RE CABE EL DOBLE el bombón que es Draco. Yo les dije, les dijeeeee, les dijeeeeeeeeeeeeeee.</span>  <a data-text-id="15175945841693283065" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1747019473">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1747019473" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1747019473u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1747019473'><a id="like_count_review_1747019473" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1747019473?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">87 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1747019473" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1747019473" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=87u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=3u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1747019473u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1747019473" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1747019473, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">16 comments</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1747019473?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=3">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1747019473' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1747019473/comments?reverse=true">View all 16 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1747019473' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1747019473, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1543865475" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543865475" />    <a title="Vane J." class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/19590155-vane-j"><img alt="Vane J." src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1468102148p2/19590155.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543865475?book_show_action=false">Feb 10, 2016</a>      <a title="Vane J." class="user" name="Vane J." href="/user/show/19590155-vane-j">Vane J.</a>          marked it as to-read            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543865475" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4611343705920593944">Should I start hyperventilating now or should I wait till I have it on my hands? In any case, I NEED THIS NOW. Who cares it's a play? IT'S A NEW HARRY POTTER STORY!<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1443226814ra/16335057.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1543865475">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1543865475" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1543865475u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1543865475'><a id="like_count_review_1543865475" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1543865475?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">85 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1543865475" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1543865475" ref="like"
