</div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1708411694" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1708411694" />    <a title="Puck" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/18562856-puck"><img alt="Puck" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467836564p2/18562856.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1708411694?book_show_action=false">Sep 25, 2016</a>      <a title="Puck" class="user" name="Puck" href="/user/show/18562856-puck">Puck</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18562856-puck?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18562856-puck?shelf=plays">plays</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/18562856-puck?shelf=2016-reads">2016-reads</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1708411694" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer467667477157422104"><b> <i> It's a lame trick. Everyone enjoys its lameness. </i> </b><br /><br />Okay, calling the long-awaited Harry Potter play lame is a bit harsh, but while this is a HP-book, I won't call it a really good one. Not everything J.K. Rowling writes becomes pure gold. <u> So as a Harry Potter fan and a scriptwriter, I'm going to explain why the script kicks ass as a play, but sucks as a story. </u><br /><br />I love theater: I'm an actress and I have even written theater scripts and movie scenario's myself, so I know what things work and don'</span>  <span id="freeText467667477157422104" style="display:none"><b>  <i> It's a lame trick. Everyone enjoys its lameness. </i></b><br /><br />Okay, calling the long-awaited Harry Potter play lame is a bit harsh, but while this is a HP-book, I won't call it a really good one. Not everything J.K. Rowling writes becomes pure gold. <u> So as a Harry Potter fan and a scriptwriter, I'm going to explain why the script kicks ass as a play, but sucks as a story. </u><br /><br />I love theater: I'm an actress and I have even written theater scripts and movie scenario's myself, so I know what things work and don't work on a stage. And with that knowledge I can say that this play would be awesome to watch. Because can you imagine? Seeing these things live:<br /><br />- The beginning at King's Cross? The place where it all started/ended? I'd probably burst into tears seeing that live. <br />- The effects of polyjuice potion? <br />- Time travelling with a Time Turner?<br />- Part Two, Act Three?! Because that part was the best of the whole book and seeing that on stage would blow me away (especially the finale. Holy crap, reading that part alone gave me goosebumps). <br />- The last battle between You-Know-Who (HA!) and Harry?<br />- And of course, seeing Albus and Scorpius, the only good characters in this play, interact live. Okay, Albus is first a bit of a pretentious whiner, but when Scorpius puts his life into perspective Albus sobers up and becomes just as strong as Scorpius. Ugh, precious boys. u0026lt;3<br /><br />But apart from the visual effects, the story of the play - which in itself is pretty bad, but I'll get to that - would actually work very well on stage. The dramatic actions, the conflicts between fathers and sons, the battles: those make a play interesting to watch. To simply read a script makes any story seem unrealistic, but you won't notice that when you're watching the play. Than the story 'works his magic'.<br /><br />So yes, this play would be marvelous to watch, and reading all the positive reviews, it certainly is. I hope I'll get the chance to see it someday.<br /><br />But as great as the script works out live, it is a script based on the Harry Potter universe. That universe is famous and known by millions of people, and that's why you have to be careful with writing a HP-play. It has to be a good, well-researched story.<br /><br />And that's what wrong with this book/script: the story isn't researched at all. In fact, it is <b>awful</b>. I've read people compare it to fanfiction, and I'm not even going to do that. Because fanfiction-writers do their research. Because even the most horrifying Harry Potter fanfiction of all (<s>My Immortal</s>) isn't as bad as this one. "My Immortal" is at least so bad that it becomes hilarious. It's a clear parody of the original Harry Potter books and so the story only makes me laugh. <br /><br /><b> The story of The Cursed Child however often made me want to tear my hair out and cry</b>. Many other Goodreaders made great lists of reasons why the Cursed Child sucks, and I really agree with those. The Time-Travelling was very plot-convenient, of the Golden Trio Ron's character was butchered most of all, and Albus u0026amp; Scorpius's relationship feels a lot like queerbaiting. Still, I want to mention the bad parts of the CC which pissed me off the most, so here's a top three:<br /><br />3.) Rose, the daughter of Ron and Hermoine, being mean and prejudiced to Scorpius. Rose, the daughter of Hermoine. You know, the girl who got bullied almost the whole time while she was at Hogwarts. Hermoine, who knows the negative-effects of prejudice better than anyone. That Hermoine, letting her own daughter act the same way as her old bullies? NO WAY IN HELL. <br />2.) What Jack Thorne, the writer of this play, did to Cedric Diggory. That boy already got an end he didn't deserve, and even now he can't rest in piece. Leave Cedric alone. <br />1.) Harry being an horrible father. Harry has multiple father-figures in the books, and while not all of them are good and healthy ones, they all support and care for him. Mr. Weasley, Dumbledore, Sirius, Remus, and especially Hagrid are there to help and talk to Harry when he needs to. Also, take in account that Harry himself has been abused and yelled at for the first eleven years of his life, so reading about <u>Harry yelling at his child and telling Albus that he wishes he wasn't his son? </u><br /><br />No. No, Jack Thorne. That's not my Harry.<br /><br />And so, although it saddens my Harry Potter Heart, I'll give this book/script <b>3 stars</b>. This play has a kind of magical power and energy to it that would make it incredible to watch on stage, but the story of the play alone is horrible and damaging to its original characters. <br />Albus and Scorpius are sweet boys and awesome Slytherins, but even they aren't strong enough to save Cedric, Harry's parents, or this play. <br /><br />Ps. If you do want to watch a Harry Potter-play that is more true to the characters, and totally awesome, I suggest <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wmwM_AKeMCk" rel="nofollow">A Very Potter Musical</a>. The actors all have fun, the songs are great, and you can watch it for free on Youtube. A good remedy for the sour taste that CC gave us.</span>  <a data-text-id="467667477157422104" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1543975103" />    <a title="Giselle (Book Nerd Canada)" class="left <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1543975103?book_show_action=false">Oct 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Giselle (Book Nerd Canada)" class="user" name="Giselle (Book Nerd Canada)" href="/user/show/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada">Giselle (Book Nerd Canada)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781338099133" href="/book/show/29069989-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-parts-1-2">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada?shelf=borrowed">borrowed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada?shelf=2016">2016</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada?shelf=3-star">3-star</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada?shelf=genre-fantasy">genre-fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada?shelf=age-children">age-children</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5789353-giselle-book-nerd-canada?shelf=genre-action-adventure">genre-action-adventure</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(u0026#39;reviewTextContainer1543975103u0026#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543975103" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12257696996839370379">This script is not what I was expecting. I didnt expect Murphy's Law to become reality and turn everything upside down. Every single thing goes topsy-turvy. Like a bad dream, or in some cases a nightmare. And this is where all the twists come in!<br /><br />First of all, the writing is different. You can tell which areas of the script were written by Mrs. Rowling herself and which were not. It read more like a fan fiction story than anything. You can't count this as the last story because it's not written i</span>  <span id="freeText12257696996839370379" style="display:none">This script is not what I was expecting. I didnt expect Murphy's Law to become reality and turn everything upside down. Every single thing goes topsy-turvy. Like a bad dream, or in some cases a nightmare. And this is where all the twists come in! <br /><br />First of all, the writing is different. You can tell which areas of the script were written by Mrs. Rowling herself and which were not. It read more like a fan fiction story than anything. You can't count this as the last story because it's not written in the same style. <br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Secondly, you can't get a feel for everyone's personalities especially the new cast of characters because the character development is simply not there. I didn't even understand why or how Albus had such a rocky relationship with his father Harry. I also thought that Albus and Scorpius were one of the most reckless decision makers I have ever emcountered. They were old enough to know the laws of Time but they completely disregarded how many times?!? It was a nightmare through and through!<br /><br />Thirdly, the characters of Albus and Scorpius weren't just platonic, I had a feeling it was more romantic than anything else and I was hoping there was going to be something happening between the two. As for the others, I loved seeing how the trio were in their respective careers. That Hermione took both her last name and Ron's considering Hermione Granger-Weasley. I love that she became Minister of Magic..That Harry became the head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcemrnt and that Ron owns the joke shop. All pretty fitting to their career paths. I love seeing how Harry fails spectacularly at being a father only because we know he's nowhere near perfect. I loved seeing Cedric even for the briefest of moments. Mr. Diggory's part was too sad and I could remember myself crying all over again when I heard him cry in the movie. <br /><br />And can we talk about that plot twist? That one part where Delphi comes in?!? I'm always suspicious of new characters and this one I filed down as one to watch and I was right. She had ulterior motives and it didn't surprise me one bit.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />Overall, this is filed away in my brain as fan fiction and not a complete story to the original books. It doesn't have the magic or the allure as the brilliant novels so please proceed with caution if you read it. <br /><br />RATING 3/5<br /><br />QUOTES<br /><br />"Nothing scares me. Apart from Mum." (67)<br /><br />Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic. In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again. (258)<br /><br />Be honest to those you love, show your pain. To suffer is as human as to breathe. (258)</span>  <a data-text-id="12257696996839370379" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544756982" />    <a title="♛ Garima ♛" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25988362-garima"><img alt="♛ Garima ♛" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1474097823p2/25988362.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544756982?book_show_action=false">Aug 31, 2016</a>      <a title="♛ Garima ♛" class="user" name="♛ Garima ♛" href="/user/show/25988362-garima">♛ Garima ♛</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25988362-garima?shelf=children-s">children-s</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544756982" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5361779993604438105"><br>Before reading: <br><br>Just ordered now! <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470117742i/19888886.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>After reading:<br><br><s>I don't think there would be any elaborate review for this except that I am disappointed. </s><br><br><b>Update Aug-16 </b><br><br>As there are so many speculations of why I didn't like this book, I feel compelled to defend my rating.<br><br><b>Parts worked out for me: </b><br><br>1. I couldn't care less about <b>book's format</b>. I'm dialogue driven person. Sometimes I skip few paragraphs just to read what a characters has to say. It's not called skipping, it's technique to read faster. As this book wa</span>  <span id="freeText5361779993604438105" style="display:none"><br>Before reading: <br><br>Just ordered now! <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470117742i/19888886.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>After reading:<br><br><s>I don't think there would be any elaborate review for this except that I am disappointed. </s><br><br><b>Update Aug-16 </b><br><br>As there are so many speculations of why I didn't like this book, I feel compelled to defend my rating.<br><br><b>Parts worked out for me: </b><br><br>1. I couldn't care less about <b>book's format</b>. I'm dialogue driven person. Sometimes I skip few paragraphs just to read what a characters has to say. It's not called skipping, it's technique to read faster. As this book was written in stage play I absolutely have no problems with it. <br><br>2. Harry becomes <b>obnoxious?</b> No people he doesn't or may be he does. People grow into something different than you imagined they would. Being parent is not an easy job. It happens, so that being said I have no problems with Harry's character development or any other (Ron/Hermione) for that matter. <br><br>3. For me, Albus never took the back-seat. He was hero for me for the entire novel, no Scorpio doesn't steal the limelight. Well, not for me atleast. I liked him, no doubt but this story is of Albus Potter, no one else. <br><br>I can go on and on about things that worked for me.<br><br>Then why 1 star - refer to below section<br><br><b>Parts didn't work out for me: </b><br><br><b>Time travelling.</b> It is as easy and simple people. I hate time travelling - it is mentioned in my profile as well. Time travelling/Parallel universe, that type of stuff makes me antsy. Very uneasy and nervous. Hence my capacity of reading/rating.<br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="5361779993604438105" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1544108177" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1544108177u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1544108177" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1544108177" ref="like" comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1714734935" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1714734935" />    <a title="Charnell (Reviews from a Bookworm)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/24060858-charnell-reviews-from-a-bookworm"><img alt="Charnell (Reviews from a Bookworm)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1423864239p2/24060858.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1714734935?book_show_action=false">Aug 09, 2016</a>      <a title="Charnell (Reviews from a Bookworm)" class="user" name="Charnell (Reviews from a Bookworm)" href="/user/show/24060858-charnell-reviews-from-a-bookworm">Charnell (Reviews from a Bookworm)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1714734935" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15265451450821489494"><a href="https://continuumissues.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/disappointed.gif" rel="nofollow"> <img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1448624434ra/17167411.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a>It is finally time for me to review a <u>new</u>Harry Potter story and that feels amazing. What doesn't feel amazing is that my thoughts are so conflicted. I finished reading this play and immediately stamped 5/5 on my Goodreads review. It wasn't that I loved the story, it was that I loved being transported back to a world I love, to characters I adore so much and to experience that magic once again. I had tears in my eyes whilst finishing this book because it just brought back all those nostalgic fee</span>  <span id="freeText15265451450821489494" style="display:none"><a href="https://continuumissues.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/disappointed.gif" rel="nofollow">  <img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1448624434ra/17167411.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a>It is finally time for me to review a <u>new</u> Harry Potter story and that feels amazing. What doesn't feel amazing is that my thoughts are so conflicted. I finished reading this play and immediately stamped 5/5 on my Goodreads review. It wasn't that I loved the story, it was that I loved being transported back to a world I love, to characters I adore so much and to experience that magic once again. I had tears in my eyes whilst finishing this book because it just brought back all those nostalgic feelings. The problem was that the story wasn't as good as I had hoped and the more I think about the book, the less happy with it I get. It's currently on a 3/5 with the potential to go lower if I dwell on it anymore. So, no more dwelling, time for reviewing. And, don't worry, if you haven't read the book yet then I won't spoil it. I will keep this part completely non-spoilery and then have the spoilers after a massive warning, for all those who have read it.<br><br><br><br>This was never going to be the story that most Harry Potter fans wanted. For one thing, it is a script of a play and not a novel. We all knew this before buying so it's not a shock, but it does mean it's a weird new way to experience the Harry Potter world. This is something that is supposed to be experienced and watched, not read. The other main issue is that, no matter how largely they write her name on the cover, this was not written by J.K. Rowling. And that is a terrible thing to me as it meant that I felt the characters were just lacking in a way they wouldn't have been if she had wrote it. The characters always just felt a little off and not like the characters we spent seven books getting to know.<br><br><br><a href="http://38.media.tumblr.com/5bbd93d7537b8a8e8218f879b9237020/tumblr_inline_n01l49jvcp1sqlubn.gif" rel="nofollow">          <img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470769678ra/19963382.gif" height="147" width="320" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a>          <br>How Jack Thorne u0026amp; JKR are probably feeling    <br><br>The story itself was not at all what I was expecting, but I am mentioning nothing about it here. I think it is better to go in blind. We all know this book takes place 19 years after the Battle of Hogwarts, and follows Harry's son Albus rather than Harry. We meet some brilliant characters in this, but also some bad ones. My main issue with the story was that it all felt a bit ridiculous and that a lot of it didn't make sense. I, quite honestly, can never view this play as canon because it all just feels ridiculous and as if it would never happen. Another major issue is the gaping plot holes that this book then leaves us with. And I hate gaping plot holes!<br><br><br><br>So, yes, overall I was disappointed. I loved some aspects of this but was really pissed about others. I need to go into spoilery detail to explain all that.  If you haven't read this yet or seen the play then now is the time to skip out.<br><br><br><br><div>  <br><b>    !SPOILERS AHEAD!  </b></div><br><div>  <br><img src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1413186402r/11476474.gif?148015611112094" height="172" width="320" class="gr-hostedUserImg hostedImg" data-src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1413186402r/11476474.gif" style=";display:none;" data-error="[image error]" onerror="$j(this).loadHostedImage();" onload="$j(this).loadHostedImage();"><img src="/assets/loading-trans.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg loadingImg"></div><br><br><br>Okay, now we have got the warning out of the way... LET'S DO THIS!!!<br><br><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<br>I am actually excited to review this and go into all my spoilery thoughts. I have to, I won't be able to contain myself otherwise. I need to lay it all out on the table. First I need to get this out of the way: I LOVE HARRY POTTER! If you know me in real life or from my blog, twitter or instagram then you already know this. Harry Potter is my life and has been since I was 6/7 and my nan bought me the first book. Harry Potter was basically my childhood and I loved every minute of it. It was a childhood of midnight releases of books and films. Of dressing up as a Hogwarts student for Halloween. It's owning more HP clothes than regular clothes. It's having to do the Harry Potter London walking tour and Studio Tour. It's owning multiple editions of the books. Harry Potter is life and will forever be. <i>BUT</i> I am never going to be one of those people who is blinded by my love for something. I wanted to love this play, I really did, but I didn't in the end and that is because it has a lot of flaws and problems and things I didn't like. Plus, and I feel this is important, it is a script for a play and I feel it is better to experience as a show (which I will doing next year as I got tickets!!!).<br><br><br><br>I will do a very quick summary for anyone reading the spoilery side even if they haven't read the play (naughty!). Basically the story focuses on Harry's son Albus as he begins attending Hogwarts and gets placed in Slytherin *gasp*. This is a huge deal and Albus ends up sucking at magic and forever living in his fathers shadow, which he resents, and their relationship is basically strained as fuck. Harry is a terrible father for some reason. Scorpius Malfoy is the most adorable bean of all time and him and Albus become best friends, who are totally in love with each other (but we will get to that later). Amos Diggory shows up out the blue with his niece Delphi, wanting Harry to go back in time and save Cedric's life. Harry, even though one last surviving time turner has been found, lies and says he can't. Albus then decides to do it himself, with the help of good ol' Scorpius. Of course going back in time and changing one tiny detail changes <b>everything</b> and shit hits the fan. So then they keep having to go back, changing things until eventually we figure out that Delphi is the lovechild of Voldemort and Bellatrix and she wants to go back in time to prevent him from ever killing Harry, so that he would never have been defeated. And, yeah, there is one really simplified version of this messy plot.<br><br><br><br><div><br>Trying to make sense of The Cursed Child plot, like...</div><br><div><br><img height="211" src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1450959455r/17492257.gif?14801561116594" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg hostedImg" data-src="https://s3.amazonaws.com/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1450959455r/17492257.gif" style=";display:none;" data-error="[image error]" onerror="$j(this).loadHostedImage();" onload="$j(this).loadHostedImage();"><img src="/assets/loading-trans.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg loadingImg"></div><br><br><br>The first thing I have to mention is probably what anyone who has read it wanted to discuss the most... Voldemort had a lovechild with Bellatrix Lestrange! REALLY!?!?! I got to that point in the book and suddenly understood why I had heard people saying they felt this read like fan fiction. My mouth dropped open and disappointment set in. It just makes zero sense to me, and the explanation of it and timeline of those events also make no sense to me. I just don't see Voldemort as someone concerned with having a child. His plan was to get the Deathly Hallows and master death, so he wasn't looking for an heir. And, come on, it's not like the guy has even one tiny paternal bone in his body. The only thing that does make sense is that if Voldemort had a kid with anyone it would be Bellatrix, you can totally see her wanting to have his baby. I still don't get how this all happened and no one knew. And that it was never alluded to in the final book. She apparently gave birth in the Malfor Manor before the Battle of Hogwarts. So where was the baby whilst she was off fighting? Why did Draco not know about it? Or did he and just never felt like he should mention it?!? Come on, this is the most ridiculous HP storyline in the history of ever and I am going to pretend that it is fanfiction and not canon because otherwise I'd have to rate this a 1/5 and I just can't deal with that right now!<br><br><br><br>The next thing we have to discuss is the main plot device here: <b>time travel</b>. Why?!?! Do not mess with time travel, it's far too overused and just results in endless plot holes and problems. This book is not an exception to that rule. Especially when we take into account that the main plot here is that Albus and Scorpius want to use the time turner to go back in time and save Cedric Diggory's life...<br><br><br><br><div><br><img alt="kristen wiig frustrated unimpressed bridesmaids are you kidding me" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1427413889ra/14269476.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></div><br><br><br>They have a time turner that can take them back <i>years</i> and they are going to use this to save Cedric Diggory. Can we all take a moment to appreciate how utterly pointless and stupid that act would be <u>if</u> we think about the fact they could go back in time and strangle tiny, evil baby Voldemort and save thousands of people?!? Oh no, let's just go back in time and save one boy.<br><br><br><br><div><br><img alt="stupid the hangover stupid people" height="167" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1461930724ra/18930879.gif" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></div><br><div><br><br></div><br><br><br>That is like someone giving you a time turner in our world and going back in time to save Anne Frank, rather than killing Hitler. If you kill the evil overlord then you would save all the people that died at their hands. So the whole time I am just sitting here wanting to slap everyone for being so stupid. But it is obvious why they can't all suddenly realise they have the power to murder Voldemort and prevent everything... It would mean that everything that came after that would completely change and the first seven Harry Potter books would never have happened. So of course we can't have that, so we will just have this giant stupid plot hole instead. Gah, I hate the time travel storyline so much.<br><br><br><br>The next biggest problem with this book is the characterisation and how wrong it is in this play. Ron is suddenly reduced to just a little bit of comedic relief. He just eats food and pulls pranks, and apparently got so drunk at his wedding that he forgot most of it. Why has Ron suddenly turned into a Weasley twin too? I know he liked pranks and found them funny before, but he was no Fred or George. And why is he giving a small boy a love potion as a joke gift? He was put under the influence of a love potion and it wasn't an experience he particularly enjoyed, so I can't see him then being stupid enough to give one to a child. Ron is my fictional husband and I hated seeing what Jack Thorne reduced his character to here, it was not fun to read.<br><br><br><br>Harry was even worse, I hated him being the world's worst father who would be so horrible to tell his son that sometimes he wished he wasn't his son. I just don't see Harry ever saying that. I feel he would love his children, no matter how difficult they could be and appreciate being able to be their for them, as he never had that as a child. And watching him treat Professor McGonagall like shit made for even more unpleasant reading. Am I supposed to believe that Harry, the guy who flipped out when a Death Eater spat on her, would then go and treat her with so little respect? Nope, I am not buying that.<br><br><br><br>Hermione was just as hard to read, especially in the timeline where her and Ron never got together. She basically becomes a female version of Snape. She's Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher at Hogwarts, who treats the children horribly. She's nasty and bitter, and apparently all because she didn't wind up with Ron?!? No. Are we really reducing Hermione down to this? She is a strong, brave, kind person and I don't see her ever turning that bitter because of a guy, she is so much better than that. Why did J.K. Rowling give this her stamp of approval?!?!<br><br><br><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470769678ra/19963383.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>Me watching Jack Thorne ruin my favourite characters<br><br><div><br>And I am still not sold on the fact that getting humiliated one time would suddenly turn Cedric Diggory into an evil Death Eater?!? Come on. I know this is J.K. Rowling trying some Butterfly Effect type situation but it is just awful. I don't believe for one second that Cedric would allow that one moment in his life change him so completely that he suddenly goes to the HP Dark Side and start working for Voldemort. No.</div><br><div><br><br></div><br><div><br>I have another big issue and that is this: Scorpius and Albus are blatantly in love with each other. The issue isn't that they love each other, the issue is that this seems super obvious to 90% of people reading and yet it is never addressed. Instead they end the book with them discussing what girls they want to get with. Come on, they totally love each other and I ship it endlessly. I just get so sad to see the potential to have our first openly gay couple in the Harry Potter universe squandered. These two were just utterly adorable and I ship it endlessly and feel it is time we finally have a gay couple in HP. Not just watch them fill a play with so much homoerotic subtext and then just brush it all aside at the end. No. In my mind they become the most adorably squishy couple ever, get married and join the Potter and Malfoy households. </div><br><div><br><br></div><br><div><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470769678ra/19963384.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></div><br><br><br><br><br>It wasn't all bad though and there were aspects that I really liked. The biggest one being Scorpius Malfoy! He is adorable and I just loved his character. He is so sweet and kind, and I just was so happy with his character. I also loved that Albus and Scorpius were both Slytherins, and both kind, wonderful Slytherins. I have a big soft spot for Slytherin house so I was happy that this play shows that Slytherins are just as awesome! I also loved Scorpius and Albus together, but still wholeheartedly believe they should be a couple. The thing I loved most about this was all the Hermione and Ron feelings that it gave me. I was so happy when reading this book. I loved when Rob told Hermione he wanted to renew their wedding vows, it was utterly adorable. And I cried a little when, even in the world where they never got together, they both still loved each other and sacrificed themselves together! My shipper heart could not handle that!<br> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br><br><div>  <br><a href="https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-_5uO-ByF6fA/V6ocCmkKGpI/AAAAAAAAGqs/750dvuwRJao8yit-Xefw30icCK2GASwlACLcB/s1600/3-butterflies.png" rel="nofollow">    <img height="63" src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470769678i/19963385.png" width="320" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></a></div><br><div>  <br><i>    <b>      3/5 Butterflies    </b>  </i></div><br><div>  <br><br></div><br>Writing this review actually felt quite therapeutic, but I must admit that the more I think about the story, the more upset I get. I just wanted this to be amazing and everything I was hoping for, and it wasn't. I feel this was definitely missing J.K. Rowling's touch and I wish she had been the one to write the script, as I feel the characters would have felt more real if she had. It wasn't all bad and I enjoyed the story whilst reading. It blew my mind reading it, as I tried to figure out how they were going to pull this off on stage. I am excited to see it on stage, as I feel I will love it when I see that. But I can't ever consider this as canon because it just had too many plot holes and makes little sense when you think back on the Harry Potter books.<br><br><br></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="15265451450821489494" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1714734935" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1714734935" ref="like" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1549520662" />    <a title="Liz Janet" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5114433-liz-janet"><img alt="Liz Janet" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1479698711p2/5114433.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1549520662?book_show_action=false">Oct 25, 2016</a>      <a title="Liz Janet" class="user" name="Liz Janet" href="/user/show/5114433-liz-janet">Liz Janet</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1549520662" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer78030380893912632"><a href="https://booksandstuff1357.wordpress.com/2016/08/13/harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-horrible-character-study-book-review/" rel="nofollow">HARRY POTTER AND THE CURSED CHILD: HORRIBLE CHARACTER STUDY </a><br /><br />I was not very excited for this book, mostly because I knew it had not been written by J.K. Rowling. However, I wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt. The story had her consent, so it could not be that bad, right? It was bad. How so many people seem to like it I will never know. My disdain for the story roots from the horrendous treatment characters got, not only because their lives were not what I expected/assumed they would be, b</span>  <span id="freeText78030380893912632" style="display:none"><a href="https://booksandstuff1357.wordpress.com/2016/08/13/harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-horrible-character-study-book-review/" rel="nofollow">HARRY POTTER AND THE CURSED CHILD: HORRIBLE CHARACTER STUDY </a><br /><br />I was not very excited for this book, mostly because I knew it had not been written by J.K. Rowling. However, I wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt. The story had her consent, so it could not be that bad, right? It was bad. How so many people seem to like it I will never know. My disdain for the story roots from the horrendous treatment characters got, not only because their lives were not what I expected/assumed they would be, but because characters we have been shown with characteristics and certain feelings, got those traits completely erased in order to fit the narrative of the story, which is not that appealing in the first place.<br /><br />Before I go on a non-spoiler rampage of all I despised with this “play”, I want to mention that quite a few things were not bad, but quite agreeable. Albus and Scorpious are both in Slytherin. I knew it was going to happen, one could simply tell, but it is nice to finally have two “main characters” in the house that once (and apparently still) was considered evil. As no one wanted to focus on Merlin, Slughorn, Regulus, Andromeda, and probably a bunch of other characters that were named but never given any characteristics. Which always leads me to this question: CAN SLYHTERINS JUST GET A BREAK???!!!<br /><br />That aside, some of the dialogue by Draco Malfoy, as well as some of his conversations with the Golden Trio seemed quite accurate, yes, even that acclaimed exclamation all over Tumblr about him loving being bossed around by Hermione Granger. My favourite scene was one in which Draco is distraught by a “plot-twist”, as his son and Albus are “missing”. “DRACO: I don’t care what you did or who you saved, you are a constant curse on my family, Harry Potter.” It tells the perfect relationship the Potter and Malfoy families seem to have here, and it seems to trod along with the belief of a few people as well, no matter how good Harry was (and he was/is), many people gave their lives for him, and that is a curse, even though it helped the Wizarding World. There is also a small snippet of what it ight be like to be Draco: “It is exceptionally lonely, being Draco Malfoy. I will always be suspected. There is no escaping the past.” No matter how much one might run, the past will always catch up with them, yet, it does not have to be the end. And finally, we have the fun scenes that demonstrate the wittiness that Draco possesses:<br />“Draco: Flipendo! … Keep up, old man.<br />Harry: We’re the same age, Draco.<br />Draco: I wear it better.”<br /><br />The one other thing was how Ron and Hermione’s love transpired everything. It showed that no matter in which world, they were meant for each other.<br /><br />That is all I enjoyed. Now, onto the things I disliked.<br /><br />Characters that were done a disservice, since their essence was butchered: Hermione, McGonagall, Harry, Ron, Astoria, Draco, Scorpious, Albus, Rose, Bellatrix, Voldemort, and perhaps a couple more. Yes, even Bellatrix and Voldemort. I will only go into detail for a couple, and at the end of the review I will go into the spoiler-filled destroyed characters.<br /><br />Let us begin with the most obvious one, Hermione Jean Granger. Do we all remember S.P.E.W.? How this little, almost non-existent organization, showed Hermione as a person who valued everyone’s lives as equal, whether they were lowly elves, giants, werewolves, centaurs. But for some reason, the protector of magical creatures has not found a way to at least, keep the peace between them and humans. No, she seems rather incompetent when it comes to that, particularly when we are given her position in the government. Also, her logic is severely flawed here, in almost all aspects. <br /><br />Then we get one of the biggest disappointments, Rose Granger-Weasley. The daughter of two brave and good-hearted people, who value family and friendship above everything, abandons her cousin simply because he belongs to another house. Rose gave me the impression that she was a version of Pansy, someone I would hate to be in school with. We all know that in this version of events, Scorpious and Albus are bullied for who they are, and Rose does nothing to stop this, perhaps she does not even tell her parents of what is going on. To this day, I imagine Rose as a clever girl with a kind-heart, someone that loves her family, and who fights for her friends, like her father, who stood in front of Harry so he would not be hurt. Like her mother, who never gave anything away, even under the Cruciatus curse. Here she seems to be following popularity, even at the cost of her loved ones. That is not the daughter the two wonderful heroes would raise. <br /><br />“How to distract Scorpius from difficult emotional issues. Take him to a library.” The one accurate thing that I imagined would ever be authentic about the son of Malfoy in this book. Scorpious and Albus’ life is a disaster, simply because of the house they belong to, as I seriously doubt it has anything to do with their families. Status is not something that is simply lost after certain events, it is a way of thinking and living, and no matter how much many try to change it, it requires time. Therefore, I will never believe that a Malfoy would loose the status that they have had for centuries, considering that they did not loose it after the first war, and that Narcissa basically saved Harry from death. It made no sense, particularly after they were pardoned and married a non-purist pureblood family. Also, a Potter being mistreated because he is in Slytherin? Even after Slytherins themselves fought at the Battle of Hogwarts? Even though he has done nothing to deserve dislike except for his horrendous name? No. <br /><br />The second greatest fall of this work is the plot, as it was mostly, useless. Of all the things to bring to the story, the one they went with is the one that leaves everything with nothing that should be touched upon again. I expected better, I wish I had gotten it. <br /><br />When I have children, I will give them the seven Harry Potter books, and when they are done and ask for more, I will gladly tell them to go read fanfiction, and I will never mention this book exists. I do not have time for some of my favourite, and the most iconic characters ever, to be obliterated before their eyes. I am not that cruel.<br /><br /><br />_____________________________<br />Emiy Cait's Spoiler Video gets a lot of the same points: <a target="_blank" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRYIYlsvyaw" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRYIY...</a></span>  <a data-text-id="78030380893912632" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1549076775" />    <a title="Sahej" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/39304721-sahej"><img alt="Sahej" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1475433330p2/39304721.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1549076775?book_show_action=false">Aug 01, 2016</a>      <a title="Sahej" class="user" name="Sahej" href="/user/show/39304721-sahej">Sahej</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/39304721-sahej?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/39304721-sahej?shelf=physical-books-i-own">physical-books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/39304721-sahej?shelf=2016-reads">2016-reads</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/39304721-sahej?shelf=magical-world-of-harry-potter">magical-world-of-harry-potter</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1549076775" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2101507036540637401">A million stars if I could! What a book? I loved it. Just... Amazing. <br /><br />So, first of all I will respect JKR and #KeepTheSecrets! <br /><br />I will like to say that I absolutely appreciate JKR for co-writing this novel! I loved it to bits but I have to say that this <b>book</b> did not have the magic the seven books had. Personally, I didn't want anymore books in this series because <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows__Harry_Potter___7_" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7) by J.K. Rowling"> Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</a>' ending was perfect. I loved that ending and I wanted to keep it that way. When <i>the Cursed Child</i></span>  <span id="freeText2101507036540637401" style="display:none">A million stars if I could! What a book? I loved it. Just... Amazing. <br /><br />So, first of all I will respect JKR and #KeepTheSecrets! <br /><br />I will like to say that I absolutely appreciate JKR for co-writing this novel! I loved it to bits but I have to say that this <b>book</b> did not have the magic the seven books had. Personally, I didn't want anymore books in this series because <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/136251.Harry_Potter_and_the_Deathly_Hallows__Harry_Potter___7_" title="Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter, #7) by J.K. Rowling"> Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</a>' ending was perfect. I loved that ending and I wanted to keep it that way. When <i>the Cursed Child</i> was announced, I was over the moon but then I was like do we need another HP book? Hmmm...<br /><br />If you wanted a proper HP book, then you'll be very much disappointed. This play/book, is mature than the seven novels, a play that is magical but is still less magical than the books and a lot of focus on characters! <br /><br />Furthermore, this book didn't loose its funny side with both Scorpius and Ron being the comic relief. I won't say much more about this play without spoiling it! Hope you all enjoy this new addition to the HP world.</span>  <a data-text-id="2101507036540637401" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1549076775">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1549076775" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1549076775u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1549076775'><a id="like_count_review_1549076775" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1549076775?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">37 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1549076775" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1549076775" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=37u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=6u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1549076775u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1549076775" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1549076775, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); + encodeURIComponent(u0026#39;GRmkpBk9hS1DdmoJkjXoTys6EsEsIysr4xrnmIyy2XqypthVdjyDXFeAUcjXWTaqikocS7F9VGW88MxhplayOA==u0026#39;)}); return false;">10</a> <span class="gap">u0026hellip;</span> <a class="next_page" href="#" onclick="new Ajax.Request(u0026#39;/book/reviews/29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two?authenticity_token=R1UbqOzKydywXWmdBdWNy02KpPurz8Z8GcTGA7rgqqbs6mdZg8vPraSrUlxAuVMu7PqqcTaRuTJGLu36kATB5A%3D%3Du0026amp;amp;hide_last_page=trueu0026amp;amp;page=7u0026#39;, {asynchronous:true, evalScripts:true, method:u0026#39;getu0026#39;, parameters:u0026#39;authenticity_token=u0026#39; + encodeURIComponent(u0026#39;T5xo8bMlJPxAonNuVLhOKmAdpYIz2kOR0t8WgWONQlbkIxQA3CQijVRUSK8R1JDPwW2rCK6EPN+NNT14SWkpFA==u0026#39;)}); return false;">next »</a></div></div>
<div class="right bookMeta darkGreyText">    <span class="smallText">(showing 181-210)</span></div><div id="bookReviewControls" data-book-reviews-page="7">  <a class="uitext" class="greyText">(481201)</span></a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span>            <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;|u0026nbsp;</span>            <span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a href="/book/reviews/29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two?rating=5" class="actionLinkLite loadingLink" rel="nofollow" data-keep-on-success="true" data-remote="true">5 stars <span class="greyText">(71885)</span></a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span>            <span          $j('#rating_details_tip_graph').remove();          $copy.attr('id', 'rating_details_tip_graph');          $copy.find('script').remove();          $j('#rating_details_tip').prepend($copy);      }  //]]>  </script></div><div id="bookReviews">    <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section firstReview">      <div id="review_1548462735" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1548462735" />    <a title="Kayley Hyde" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/735954-kayley-hyde"><img alt="Kayley Hyde" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1476120866p2/735954.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1548462735?book_show_action=false">Aug 22, 2016</a>      <a title="Kayley Hyde" class="user" name="Kayley Hyde" href="/user/show/735954-kayley-hyde">Kayley Hyde</a>          added it                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/735954-kayley-hyde?shelf=top-to-read">top-to-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/735954-kayley-hyde?shelf=2016-release">2016-release</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1548462735" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17060880053890690192">Honestly I don't even know how I'd rate this because having had the incredible privilege to see it was remarkable. I have issues with a lot of the plot and characters but ultimately it was the most, forgive me, magical visual experiences I've ever had and I think about moments of it every day. It sits beside my beloved Harry Potter books, but not with them. I feel the same way about the canon of the play as I do the films, JK Rowling's tweets, etc: (mostly) wonderful additions, but separate. So,</span>  <span id="freeText17060880053890690192" style="display:none">Honestly I don't even know how I'd rate this because having had the incredible privilege to see it was remarkable. I have issues with a lot of the plot and characters but ultimately it was the most, forgive me, magical visual experiences I've ever had and I think about moments of it every day. It sits beside my beloved Harry Potter books, but not with them. I feel the same way about the canon of the play as I do the films, JK Rowling's tweets, etc: (mostly) wonderful additions, but separate. So, overall, this play has brought more magic into my life, but reading it was...not the experience I'd have wanted from this world. So. There's a review. </span>  <a data-text-id="17060880053890690192" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50105236-ellie?shelf=2016-book-release">2016-book-release</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544163612" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15864327944700098917"><i>Nineteen years after the Battle of Hogwarts,</i> everything goes to shit (again).<br><br>#KeepTheSecrets?? #KeepYourStory please.<br><br>I was one of the people who spread the spoilers (I talked to a girl who attended the show during the first two weeks) and I was <b>not</b> very happy with them, to say the least.<br><br><i>Hogwarts will be the making of you, Albus. I promise you, there is nothing to be frightened of there. </i><br><br>But it was written well. I think plays are always meant to be performed, of course, not read, but I went throu</span>  <span id="freeText15864327944700098917" style="display:none"><i>Nineteen years after the Battle of Hogwarts,</i> everything goes to shit (again).<br><br>#KeepTheSecrets?? #KeepYourStory please.<br><br>I was one of the people who spread the spoilers (I talked to a girl who attended the show during the first two weeks) and I was <b>not</b> very happy with them, to say the least.<br><br><i>Hogwarts will be the making of you, Albus. I promise you, there is nothing to be frightened of there. </i><br><br>But it was written well. I think plays are always meant to be performed, of course, not read, but I went through it really fast and it made sense (at some parts!) <br><br>However. The beginning and the middle stretched out so much that near the end, everything felt rushed and like it was happening all at once. Mainly Act 3 and 4 - maybe it'll be a good pace while it's being performed?<br><br>To continue, there are still many issues I have with the plot. Delphi, for instance. Why Lily Luna was sidelined so much. Why so many characters were left out - all the Weasleys (i.e. Roxanne, Dominique, Victoire, Fred II, Molly II), Lorcan and Lysander...<br><br><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ Snape being referred to as "every inch a hero"<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1449291127ra/17263409.gif" width="300" height="170" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><i>DRACO looks up at HARRY, and for the first time— at the bottom of this dreadful pit—they look at each other as friends.</i><br><br>Me: *starts crying* <br><br><i>You don't know what he needs. You only know he needs it. Find him, Scorpius. You two—you belong together.<br><br>In fact, you're the best person I know. And you don't—you couldn't—hold me back. You make me stronger.<br></i> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br>And the thing that makes me the most annoyed: how much JKR could've done with the sexualities of these brand new characters, but chose not to. I'm sorry?? How hard would it have been to make Scorbus gay? Come on. They literally make the book what it is. They shine together more than they do without. <br><br>Scorpius Malfoy will undoubtedly steal your heart. Albus and Harry, of course, i think are the main characters, but he is someone who stands out even in the words he says in this script. He is wonderful, beautiful, thoughtful, and everything beyond my expectations. He makes me want to fight to be a better person. Albus is very <b>angsty</b> (he's Harry's son through and through!)<br><br>All the Ron and Hermione scenes made my heart warm. I honestly don't care if Dramione shippers point out that Hermione calls him Draco etc etc, whatever, you have your ship and I have the two people who can't stop being in love in every alternative universe. <br><br>Everyone was really OOC in a lot of the play, though. (*cough* Snape *cough*) Especially Harry, which sucks. Also, so many lines were repeated from the books - that was surprising. In a way, a lot of this was like bad fanfiction.<br><br>If this was a novel, it would be much thicker and much more developed all around, I think. Maybe because we tend to read faster in these one lines, but it was like...one minute they were at Hogwarts and then it was like 3 years later. During the play it would've probably taken some time to get everything changed, but we - as a reader - don't get that.<br><br>Even though it is a scriptbook, it felt like J.K. Rowling's writing. That was the best part. Her humor is always written well and I did laugh out a LOT so that made me really happy.</["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="15864327944700098917" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr I was ready to devour it in One sitting when I got my hands on it but that is not what happened exactly.... <b>  <i>I took my time reading this one because this is written in form of a play and I took some time getting used to it (around 50 pages or so)</i></b><br><br>The story starts with where it left off at Book 7, the train station where Harry, Ginny, Hermione, Ron and Draco are dropping off their kids at Hogwarts express...<br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1470481215ra/19933042.gif" height="" width="" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Harry is now working for the ministry and is facing his own set of issues as a parent...<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1470481215i/19933043.png" height="" width="" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>The story was pretty cool and very adventurous... Though the plot in few places was very transparent and lacked the magical touch.</b><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[It was soo evident that Delphi is a negative character from the start. In the earlier books, it was very difficult to identify the villain right away... <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><br>Overall, I have very mixed feelings about this as it is very different from the rest of the series (even though the characters and concept are similar to the other books of the series)- <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[It is more focused on Al and Scorpio but some of the reactions of the older characters felt out of place and did not ring true, especially Draco and Ron. The Trolley lady from the train thing was ridiculous. Also the whole thing that Voldemort and Bellatrix had a child felt more like a spoof. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br>We get to meet our beloved characters once again and see what is happening in their lives. We even get to go back to Hogwarts.<br><br>I kept imagining the movie characters while reading this and could not for the life of me connect this to the Play cast... <b>I would still not think for a moment and grab the chance to go and check out the play...</b><br><br><b>  <i>I miss the Harry Potter world and would want another book more closer to the original series...</i></b><br><br><img </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1544672804" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544672804" />    <a title="Andi" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/28647266-andi"><img alt="Andi" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1479370752p2/28647266.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544672804?book_show_action=false">Aug 20, 2016</a>      <a title="Andi" class="user" name="Andi" href="/user/show/28647266-andi">Andi</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/28647266-andi?shelf=the-archives">the-archives</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544672804" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15102758777462572523">*3.50*<br /><br />It pains me to not give this a five star rating. I went into this with an open mind. I promised myself I wouldn't let the script format affect my judgement; that I would base my rating solely on the story. And still I have to give this a 3.50 stars. <br /><br />I liked the plot. It took me back to all the previous adventures Harry and gang had; mentioning some significant events of the past was very nostalgic, and I absolutely loved Scorpius Malfoy. <br /><br />However, this story lacked so much. Most of the belo</span>  <span id="freeText15102758777462572523" style="display:none">*3.50*<br /><br />It pains me to not give this a five star rating. I went into this with an open mind. I promised myself I wouldn't let the script format affect my judgement; that I would base my rating solely on the story. And still I have to give this a 3.50 stars. <br /><br />I liked the plot. It took me back to all the previous adventures Harry and gang had; mentioning some significant events of the past was very nostalgic, and I absolutely loved Scorpius Malfoy. <br /><br />However, this story lacked so much. Most of the beloved characters from the other books where barely in it and some weren't even mentioned. I guess I should expect that since this story is a lot shorter and lacked the detail that we got from Rowling's previous books. But the one thing that really disappointed me was the lack of HEART this book had. Despite knowing so much about this world, this story didn't hit me as much as the other ones did.<br /><br />Should I consider this canon? Not really. There were some parts that could be and others that shouldn't. Would I recommend this book to all HP fans? Sure. If you're a die hard fan then go for it. Feed your curiosity. But if you don't read it, it's not a big deal. You're not really missing much. The first 7 books are the ones you should read in your lifetime. This book is more of a bonus.<br /><br />I hope that one day, Rowling will rewrite this story again and publish it as a full-on novel. I am sure there is more to this story than what I have read. I'd like to see her expand this story even more and see what the rest of the Potterworld has been up to while all this is happening. Kinda like a "Writer's Cut" edition, if you get my drift. Maybe that can be the official 8th book in the series. Until then, there are only 7 books to the story for me.</span>  <a data-text-id="15102758777462572523" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1544918313" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1544918313" />    <a title="Alia" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/41399254-alia"><img alt="Alia" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467569641p2/41399254.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544918313?book_show_action=false">Aug 22, 2016</a>      <a title="Alia" class="user" name="Alia" href="/user/show/41399254-alia">Alia</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/29058155-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/41399254-alia?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544918313" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10276786134300919383">I'm an emotional mess right now.<br />I've loved every bit of this book. <br /><br />Honestly, I was scared and hesitant to read the Cursed Child since a lot of people said that it is a disappointment. I see why people might not love it, but I enjoyed it immensely. <br /><br />I think when you read it you have to use your imagination a lot and forget when out of nowhere you see the words "...appears at the back of the <i>stage</i> " This ruined the image for me many times, but you'll have to try to ignore it.<br /><br />Albus and Scorpius's fr</span>  <span id="freeText10276786134300919383" style="display:none">I'm an emotional mess right now.<br />I've loved every bit of this book. <br /><br />Honestly, I was scared and hesitant to read the Cursed Child since a lot of people said that it is a disappointment. I see why people might not love it, but I enjoyed it immensely. <br /><br />I think when you read it you have to use your imagination a lot and forget when out of nowhere you see the words "...appears at the back of the <i>stage</i> " This ruined the image for me many times, but you'll have to try to ignore it.<br /><br />Albus and Scorpius's friendship was different and interesting, although I would've loved if they actually <i>got</i> together...<br />Also, you can notice that both of them are different from their parents.<br /><br />I've always loved Draco Malfoy so it made me really happy that we got to see this other side of him, in a book partly written by JK Rowling and not in a fanfiction..<br /><br />Anyway, I'm not going to talk about every character. I think you should read the book and form your own opinion about how each character grew up to be.<br /><br />I love the aspect of the time-turner and all the mess that happened. It proves how everything happens for a reason, even the slightest things that seem unimportant.<br /><br />What I've loved most about the book though, is that we got to meet characters we haven't thought that we would get to live with again, and it was amazing.. really amazing.<br /><br />I believe that you should get into the book without any expectations, It will make the experience a hundred times better.<br /><br />I adore this book. If only I could watch the play.</span>  <a data-text-id="10276786134300919383" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1544918313">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1544918313" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1544918313'><a id="like_count_review_1544918313" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1544918313?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">35 </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1714544575" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1714544575" />    <a title="u0026#39;Cila" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/27011842-cila"><img alt="u0026#39;Cila" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1472936297p2/27011842.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1714544575?book_show_action=false">Aug 25, 2016</a>      <a title="u0026#39;Cila" class="user" name="u0026#39;Cila" href="/user/show/27011842-cila">u0026#39;Cila</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/29058155-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1714544575" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3099183764659753635">I will be very clear as to why I gave this a five star. I <b>completely</b> fell in love with <u>Scorpius,</u> his character dominated every single scene he was in, and for me that made this book worth reading. I also loved Malfoy. Why, you might ask? Because it genuinely felt like a grown-up version of Draco, the way he talked and acted felt natural to his character and rang true to the original books, everyone else though felt a tad wrong. Had those two characters not blown me away, I would probably have ra</span>  <span id="freeText3099183764659753635" style="display:none">I will be very clear as to why I gave this a five star. I <b>completely</b> fell in love with <u>Scorpius,</u> his character dominated every single scene he was in, and for me that made this book worth reading. I also loved Malfoy. Why, you might ask? Because it genuinely felt like a grown-up version of Draco, the way he talked and acted felt natural to his character and rang true to the original books, everyone else though felt a tad wrong. Had those two characters not blown me away, I would probably have rated this a 2 1/2 star; honestly I didn't particularly like the portrayal of Harry's character in this play, and that felt so odd. The plot was redundant, and I'm genuinely convinced J.K didn't do much other than approve the script, because it certainly doesn't sound like her writing. However, I have to say it was fun to read (if you ignore all the massive plot holes); so my advice would be to enjoy it as you would a very <i>far-fetched</i> fan fiction.That being said, seeing this personally played out on stage, has been upgraded to the top of my wish-list.</span>  <a data-text-id="3099183764659753635" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1714544575">  <td colspan="2">    <div
