itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1699364941" />    <a title="Catie" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1886642-catie"><img alt="Catie" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1385169623p2/1886642.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1699364941?book_show_action=false">Aug 26, 2016</a>      <a title="Catie" class="user" name="Catie" href="/user/show/1886642-catie">Catie</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1886642-catie?shelf=ya">ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1886642-catie?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1886642-catie?shelf=plays">plays</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1886642-catie?shelf=series">series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1886642-catie?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1886642-catie?shelf=read-in-2016-summer">read-in-2016-summer</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1699364941" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4629956972921794267">3 1/2 stars<br /><br />The lighting, special effects, sets, and stage choreography were AMAZING. They truly made me believe that I was seeing magic, and they were incredibly creative in bringing the world of Harry Potter to life on stage. <br /><br />The plot of the play, however, left something to be desired. It relied heavily on family drama between Harry and his son, which mostly felt overly dramatic and tedious. The action largely took place in the past, with plenty of fun Easter eggs and reveals for the super-fans</span>  <span id="freeText4629956972921794267" style="display:none">3 1/2 stars<br /><br />The lighting, special effects, sets, and stage choreography were AMAZING. They truly made me believe that I was seeing magic, and they were incredibly creative in bringing the world of Harry Potter to life on stage. <br /><br />The plot of the play, however, left something to be desired. It relied heavily on family drama between Harry and his son, which mostly felt overly dramatic and tedious. The action largely took place in the past, with plenty of fun Easter eggs and reveals for the super-fans, but without much in the way of new material. I loved the development of Malfoy and his son, Scorpius, however. And, with five hours of performance, there was still plenty to love in this play.<br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="4629956972921794267" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1699364941">  <td id="reviewTextContainer1726454485" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2821496064532015204">Again, it feels as if I'm the last to arrive to the party, but hey ho - I'm here now. I can't help but admit I am a little disappointed. I knew it was never going to be the same, and I didn't really want it to be the same, because I was happy with how the series concluded. I got all the feels and there was lots of humour and good parts, but all it did is make me mourn for the previous characters all over again. <br /><br />I wish I had a time-turner to go back and read them all again for the first time to e</span>  <span id="freeText2821496064532015204" style="display:none">Again, it feels as if I'm the last to arrive to the party, but hey ho - I'm here now. I can't help but admit I am a little disappointed. I knew it was never going to be the same, and I didn't really want it to be the same, because I was happy with how the series concluded. I got all the feels and there was lots of humour and good parts, but all it did is make me mourn for the previous characters all over again. <br /><br />I wish I had a time-turner to go back and read them all again for the first time to experience the excitement all over again.</span>  <a data-text-id="2821496064532015204" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> class="user" name="Brittany (The Book Addictu0026#39;s Guide)" href="/user/show/4471081-brittany-the-book-addict-s-guide">Brittany (The Book Addictu0026#39;s Guide)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4471081-brittany-the-book-addict-s-guide?shelf=ya">ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4471081-brittany-the-book-addict-s-guide?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4471081-brittany-the-book-addict-s-guide?shelf=currently-own">currently-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4471081-brittany-the-book-addict-s-guide?shelf=2016">2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1543984760" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16148372402873864863">Book Added to TBR: IT'S REALLY HAPPENING!! And release day on Harry's birthday! Cheeky. I like it.<br /><br /><b>Initial Impressions 8/4/16:</b> Hmmm I'm not sure what I want to rate this. It was kind of all over the place for me. The overall plot was interesting and I really, really loved certain parts. Obviously it was a unique experience reading it as a script and I think it lost a LOT. Less atmosphere, less dialogue, less development. I didn't feel like the characters were well-represented? Maybe because they'</span>  <span id="freeText16148372402873864863" style="display:none">Book Added to TBR: IT'S REALLY HAPPENING!! And release day on Harry's birthday! Cheeky. I like it.<br /><br /><b>Initial Impressions 8/4/16:</b> Hmmm I'm not sure what I want to rate this. It was kind of all over the place for me. The overall plot was interesting and I really, really loved certain parts. Obviously it was a unique experience reading it as a script and I think it lost a LOT. Less atmosphere, less dialogue, less development. I didn't feel like the characters were well-represented? Maybe because they're so much older... But a lot of them felt far off from their younger counter-parts (although I've changed exponentially since I was 17 so... Fair enough) but I hated that Ron came off the way he did. He was such a lump and a putz with little personality and essentially was Hermione's lesser half. Hermione was a stronger personality, as she usually is, but I feel like she lost a lot of her logic and wisdom... How do you LOSE wisdom over the years? Harry was always a bit all over the place for me so that was about the same and Ginny was a total movie Ginny, not book Ginny. Ugh. There was a weird sexual tension between the Albus and Scorpius (was that just me? Them always commenting on the hugging thing?) and I honestly thought it was going to be revealed that one had a crush on the other, which would have been fine expect for the fact that it didn't and I was confused by them always bringing up hugging and the deep friendship feelings which sounded almost romantic. Maybe I was reading too much into that because I was looking for more depth! There were also a few characters from the series who make appearances (though I won't reveal who they were) and some were AWESOME and some were confusing, to say the least. <br /><br />Honestly, some of it was so much fun. Parts made me cry. Some made me laugh. But I also had moments where I scratched my head, questioned a lot, and even laughed out loud (not in a good way). Some of it was suuuuper cheesy and I can see why people said it read as fanfic. I think the fact that it was a rehearsal copy of a script really had a part in that too. You lose so much when you're not READING reactions, nuances, and tone of voice. Some of that is included but the atmosphere is greatly lost because of the format. So much is shown through the scenery and the acting (I imagine) that is not needed to include in a script, and I'm sure there are so many notes that aren't included to keep the book from being endless amounts of scenery and character notes. <br /><br />The overall plot was... a really interesting concept but seemingly poorly executed. This was like cramming multiple books into one book (or I suppose, one play) and concepts were sort of flying all over the place. It was really fun to see things from the original series turn up but other times, the references back to the original series was very cheesy or just plain inaccurate. (Small inaccuracies, in my opinion but it's Harry freakin' Potter. You don't think the fandom will pick up on this, you guys??) <br /><br />I mean, obviously this was specifically adapted for a play and that's how they wanted to tell this story... But I really, really wish it had been developed into an actual book instead of just giving us the rehearsal script. There was so much more of this story to tell! Things would have been a lot less cheesy if they had been developed or explained. (Although some things I'll never get over. They were just weird.) Everything felt really, really rushed and I would have rather had a simpler plot with more development instead of bursting from scene to scene. There was no time to really absorb anything and that also left very little room for character development. I don't care if we already know the majority of these characters -- they still need to have a personality. <br /><br />So great to see the future for Harry Potter but I just really feel a little let down by a short story. Overall, it felt messy and rushed and after sleeping on it, I think I'm left more disappointed than excited about the development. I would have loved to see this really developed in a novel or in a series. We needed so much more time with Albus to understand him a little better. I would have loved to see this great friendship between the two boys and their complicated friendship with Rose (oh, and don't get me started about her role in the end of the book. An even cheesier way to wrap things up. Yay). I always love more time at Hogwarts. I would have loved to see those little clues along the way to the big reveal. I was okay with what the plot WAS but it really just needed way more development. I kind of feel like if it can't be done well, best to leave it alone. <br /><br />I guess beggars can't be choosers! <br /><br />Now can we have an Ilvermorny series pretty please? <br /><br /><b>Full and organized review as originally posted <a href="http://www.bookaddictsguide.com/2016/08/19/harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-harry-potter-8-j-k-rowling-john-tiffany-jack-thorne/" rel="nofollow">HERE</a> on The Book Addict's Guide 8/16/16:</b> Obviously there are a lot of mixed emotions before starting the infamous eighth Harry Potter book. Naturally I was excited — because it’s Harry freakin’ Potter — but I also just didn’t quite feel as excited as I thought I should be. Before picking up the bound version of the play (since I guess we really shouldn’t be calling it a book as it was never intended to be an actual book), I knew there were a few things that were hindering my excitement that I ultimately expected to affect my overall enjoyment of the experience (and in fact, they all did play a part in that). I knew that J.K. Rowling was involved in the plot and creation of CURSED CHILD, but ultimately, it was not her writing on the page. I knew that I was going to be reading a rehearsal script for the play and that the formatting might throw off my experience. And I knew that I’d be reading about adult Harry, Ron, Hermione, and company and I didn’t know if I’d like where their characters were in their adult lives since we had some pretty cheesy things happen in the epilogue of DEATHLY HALLOWS, and that actually was J.K. Rowling’s writing.<br /><br />The short version of this review is that CURSED CHILD was kind of all over the place for me. The overall plot was interesting and I really, really loved certain parts but other parts of it just seemed so… I guess amateur is the best word I can think of at the moment, although that seems quite harsh. We’ve grown to love J.K. Rowling’s stories and how detailed they are and there were just certain things about CURSED CHILD that didn’t seem like they were plotted out very well. Other parts seemed completely random and totally uncharacteristic of the series. The overall concept of this story of the next generation was a really interesting concept but seemingly poorly executed. This was like cramming multiple books into one book (or I suppose, one play) and concepts were sort of flying all over the place. It was really fun to see things from the original series turn up but other times, the references back to the original series was very cheesy or just plain inaccurate. Small inaccuracies in some parts (it was “Happee Birthdae” not “Happy Birthday”), and some big timeline disagreements in others but it’s Harry freakin’ Potter. You don’t think the fandom will pick up on these? (They totally did.) It was just things like that that really made me feel like this was sloppily put together and that these playwrights who put the CURSED CHILD play together were missing some really core feelings and elements of the series.<br /><br />I knew that I was going to be reading a script when I started and it was definitely a unique experience but I think the format lost a LOT in translation. There was less atmosphere, less dialogue, and less development which obviously you’ll get through the actors of the play and you won’t see in a rehearsal script. I just felt like I lost so much not READING those reactions, nuances, tone of voice, sensory descriptions — I mean, really a little of everything that brings the world of Harry Potter to life. Some of that is included in the script notes but the atmosphere is greatly lost because of the format. I mean, obviously this was specifically adapted for a play and that’s how they wanted to tell this story… But I really, really wish it had been developed into an actual book instead of just giving us the rehearsal script. There was so much more of this story to tell! Things would have been a lot less cheesy if they had been developed or explained. (Although some things I’ll never get over. They were just weird.) Everything felt really, really rushed and I would have rather had a simpler plot with more development instead of bursting from scene to scene. There was no time to really absorb anything and that also left very little room for character development. I don’t care if we already know the majority of these characters — they still need to have a personality.<br /><br />I also didn’t feel like the characters were well-represented at all. Part of it may be because they’re so much older… But a lot of them felt far off from their younger counter-parts (although I’ve changed exponentially since I was 17 so… fair enough in some respects) but I hated that Ron came off the way he did. He was such a lump and a putz with little personality and he was essentially was Hermione’s lesser half. Hermione was a stronger personality, as she usually is, but I feel like even she lost a lot of her logic and wisdom… How do you LOSE wisdom over the years? Harry was always a bit all over the place for me so that was about the same and Ginny was a total movie Ginny, not book Ginny. (Ugh.) The main adult characters (the aforementioned) seemed so stiff and one-dimensional which is hard to bear after spending a full series with them, reading the series multiple times, and watching the movies over and over. We know these characters. They are our childhood. They are our friends. We grew up with them. To see them underdeveloped and misrepresented in a sequel like this just felt so uncaring. There were also a few characters from the series who make appearances (though I won’t reveal who they were) and some were AWESOME and some were confusing, to say the least.<br />There was a weird sexual tension between the Albus and Scorpius (which I thought was just me at first but there are tons of THINGS all over Buzzfeed and Tumblr about this so I’m not alone) and I honestly thought it was going to be revealed that one had a crush on the other, or that they both shared romantic feelings. That would have been fine expect for the fact that it didn’t happen and I was confused by them always bringing up hugging and the deep friendship feelings which when described really sounded like something more than just a deep platonic friendship bond.<br /><br />It was so great to see the future for Harry Potter but I just really feel a little let down by a short story. Some of it was so much fun. Parts made me cry. Some made me laugh. But I also had moments where I scratched my head, questioned a lot, and even laughed out loud (not in a good way). Some of it was suuuuper cheesy and I can see why people said it read as fanfic. Overall, it felt messy and rushed and the more I think about it and discuss it, the more I realize that I’m more disappointed than excited about the development. I would have loved to see this really developed in a novel or in a series. We needed so much more time with Albus to understand him a little better. I would have loved to see this great friendship between the two boys and their complicated friendship with Rose (oh, and don’t get me started about her role in the end of the book. An even cheesier way to wrap things up. Yay). I always love more time at Hogwarts. I would have loved to see those little clues along the way to the big reveal. I was okay with what the plot WAS (except for some parts) but it really just needed way more development. I kind of feel like if it can’t be done well, best to leave it alone, and I don’t think CURSED CHILD did justice to this series at all.<br /><br />We did beg for an eighth book though… so I guess beggars can’t be choosers?<br /><br />But now can we beg for an Ilvermorny series, pretty please? (Will I ever learn my lesson?)</span>  <a data-text-id="16148372402873864863" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div href="/user/show/22379145-norman">Norman</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok"     <span id="freeTextContainer12606366161869573504">Cannot believe all the positive reviews I am seeing. <br />This was a huge disappointment and I did not even have high expectations in the first place. <br />It started out pretty interesting to me but as soon as they started going back to events of the books all of this became a huge mess. The only thing I really liked was Scorpius. <br /><br />I literally just finished this but at the top of my head my main problems were: <br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<br />-The Original Trio: Awful, all of it was awful. I mean have these people read the</span></span>  <span id="freeText12606366161869573504" style="display:none">Cannot believe all the positive reviews I am seeing. <br />This was a huge disappointment and I did not even have high expectations in the first place. <br />It started out pretty interesting to me but as soon as they started going back to events of the books all of this became a huge mess. The only thing I really liked was Scorpius. <br /><br />I literally just finished this but at the top of my head my main problems were: <br /><br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<br />-The Original Trio: Awful, all of it was awful. I mean have these people read the books ??? HERMIONE doesn´t realize that Ron isn´t Ron, a guy she has grown up with, been in love with forever, and spent most of her life with? Then she hides a Time-Turner in a BOOK in her office. RON is basically based on everything thats wrong with him in the movies. He isn´t doing anything besides eating and saying dumb shit. And worst of all HARRY. The orphan boy spending most of this life trying to find a family and acceptance tells his own son that he wishes he wasn´t his son?? And goes on to tell him who he can and can´t be friends with. I mean thats pretty much going against everything Harry stands for. <br /><br />-It was a mistake trying to include so many of the original characters. Cedric as a death eather (?), Dumbledore appears in weird ass dream sequences, Hagrid has two lines in a single scene, and even the Dursleys and Harry´s parents, it was all too much.<br /><br />- Way too many dream sequences and alternative realities. <br /><br />-Voldemort´s child : Get this away from me. <br /><br /> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />Sorry I am just a bit angry xD No idea how to rate this. </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1714196760" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1714196760" />    <a title="Lindsey Lynn" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/31966250-lindsey-lynn"><img alt="Lindsey Lynn" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467170289p2/31966250.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1714196760?book_show_action=false">Sep 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Lindsey Lynn" class="user" name="Lindsey Lynn" href="/user/show/31966250-lindsey-lynn">Lindsey Lynn</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">                  <em>                    This review has been hidden because it contains spoilers. To view it,                    <a href="#" onclick="Effect.toggle(u0026#39;reviewTextContainer1714196760u0026#39;); return false;">click here.</a>                  </em>              <span id="reviewTextContainer1714196760" class="readable"                    style="display:none"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2787662232514746985">4.5/5 Stars!<br /><br />I know what you're thinking... Not 5 stars? I'll get into that. Keep reading :)<br /><br />I am a huge Harry Potter fan, I remember getting all of the books as they released and having to wait for months to a year in between. This follows Harry and Giny's son Albus and his closest friend, a bit of an unexpected paring. Albus doesn't really feel like he belongs at home or at Hogwarts.<br /><br />I personally was just a bit disconnected from the newer generation because of how short this was. Also of course i</span>  <span id="freeText2787662232514746985" style="display:none">4.5/5 Stars!<br /><br />I know what you're thinking... Not 5 stars? I'll get into that. Keep reading :)<br /><br />I am a huge Harry Potter fan, I remember getting all of the books as they released and having to wait for months to a year in between. This follows Harry and Giny's son Albus and his closest friend, a bit of an unexpected paring. Albus doesn't really feel like he belongs at home or at Hogwarts.<br /><br />I personally was just a bit disconnected from the newer generation because of how short this was. Also of course it being written in play script format takes a bit away from the emotional attachments. I wish I connected a bit more but there were actual portions where I wanted to strangle a couple of people haha.<br /><br />I really enjoyed being back with this wonderful motley crew. Seeing all of the original characters grown up and working, is just really heartfelt. Seeing some of the characters again interact but in a more adult fashion is just brilliant. I also love some of the different 'realities' one made me cry immensely. I won't spoil of course but if anyone wants to talk Harry let me know!!!<br /><br />Overall... this over. The series is done. It is so bittersweet. I love this world and it will forever be my favorite and a place I can call home. </span>  <a data-text-id="2787662232514746985" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1714196760">  <td colspan="2">    <div imgcol" href="/user/show/4615008-lauren-lauren-reads-ya"><img alt="Lauren (Lauren Reads YA)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1478088662p2/4615008.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1544775109?book_show_action=false">Aug 04, 2016</a>      <a title="Lauren (Lauren Reads YA)" class="user" name="Lauren (Lauren Reads YA)" href="/user/show/4615008-lauren-lauren-reads-ya">Lauren (Lauren Reads YA)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/29058155-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4615008-lauren-lauren-reads-ya?shelf=i-own">i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4615008-lauren-lauren-reads-ya?shelf=harry-potter">harry-potter</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4615008-lauren-lauren-reads-ya?shelf=2016">2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1544775109" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4584985021606543482">What the fuck did I just read.<br /><br />I mean, it was fun, I enjoyed the first half or so a lot, but WHAT. Can't wait to hopefully see the play and just whisper "what the fuck" to myself the whole time.</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1544775109">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1544775109" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=1544775109u0026amp;resource_type=Reviewu0026amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F29056083-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child---parts-one-and-two">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1544775109'><a id="like_count_review_1544775109" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1544775109?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">35 likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1544775109" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1544775109" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=falseu0026amp;format=jsonu0026amp;lc=35u0026amp;rating%5Bpage%5D=7u0026amp;rating%5Brating%5D=1u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_id%5D=1544775109u0026amp;rating%5Bresource_type%5D=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a id="commentLink_1544775109" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(u0026#39;reviewu0026#39;, 1544775109, true, u0026#39;u0026#39;); return false;">comment</a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<a href="/review/show/1544775109?book_show_action=falseu0026amp;from_review_page=7">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1544775109' style='display: none;'></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_1544775109' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 1544775109, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1762432814" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1762432814" />    <a title="Rikke" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4327582-rikke"><img alt="Rikke" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467464893p2/4327582.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1762432814?book_show_action=false">Sep 20, 2016</a>      <a title="Rikke" class="user" name="Rikke" href="/user/show/4327582-rikke">Rikke</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=theatre">theatre</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4327582-rikke?shelf=owned-books">owned-books</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1762432814" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4464305554798061166">God, no. This was horrible. If it wasn't tragically getting the last word in the Harry Potter-saga, I could perhaps laugh it off, or even accept it as a weird writing experiment. But as it is, people are referring to it as the 'eight Harry Potter book', and I will not, cannot accept it. <br /><br />In all honesty, this was bad. And not even a charming, nostalgic, guilty pleasure kind of bad. It was all bad. Wrong. Horrid. And filled with plot holes.<br /><br />It's not that it is written as a play, and the overall atmo</span>  <span id="freeText4464305554798061166" style="display:none">God, no. This was horrible. If it wasn't tragically getting the last word in the Harry Potter-saga, I could perhaps laugh it off, or even accept it as a weird writing experiment. But as it is, people are referring to it as the 'eight Harry Potter book', and I will not, cannot accept it. <br /><br />In all honesty, this was bad. And not even a charming, nostalgic, guilty pleasure kind of bad. It was all bad. Wrong. Horrid. And filled with plot holes.<br /><br />It's not that it is written as a play, and the overall atmosphere has been changed. Of course a change of atmosphere is to be excepted, when long descriptions of school capes and spell lessons are switched for witty lines and a fast-moving plot in order to keep an audience engaged. Of course a change of atmosphere is unavoidable, when everything needs to be doable on a stage, while keeping a reasonable pace.<br />Rowling doesn't have time for descriptions of school capes or minor characters. She doesn't have time to invent new spells or even revisit old classes. A play is all about <i>what you can see</i>, and not as much about <i>what you are told to see</i>. I get it. And it doesn't necessarily make this a failure.<br /><br />What does make this a failure is however all the plot holes. The reuse of dear and beloved characters who seemed to have completely lost their <b>purpose and integrity</b> in the years that has passed. A blabbering Ron who only mumbles jokes and looks confused – embarrassing teenagers with love potions, even though he was nearly killed by one himself. In this play, Ron is every bit as comical and inconsequential as he himself feared he would be. <br />Oh, and add to the mix a sobbing Dumbledore <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[who of course is partly excused by being a portrait and thereby a shadow of himself ... but still. A sobbing Dumbledore? Even in a painting, I find it hard to believe. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>, an insecure Professor McGonagall, a completely insane trolley-witch <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[(WHY was that stunt even necessary?!) <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>, an evil Rose Granger-Weasley and a Harry Potter without any human understanding. <br /><br />God, I really had hoped for better fates for my favorite characters.<br /><br />And then, there's the plot. First of all, <i>why</i> timeturners and why now? It seems like such an obvious answer to Voldemort's earlier struggles, that I can hardly see why every death eater suddenly would remember them years after his downfall. It seems too convenient. Too unlikely. Why would Hermione have had the use of a time-turner in book four, if it was basically a weapon to resurrect Voldemort all this time? Why would a school-girl have been granted such a dangerous weapon, at her free disposal? No. Just no.<br /><br />Secondly, and perhaps more gravely, time-travel is such a lazy plot device. It allows Rowling to play largely on nostalgia; to not invent any new scenes, places or even plot points. She takes the reader back into her beloved character's past, not bothering to introduce new places, but simply to revisit. This story adds nothing new to the world of Harry Potter. It doesn't explore or even elaborate how the wizarding world works after Voldemort, but only shows us what we already know. <br /><br />Can you really call this a 'continuation', much less a 'contemporary Potter book', when it doesn't reveal anything about the wizarding world in 2016?<br /><br />And while I promised myself, I wouldn't fault the book for its form, it still feels very abrupt. A play always comes in parts, and this play comes in two, but those two parts feel like two separate stories. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[The split between the first time-travel problem and the next is simply too wide. The story could have been finished by Scorpius' own problem solving, and yet it keeps going on. To prove what? To do what? To repeat itself once again?! <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />There were times when this book felt like a joke. Almost as if Rowling was parodying herself. With concepts like <b>Voldemort day</b> (really? even the name sounds like child play), and even a key plot point <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[like Bellatrix and Voldemort having a baby together – wasn't he supposed to be incapable of love? I'm having a hard time picturing him list sex as a priority -  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>seems unbelievable. <br /><br />This book is horribly structured, its time-turner plot is completely weak and unoriginal, and the characters are flat ghosts of people I used to love. While it might work as a play on stage, it falls horribly flat on paper – and shouldn't have been published if it couldn't stand alone. I was even bored when I read this. I didn't care to find out, what happened next, because I couldn't recognize the world I'd stumbled into. The fast pacing is so ridiculous that it actually works against itself. <br /><br />There were things I hated. Things I loathed. And even things I could have overlooked, if it wasn't for this: <br /><br />I didn't care. I didn't care about my childhood friends who populates this book. The story didn't serve as a reunion, instead it served as a reminder. A reminder of places I used to go and characters I used to love. Rowling imitates herself, instead of creating something new. And that is the biggest failure of all.<br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />(Oh, and then there's the fact that Rowling really didn't write this. But as the frontcover gives her almost all the credit, so do I.) </span>  <a data-text-id="4464305554798061166" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span> likes</span></a>u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1762432814" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1762432814" ref="like" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1563791652" />    <a title="lauren ♡ (wonderless <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1563791652?book_show_action=false">Aug 17, 2016</a>      <a title="lauren ♡ (wonderless reviews)" class="user" name="lauren ♡ (wonderless reviews)" href="/user/show/3866561-lauren-wonderless-reviews">lauren ♡ (wonderless reviews)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3866561-lauren-wonderless-reviews?shelf=made-me-cry">made-me-cry</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3866561-lauren-wonderless-reviews?shelf=own">own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3866561-lauren-wonderless-reviews?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3866561-lauren-wonderless-reviews?shelf=genre-fantasy-series">genre-fantasy-series</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1563791652" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9664932751127076554"><a href="https://wonderlessreviews.wordpress.com/2016/08/04/i-just-have-a-lot-of-mixed-feelings-review-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-by-j-k-rowling-john-tiffany-jack-thorne/" rel="nofollow"> <b>Read this review and a more in depth spoiler discussion @ my blog Wonderless Reviews</b> </a><br><br>If I was to sum this review up in a GIF it would be:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1471428334ra/20048878.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The Cursed Child is first and foremost a play. I could easily see which lines were written solely to get a reaction from the audience. You can’t go into this expecting to read a book similar to the previous seven. There’s no description or build up because it relies on our prior knowledge of the universe. Again, I can’t complain about this because it’s a scrip</span>  <span id="freeText9664932751127076554" style="display:none"><a href="https://wonderlessreviews.wordpress.com/2016/08/04/i-just-have-a-lot-of-mixed-feelings-review-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child-by-j-k-rowling-john-tiffany-jack-thorne/" rel="nofollow">  <b>Read this review and a more in depth spoiler discussion @ my blog Wonderless Reviews</b></a><br><br>If I was to sum this review up in a GIF it would be:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1471428334ra/20048878.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The Cursed Child is first and foremost a play. I could easily see which lines were written solely to get a reaction from the audience. You can’t go into this expecting to read a book similar to the previous seven. There’s no description or build up because it relies on our prior knowledge of the universe. Again, I can’t complain about this because it’s a script. I know some people might be feeling disappointed because one of my favourite things about the Harry Potter series was the vivid imagery that J.K. Rowling created. That’s another important thing to remember J.K. Rowling didn’t write this script.<br><br>I know there’s a lot of debate about whether this should be included in canon and I think that as long as you’re being respectable that decision is entirely your own. Personally, for me, I hated the epilogue in Deathly Hallows so I just imagine book 7 ended on the last chapter. I think the great thing about books is that we can make the story our own. Canon doesn’t have to be everything.<br><br>The experience I had whilst reading this was absolutely magical. The moment I read the first page I felt like I had been transported back into time. It actually felt surreal. It was just so great being back in the world of Harry Potter. I was reminded just how much I loved these characters and how important this book series is to me. I had a very emotional reading experience. My parents probably thought I was crazy because I was talking to myself the whole way through. I remember walking around the house with my Kindle and taking it with me when I had to go do some grocery shopping and I felt like I was 15 again and reading Order of the Phoenix for the first time. I had the most amazing time reading this book.<br><br>However, I had some issues with the plot. Again, it had nothing to do with the script format. I knew going into this to expect a rapid pace – that wasn’t the problem. I hate saying this, but at times The Cursed Child read like fan fiction and not the good kind. I’m in no way trying to shame fan fiction – I think it’s amazing. However, as a published work I expect not to see every cliche trope that’s ever existed crammed in. Maybe this is my fault for having read fan fiction since I was 14. I just feel like at times it was a bit too ridiculous and the fan service too heavily obvious.<br><br>Then there’s the characters. This is set nineteen years after Deathly Hallows so the Golden Trio and co. are all middle aged adults now. They definitely are going to be different to their teenage selves, but to me they felt too different at times. Certain things happened that I could NEVER imagine them doing. I’m aware that everyone in this series is flawed and that’s what I love about it, but even then I couldn’t see some things that went down happening.<br><br><blockquote>“Those we love never truly leave us, Harry. There are things that death cannot touch.”</blockquote><br><br>That’s pretty much all I can say without spoiling anything. I had a seriously hard time trying to decide on a rating. If I was reviewing the plot alone it would probably be 3 stars, but reading experience would have been 5 stars. I couldn’t ignore all the issues I had though so I settled on 4. I think The Cursed Child can be really enjoyable if you go in with an open mind and remember it’s a play – not J.K. Rowling writing an eight novel in the series.</span>  <a data-text-id="9664932751127076554" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1671191933" />    <a title="Sushi" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/47078917-sushi"><img alt="Sushi" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465219426p2/47078917.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1671191933?book_show_action=false">Aug 06, 2016</a>      <a title="Sushi" class="user" name="Sushi" href="/user/show/47078917-sushi">Sushi</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/47078917-sushi?shelf=plays">plays</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1671191933" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13549898689045036043">I don't remember the last time I wanted to love a book so much. And though it's nothing like I expected it would be, it's safe to say that being back at Hogwarts was well worth the wait.<br /><br /><b> "The truth is a beautiful and terrible thing, and should therefore be treated with great caution." </b><br /><br />And the ugly truth is, this will never be an extension of the canon to me. Just nope. Individually, the script would make for an amazing play, but it's not fair to even compare this to the rest. It all ended with t</span>  <span id="freeText13549898689045036043" style="display:none">I don't remember the last time I wanted to love a book so much. And though it's nothing like I expected it would be, it's safe to say that being back at Hogwarts was well worth the wait.<br /><br /><b> "The truth is a beautiful and terrible thing, and should therefore be treated with great caution." </b><br /><br />And the ugly truth is, this will never be an extension of the canon to me. Just nope. Individually, the script would make for an amazing play, but it's not fair to even compare this to the rest. It all ended with the Battle of Hogwarts, and that's how it should stay. <br /><br />But I also know it wouldn't be fair to compare the characterization and plot-line with the other 7. Reading a play-script is no cakewalk as it's clunky, and moreover, the only way to get to know what's happening is through the dialogue. The little things that make books so special, like character traits and pretty prose are absent, which makes it a bit harder to dip our toes back into our beloved potterverse. This is a point I wish I kept in mind before I stared: It's a script and plays are almost always better seen than read. <br /><br />But, that didn't stop me from freaking out over:<br /><br />1) Albus Severus Potter. The name itself is a work of art. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ And can we please talk about the fact that he's a SLYTHERIN!!!  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> Though I found it hard to sympathize with all his "problems", he stands for everything HP has been. He stands for Dumbledore's valor and Snape's quiet suffering. He's proof that all the lives lost in the Battle of Hogwarts haven't been for nothing, and that love may be your biggest weakness, but it will also be your biggest ally when you need it.<br /><br />2) Scorpius. God, the name brought tears to my eyes. Not the happy kind. Though the name itself is outrageous, this kid is a total sweetheart!! And the fact that <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ he's best friends with the Potter kid AND he has a crush on Ron and Hermoines' daughter Rose !!!! <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> just made me love him even more!<br /><br />3) All the time traveling and revisiting old memories. Time is not something to be messed with, and it was entertaining watching how circumstances and the simplest of decisions can make or break an entire community.<br /><br />4) The fast pace. A bit too much for my liking in the beginning when three years passed before I flipped even a single page, and though I guess that was necessary for the story, it just left me aggravated. But then, I got used to it and the whole play thing too, and it just made it all so much better considering all the mini heart attacks I was getting about where the book was headed.<br /><br />5) <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ HE HAS A KID. HE HAS A KID. HE HAS A KID. DID NOT SEE THAT COMING!!!  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />6) <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[ WITH BELLATRIX OF ALL PEOPLE!!!!! I guess I should've seen that coming, but hey, I was too numb over the fact that he had a kid!  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />7) HAGRID. This man will forever be my favorite character, and those stolen "moments" we got with him made it all so worth it.<br /><br />8) The humor. It has JKR written all over it. <br /><br /><b> "There is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world. Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic." </b><br /><br /><br /><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="13549898689045036043" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1671191933">  <td </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1599778901" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1599778901" />    <a title="Keertana" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/7584700-keertana"><img alt="Keertana" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1438801223p2/7584700.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1599778901?book_show_action=false">Aug 07, 2016</a>      <a title="Keertana" class="user" name="Keertana" href="/user/show/7584700-keertana">Keertana</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/7584700-keertana?shelf=why-the-hype">why-the-hype</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1599778901" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5752765549728886801">Like it is for a lot of people, Hogwarts is my home. And I'm not even going to lie: I missed it. There is something magical about being back in these halls, with Minerva as headmaster, using the invisibility cloak, seeing the Marauder's Map...it's a gift, in and of itself. That being said, this "epilogue" of sorts to the Harry Potter series leaves a lot to be desired.<br /><br />What I enjoyed about this script is the thought and care given to a lot of these character relationships. Harry struggles to be a</span>  <span id="freeText5752765549728886801" style="display:none">Like it is for a lot of people, Hogwarts is my home. And I'm not even going to lie: I missed it. There is something magical about being back in these halls, with Minerva as headmaster, using the invisibility cloak, seeing the Marauder's Map...it's a gift, in and of itself. That being said, this "epilogue" of sorts to the Harry Potter series leaves a lot to be desired.<br /><br />What I enjoyed about this script is the thought and care given to a lot of these character relationships. Harry struggles to be a father, to deal with the aftermath of his childhood--his life with the Dursleys, his very justified fear of Voldemort--and I loved seeing him brought down from the perfect pedestal we often push him on. Albus, too, can't bear to be the son of Harry Potter. He's nothing like his father and though he's grateful for the world his father has given him, Hogwarts isn't a haven for him and neither is his home. <br /><br />I love reading dark, intense character portraits. If this entire book was just about Albus struggling to find his place, in Hogwarts and in his family, I think I could have rated it higher. Both old and new characters are given similarly complex storylines and that, for me, is where this sequel excels. However, it also fails to live up to its potential in a lot of important ways. For one, there are so many characters I was expecting to see in this and simply did not see at all: Teddy Lupin, Hugo Granger-Weasley, James and Lily Potter (very little screen time), and Neville Longbottom to name a few.<br /><br />The most problematic aspect of this novel, though, is its PLOT. A lot of reviewers have already mentioned this, but it bears repeating: plot holes. LOTS of plot holes. And this is a play that relies heavily on the plot, no matter how well-done the characters are. This is an entertaining read and the plot moves seamlessly, proving to be surprisingly easy to follow despite its convoluted-ness, and I have no doubt it translates well on-stage. But it felt unnecessary and rather silly. <br /><br />There are some very touching moments scattered throughout this play but it wasn't what I wanted it to be and it isn't a strong addition to this series. I'll be re-reading the original Harry Potter series for years to come and this, in my mind, isn't part of that.</span>  <a data-text-id="5752765549728886801" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1599778901"> comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1528802529" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1528802529" />    <a title="Drew The Reviewer" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25599529-drew-the-reviewer"><img alt="Drew The Reviewer" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1451757668p2/25599529.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1528802529?book_show_action=false">Sep 13, 2016</a>      <a title="Drew The Reviewer" class="user" name="Drew The Reviewer" href="/user/show/25599529-drew-the-reviewer">Drew The Reviewer</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1528802529" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer16838814328173511590">Holy fucking shit. The Cursed Child is absolutely phenomenal. It is the best book of the decade. Truly one of the best things I have ever read in my life. But of course, all of the Harry Potter books are one of the best things I have read in my life. I got this book at the midnight release and stayed up till 4AM reading it in one sitting. <br /><br />I don't even know how to describe how amazing this was. The way the returning characters transitioned into the time jump was so great. Everyone felt new and ol</span>  <span id="freeText16838814328173511590" style="display:none">Holy fucking shit. The Cursed Child is absolutely phenomenal. It is the best book of the decade. Truly one of the best things I have ever read in my life. But of course, all of the Harry Potter books are one of the best things I have read in my life. I got this book at the midnight release and stayed up till 4AM reading it in one sitting. <br /><br />I don't even know how to describe how amazing this was. The way the returning characters transitioned into the time jump was so great. Everyone felt new and old at the same time. I've never read characters like these. The flashbacks and nostalgia that occured when encountering characters like Hagrid and McGonagall killed me. <br /><br />Going into this, I really had no idea what the exact plot was. I am so glad that it was a surprise to me because it made the story that much better. The plot is just so fucking adventurous and entertaining. And the way this book connected with past events in the Harry Potter series and continued to make everything relevant just blew my mind.<br /><br />I am fucking stunned by this book. It deserves every award possible. I am dying to see this play in person. This is an epic Harry Potter story. As a fan, I am absolutely stunned by how beautiful, emotional, and jaw-droppingly breathtaking The Cursed Child is.<br /><br />(SPOILER WARNING) As soon as we found out that Voldemort had a child, I immediately predicted that Bellatrix was the mother. Also, getting to see Snape again in brand new material was so good. That was actually my favorite part of the book.</span>  <a data-text-id="16838814328173511590" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> </div>  </div>    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1551066202" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1551066202" />    <a title="Denisse" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/8759700-denisse"><img alt="Denisse" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1474862579p2/8759700.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1551066202?book_show_action=false">Aug 10, 2016</a>      <a title="Denisse" class="user" name="Denisse" href="/user/show/8759700-denisse">Denisse</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1551066202" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6039980686126257542">Very good. <b>But as much as the main idea is clever, John and Jack cannot compete with the impressive storytelling and plot building Rowling accustom us</b>, and of course this is not a book just a play, so forget about those incredible descriptions we used to have in the original series. But the idea is there, the magic is there, I can assure you this people, it hasn’t gone away. <b>More than an eight HP story, this is a family-problems play set in the Harry Potter world</b>, which is not a bad idea nor som</span>  <span id="freeText6039980686126257542" style="display:none">Very good. <b>But as much as the main idea is clever, John and Jack cannot compete with the impressive storytelling and plot building Rowling accustom us</b>, and of course this is not a book just a play, so forget about those incredible descriptions we used to have in the original series. But the idea is there, the magic is there, I can assure you this people, it hasn’t gone away. <b>More than an eight HP story, this is a family-problems play set in the Harry Potter world</b>, which is not a bad idea nor something I didn’t care reading, but, it is not exactly what I had in mind either. What I can say without spoiling anything is that the afterward of a complicated life is difficult and understanding that your children sometimes do almost the same stupid things you used to do as child is both scary and shocking. <b>Some details I didn’t like at all, but overall, for my generation there is nothing better than getting back to our most beloved fictional home; Hogwarts.</b> Few can compete with that feeling. <br /><br /><br /><i>  <b>“I didn’t choose, you know that? I didn’t choose to be his son.”</b></i><br /><br />Hay cosas demasiado grandes como para morir. Ahí tienen Star Wars, y aquí tienen otro ejemplo: <b>Harry Potter. </b><br /><br />Y como algo que no puede pasar así nada más, puede llegarnos de nuevo en cualquier forma. Y ahorita tenemos una obra de teatro de la vida de Harry Potter y su hijo Albus Severus 19 años después de la batalla de Hogwarts. <b>Y que nos da Rowling? Una probada de magia a través del tiempo. Que nos da Jack Thorne y John Tiffany? Una obra con mucha enseñanza contemporánea.</b> <br /><br />De alguna forma todo se mezcla muy bien y logras adentrarte en lo que esta pasando, pero al mismo tiempo estas esperando esa chispa…esa magia que se siente solo al volver a la saga original de Harry Potter, lamento decirles que no lo van a encontrar pero en su lugar tenemos una historia mucho más centrada en la realidad, una idea simple y una enseñanza poderosa.<br /><br /><b>Nuestros héroes y personajes favoritos regresan y se vuelven a enfrentar a la Magia Oscura.</b> Me gusto mucho ver pasajes clave de los libros pasados, me gusto el papel del tiempo y las dificultades de Harry en su nueva vida, que no todo fuera felicidad para el o sus compañeros.<br /><br />Como siempre, cuando algo proviene de Rowling, no nos falla a la hora de las enseñanzas y es que no importa las acciones horribles que hayan pasado, porque ya pasaron e intentar cambiarlas en lugar de aceptarlas e intentar vivir con ellas no es la solución. <br /><br />No puedo darle más puntuación porque si hubo una cosa que no me gustó nada. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Voldemort? Una hija? No, lo siento pero no queda, no va con el personaje en ningún aspecto. Y con Bellatrix, justo en los tiempos de la Batalla de Hogwarts? MENOS TODAVIA! Pero fue lo único que no me gusto.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br /><br />Si logras ver esta historia como una ramificación de la original y si logras entender que no se puede tener la profundidad que los libros tienen, vas a disfrutar mucho The Cursed Child, porque, tiene toda la vibra HP y no se puede negar. <br /><br /><b>Recomendado solo para los verdaderos fans!</b></span>  <a data-text-id="6039980686126257542" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter      <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1714861108?book_show_action=false">Aug 04, 2016</a>      <a title="Sabrina" class="user" name="Sabrina" href="/user/show/8940553-sabrina">Sabrina</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8940553-sabrina?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8940553-sabrina?shelf=read-in-2016">read-in-2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1714861108" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13843138076445572890">What bothers me most about the play is that it didn't feel like Harry Potter at all.<br /><br />Whenever I read a new Harry Potter book as a kid, I felt like I was in the Harry Potter universe. It was magical and lovely, and quickly became a source of nostalgia. All of the Harry Potter books carried this feeling, and still do when I re-read one of the books. It is a feeling that is completely absent here.<br /><br />I found the dialogue to be stilted, forced, and nothing like the characters I expected to recognize. I f</span>  <span id="freeText13843138076445572890" style="display:none">What bothers me most about the play is that it didn't feel like Harry Potter at all.<br /><br />Whenever I read a new Harry Potter book as a kid, I felt like I was in the Harry Potter universe. It was magical and lovely, and quickly became a source of nostalgia. All of the Harry Potter books carried this feeling, and still do when I re-read one of the books. It is a feeling that is completely absent here.<br /><br />I found the dialogue to be stilted, forced, and nothing like the characters I expected to recognize. I found myself rolling my eyes or laughing at a bad line pretty frequently. I'm sure this comes off better as a stage production, and I'd actually be pretty interested to see how they handle the special effects. For me, that doesn't forgive the ridiculous plot or bad dialogue. It didn't give me that Harry Potter feeling, but rather, the feeling of the bad fan fiction I used to read.<br /><br />UPDATE: The more I think about it, the worse it gets. There are so many plot holes. None of this works. I need to stop thinking about it. It's such a mess.</span>  <a data-text-id="13843138076445572890" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext elementListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1546967948" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1546967948" />    <a title="Silvana" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/666003-silvana"><img alt="Silvana" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477219410p2/666003.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1546967948?book_show_action=false">Sep 03, 2016</a>      <a title="Silvana" class="user" name="Silvana" href="/user/show/666003-silvana">Silvana</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">u0026nbsp;u0026middot;u0026nbsp;</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/29058155-harry-potter-and-the-cursed-child">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/666003-silvana?shelf=fyeahfantasy">fyeahfantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/666003-silvana?shelf=disappointing">disappointing</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/666003-silvana?shelf=sff-2016-reading-challenge">sff-2016-reading-challenge</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1546967948" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3070211427235455545">I don't know how to rate this. I want it to be NOT the 8th story (sigh) of Harry Potter. But it is. For Merlin's sake. Why. <br /><br />Ok. I know what was going to happen since I read the spoilers. They were horrible. I was prepared. I thought I was. <br />It turned out to be...well, the main plot points were just insane. Not in a good way. We'll get into that. I did like some of the funny scenes (Ron is amazing) and the heartwarming scenes (I think Draco will get more fans) and I did like Scorpius, who was actu</span>  <span id="freeText3070211427235455545" style="display:none">I don't know how to rate this. I want it to be NOT the 8th story (sigh) of Harry Potter. But it is. For Merlin's sake. Why. <br /><br />Ok. I know what was going to happen since I read the spoilers. They were horrible. I was prepared. I thought I was. <br />It turned out to be...well, the main plot points were just insane. Not in a good way. We'll get into that. I did like some of the funny scenes (Ron is amazing) and the heartwarming scenes (I think Draco will get more fans) and I did like Scorpius, who was actually a likable character, despite being very conveniently know-everything-at-the-right-time-and-place.<br /><br />First of all, the main plot and plot devices. IT DOES NOT FEEL POTTERY. IT DOES NOT PORTRAY A WORK OF JK ROWLING AND THUS HER NAME SHOULD NOT BE INCLUDED IN THE AUTHOR LIST. Well, ok she did make some contributions but I wonder how much. Jack Thorne approached her with HIS idea of an 8th story then JKR gave her blessing and most likely contributed to the writing. Maybe only the spells. Only. I just could not fathom on the idea that she - a brilliant plot writer - would condone something like...this. <br /><br />I was really upset when reading the big reveal scenes and the fact that they are NOT actually creating a new story but just using OLD scenes and stories in the Harry Potter books to the point where I asked, could you not create a new plot on your own? The fact that <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Amos Diggory was still NOT over Cedric's death is a lazy writing.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> Moreover, using those infernal devices as literary plot devices were even more lazy writing. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Bloody time-turners. Not just one but hey we got TWO.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> How very convenient.<br /><br />And the big kaboom. The Cursed Child. So<a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Voldemort and Bellatrix had a child together. HAHAHAHAHA. Before the Battle of Hogwarts. Somehow Voldemort had still the physical ability to impregnate someone. Somehow Bellatrix could have a baby in just three or four months before the Battle.  <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> I know this is a magical world but there are way too many suspension of belief. Oh wait. Maybe it was <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[an immaculate conception! Or Voldie used a sperm bank. Wait. Does Gringotts also provide sperm storage service? It is a bank, no? I don't see Voldie using muggle's sperm bank. Hmm maybe that'll be the 9th story. Harry Potter and Voldemort's Sperm Bank (and Legions of Cursed Children). <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span>. HAHA. HA. Sigh.<br /><br />(not-so) Minor ticks:<br /><a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Albus kissing Hermione in Ron's form. Several times. Gross. And I really don't like Albus. And I don't like mean Harry. Over the top. So dramatic.<br />Rose is a non-existent character. She was so promising. The actress looks great. But not much use except as the love interest. She was given so little.<br />In one of the timelines, Hermione became a bitter person because she did not marry Ron. Really? So the reason she would ever be happy is a guy??? That sets back the feminist streak in HPverse.<br />Triwizard tournament in loop. Argh stop.<br />Godric's Hollow. Harry's parents's deaths. Again.<br /> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> So. Many. Repetitions. <br /><br />This is the first canon fanfiction I read. I hate that it is canon. As a fanfiction, this is a good one. I will gladly read it in fanfiction.net. But it is not. I just don't want it to be my last image of a series which I love so dearly. Why it has to be canon, why, JKR? And are you going to issue the 9th story? When are you going to stop? <br /><br />So, 1 star since it is canon. 3 stars if it is not canon.<br /><br />PS: If you are thinking of buying this and haven't owned <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/31115463.Harry_Potter_and_The_Sorcerer_s_Stone_The_Illustrated_Edition" title="Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone The Illustrated Edition by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone: The Illustrated Edition</a>, buy THAT one instead.<br /><br />Further reading on why the Cursed Child also 'cursed' its female characters: <a target="_blank" href="http://mashable.com/2016/08/17/harry-potter-cursed-child-female-characters/#jGQXTUZDLGqt" rel="nofollow">http://mashable.com/2016/08/17/harry-...</a></span>  <a data-text-id="3070211427235455545" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr
